That since 1788 discrimination has been accepted and promoted by Australian laws and practices, particularly in the provision of work, in appointment to jobs, in promotion to positions of authority and lucrative incomes, in the provision of goods and services, in the provision of accommodation and generally in relation to political, economic and social institutions of power.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: That adequate and appropriate laws be immediately formulated and passed through the Parliament to render unlawful discrimination in all areas over which the Commonwealth holds power, namely, in employment of all persons in the Commonwealth Public Service and employed in Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and other bodies, in the provision of Commonwealth accommodation and goods and services and also in all areas over which legislation for the Australian Capital Territory would be valid.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Present income tax laws discriminate against single-income families.
2. It is unfair that families should pay more tax, the more unequally their total income is divided between spouses.
3. All marriages should be recognised as partnerships by allowing spouses to divide their joint income for taxation purposes.
4. The family, which is the natural and fundamental unit of society, should be an economic unit in tax laws.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament will reform income tax laws to allow the joint income of husband and wife to be equally divided between them for taxation purposes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aids for Disabled
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :

That the PADP (Program of Aids for Disabled People) Scheme, while in theory an excellent initiative, is not at present funded to an adequate level to provide all the aids listed. This will result in a substantial shortfall which will restrict the ability of the States to fully implement the scheme.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will increase the funding for the PADP Scheme to enable its total implementation.
And Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of Disabled
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The failure of the Federal Government to seek information from the census re disabled people-i.e. partial or total disability-to enable for adequate planning of, and for, types of services needed by disabled people to be undertaken.

2. The failure of the Federal Government to lead the way in employment of disabled people by employing a greater number of such people within the Commonwealth Public Service-note the small number currently employed within the Service.

3. The wastage of the Federal Government funds perpetuating large, bureaucratic institutions and organisations where there are often few disabled people on their boards and little emphasis is placed on consumer participation in decision making.
4. The failure of the Federal Government to encourage independence of disabled people, or to develop 'normalised' support systems-attendant care.
5. The failure of the Federal Government to provide 'noninstitutionalised' specialised accommodation for those people who would not be able to benefit from , or or cope with attendant care.
6. Failure by the Federal Government to alter, or create a 'disability' allowance means test free for all disabled people-this would assist with necessary equipment and mobility costs.
7. Failure to provide a national compensation scheme thus saving time and enabling people to be automatically covered in the event of a disability.
8. Failure by the federal government to abolish tariffs on all equipment available to the disabled-e.g. Optacon.
9. Mismanagement of Federal I.Y.D.P. Funds-e.g. non-receipt by some States of funds through unresolved negotiations.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that immediate action be taken to remedy the above stated and that the Federal Government recognise that disabled people are citizens who should have equal rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of Australian Parliament assembled. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament assembled take action as it deems appropriate to ensure that funding in the area of children's services which has been reduced by almost 40 per cent in real terms over the last five years, should be restored forthwith to the real value of funding allocated in the 1975-1976 budget and further that the annual budget allocation in the area of children's services should be spent in full for the purposes designated.

The Federal Government retains its existing responsibility for children's services and that, it not be passed on to State Government many of which have shown no commitment to child care over the past ten years.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action on the above mentioned issues.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

(a) Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

(b) The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilizers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
(c) The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognize that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Broadcasting and Television Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That because television and radio
(a) affect our social and moral environment,
(b) are family media watched and heard by many children at all times, and
(c) present too much explicit violence and sex,
they therefore need stronger control than other media and the existing standards need stricter enforcement in both national A.B.C., and commercial sectors.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: That the Australian Government will amend the Broadcasting and Television Act, in relation to both national and commercial broadcasters, to legislate
(a) for adequate and comprehensive programs in the best interests of the general public.
(b) for a 'Dual System of Regulation' enforced by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal by internal regulation and external control.
(c) for an independent consumer body to represent the best interests of the general public, and
(d) for immediate and effective penalties to be imposed for breaches of program and advertising standards.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This humble petition of citizens of this country are concerned with increased in house interest rates and that this Governmnent has not taken action to peg increases in such rates. We ask that the Government establish a maximum fixed interest rate on a First Mortgage that would cover the entire period of time for which the loan is taken out. The rate of interest to be set at the time of signing the contract.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Immigration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we protest at the continual refusal of the Commonwealth Government to seek the opinion of the Australian people as to whether or not we should remain a homogeneous European society, and that, against the advice of all public opinion polls it continues to dismantle the trouble free and cohesive structure of the Australian way of life; as it continues to promote and mislead the people on the alleged benefits of a multi-racial society.

That the Government seeks immediately to increase the percentage of Australians of British, Irish and other Caucasian background so that the traditions, heritage and the way of life of our people shall not be destroyed.
That Mr Grassby be dismissed as Commissioner for Community Relations as his racial bias renders him unsuitable to hold this position.
That the position of Commissioner for Community Relations be phased out as the need diminishes with an increase in the content of British, Irish and Caucasian people in the Australian population.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That we request that the Government take immediate steps to relieve us of the burden of increasing mortgage costs resulting from increasing home loan interest rates.

We find that the resultant increases in our mortgage payments have unduly caused a reduction in our standard of living, reflected in the severe difficulty we are experiencing meeting our household budgetary commitments.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should amend the relevant taxation Acts to provide for deduction of home loan interest payments with the necessary adjustments to PAYE deductions to give immediate relief to home buyers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Institute of Early Childhood Development
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of citizens in Victoria showeth that at a general meeting concern was expressed as to the necessity to retain the Institute of Early Childhood Development as an autonomous institution.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you would make note of the following resolution passed at a public meeting held in Melbourne on 12 August 1981:

We request that the Federal Government continue funding the Institute of Early Childhood Development as an autonomous specialist institution recognizing that it is unique in its capacity to serve the needs of the early childhood field in Victoria and throughout Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr N.A. Brown,Mr Falconer,Mr Fife,Mr Peacock and Dr Theophanous.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives as in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Queensland respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are aware that the proposed sales tax is only one aspect of a Budget needed to support the growth and development of our country.
And that every Australian, whether rich or poor must aid this aim.
But that the social conscience of a country must be judged by the way in which it responds to the needs of its poorest, most helpless citizens.
And that this latest imposition will be responsible for Australia being judged not only by its own people but by the rest of the world.

We, the citizens of Queensland most humbly pray that: In the cause of justice and equity, your Honourable Members will reject any attempt to impose a sales tax on all essential goods including packaging of foods, shoes, clothing, literature and building materials.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned members of parents and citizens associations respectfully showeth:

That retention of the Schools Commission and the Curriculum Development Centre in their present forms is essential for the balanced and progressive allocation of educational resources and facilities in the Australian community.

That serious concern has been generated by the decision within the Schools Commission guidelines, to cut funds to the general recurrent and capital programs by reallocation to transition, the decision not to implement the school improvement program; and the devisiveness created between government and non- government schools due to increases of $43.25 million to non-government schools while government schools funds have not increased.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the government will reverse these decisions-will retain the Schools Commission and Curriculum Development Centre in their original forms; retain the Schools Commission proposals including recurrent and capital funding proposals, basket of services and the schools improvement program.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Sydney respectfully showeth that your petitioners call upon Federal Parliament not to:
1. Lift the curfew at Kingsford-Smith Airport for any reason
2. Not to pursue the proposal to build an additional runway at Kingsford-Smith Airport.
These proposals, if carried out, would add greatly to the noise, stress and pollution for the thousands of residents who live in the densely populated suburbs around Kingsford-Smith Airport.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, Federal Parliament, Canberra. The humble petition of the undersigned residents of Hindmarsh Division, State of South Australia.

Petition that: Competition between banks and finance companies by giving ever increasing interest rates to obtain the investors' capital, is against the nation's best interest. It penetrates every form of activity by constant demands for higher wages to meet these explosive conditions.

It is an intolerable burden to the younger generation of family life, that by necessity are the recipients of these excessive interest rates that are catastrophic to house purchase and natural living. We therefore respectfully petition for an urgent annual realistic controlled reduction right 'across the board' on all existing and future interest rate agreements. With a maximum interest percentage ceiling on investors' capital, and a scale of interest charges for loans as appropriate.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will give effect to our submissions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the special privileges bestowed on the Deputy Prime Minister Mr Anthony MP and the Minister for Primary Industry Mr Nixon MP:

(1) That in 1964 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Anthony MP a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $17,964 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 4.75% and that at 1.10.81 the amount of principal outstanding was $15,005.

(2) That in 1970 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Nixon MP a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $30,352 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 6.25% and that at the 1.10.81 the amount of principal outstanding was $28,404.

(3) Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government immediately extend these most generous terms to the many thousands of young couples in South Australia who are at present suffering undue hardship and financial embarrassment due to high interest rates.

PETITION.TITLE: Motor Vehicle Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This Petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Burke respectfully showeth that:
1. the automotive products industry is vital to the livelihood and well being of many thousands of Australian workers and their families.
2. if imported automotive products are allowed to flow freely into the Australian market it will deprive over 100,000 workers in the industry of their work opportunities.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament recognise the rights of Australian workers in this industry and that proposals to reduce the level of protection in the future be rejected.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Government for the failure of its economic policies, for the grave economic and social distress those policies are inflicting on the community, and for the unfair and unjust way the Government is imposing the heaviest burden of disadvantage on those less able to bear it.
I would expect that the Government would want to proceed with this debate immediately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —In spite of the expectations of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden), the Government is prepared to suspend Standing Orders for that purpose. I seek leave of the House to move a motion to enable the Leader of the Opposition to move forthwith the motion of censure of which he has given notice for the next sitting.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving forthwith the motion of censure of which he has given notice for the next sitting.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion of Censure

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Government for the failure of its economic policies, for the grave economic and social distress those policies are inflicting on the community, and for the unfair and unjust way the Government is imposing the heaviest burden of disadvantage on those less able to bear it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a procedural point. Under the Standing Orders different times are permitted for speaking to a motion that is accepted by the Government as a motion of censure and a motion for which Standing Orders are suspended to allow the motion to be moved forthwith. Is this an issue which the Government regards as an issue of censure?
—No.

—It is remarkable that once again, when given the opportunity to defend in this Parliament in public debate the Government's record, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has gone into his funkhole. It is also equally significant that, instead of treating this motion of censure of the Government properly, the Government has sought to curtail the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: A year ago, at the start of this new Parliament, I reminded the House of what the people of Australia had a right to expect of their national government. I stressed that, while we in the Labor Party strongly opposed the actions and policies of this Government, we did not dispute the fact that the people had made their choice at the ballot box and had given the Government another three years to honour all the promises it had broken in its first five years in office . I commend all honourable members opposite to read the full text if they want to know how this country should have been governed over the past 12 months and how it could be governed in the next two years if they want to avoid the electoral disaster now staring them in the face. After all, it was the former right honourable member for Lowe who has just reminded Australians of the wasted years of this Government's leadership and why it was futile for him to stay any longer in the Parliament. It is the gelded colt from Kooyong who is now trying to raise a gallop by adopting the ALP's policies on taxes and interest rates to revitalise his frustrated ambitions to replace the Prime Minister before the next election.

The point is that exactly one year after I made the speech from which I would have quoted if we had had more time, it remains every bit as valid as it then was, and even more relevant. All that is different is that this Government has now squandered another 16 months, to the great cost of the rest of Australians, and grossly abused the mandate it received at the last election. That, Mr Speaker, is what this no confidence motion is all about. It is not just because we are now into the seventh year of the Prime Minister's sick parlour game which he calls 'fight inflation first', when we have not even reached the square marked 'start here'. Neither is it because all the major economic indicators on taxes, interest rates, unemployment, inflation and national growth are worse now than when this Government mugged its way into office in November 1975.

It is not just because 12 months ago this Government had yet another opportunity, at the beginning of a new parliamentary term, to put into practice all the unfulfilled pledges and promises it had lived on for five years, but then simply abandoned at the first opportunity. It is not because, in the three months in which this Parliament has been dormant, inflation has recorded its worst three month increase in five years, unemployment has jumped again, interest rates have climbed still higher to new record levels and the Government 's new sales taxes have begun to bite into families' pay packets. It is not only because, in calling the Parliament together, the Prime Minister plans one of the shortest autumn sittings on record, despite the economic mess into which his tired and failed policies are pushing this country.

Any one piece of this evidence of the Government's economic mismanagement should be enough to earn the censure of this Parliament. Together, it becomes a wholesale indictment demanding resignation. Like its constituent Ministers, however, this Government would not resign even when caught red handed. It remains self-evident that any board of directors or group of employees who behaved as this Government does would be sacked immediately if not gaoled for fraud, dishonest practices and perjury. The Government condemns itself out of its own mouth. In his election policy speech 16 months ago the Prime Minister fantasised as follows:
Today, a new spirit, a new enthusiasm, a new dynamism, is at work in Australia.

He was speaking of the only job creation scheme in a 69 page policy speech, and even then it was another Fraser myth. Recent headlines in our national newspapers are bereft of any inkling of this new dynamism that our Prime Minister professed to see working so hard at the time of the election campaign. Those newspaper headlines are the reality of this Government's economic incompetence. All the things that should be coming down-I refer to taxes, inflation, unemployment and interest rates-are going up. All those indicators that should be going up-I refer here to living standards, consumer spending and business confidence-are smartly coming down. The Prime Minister's goebbelising of the truth is endemic in his Cabinet. Four months ago the Treasurer (Mr Howard ) was asked by my colleague the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) about interest rates. The Treasurer replied:

All of the indications in recent weeks are that the climate for interest rates has improved in Australia. There are a number of very encouraging signs that we have started to turn the corner. All in all, the Budget strategy designed to take pressure off interest rates appears to be working.

He should be a teacher in a nursery school. The children might believe him. The Treasurer made that statement on 14 October last year. Like the Prime Minister's new dynamism, the Budget strategy was not at work then, and it still is not. Since the Budget, interest rates have increased on large trading bank deposits, trading bank prime borrowings, commercial bills, interest rate futures, finance company debenture raisings and building society mortgages. It is now only a matter of time before bank home loan rates again surge upwards. The Government knows this and so does the financial community. The pressure is simply too great . Australia is being pushed deep into a nasty winter of economic discontent by Government actions. Economic activity is being stricken by a vicious credit squeeze. Bank bills will go beyond 20 per cent and Treasury notes beyond 18 per cent by June if present policies continue. Housing mortgages will go up by more than one per cent, and special overdraft rates for small business and funds for the farm sector will dry up.

The Government has plotted a course which it doggedly pursues and which can be described only as economic madness. What the Fraser Government has achieved has been to establish the age of usury in Australia. Speculators, profiteers, boosters and the get-rich-quick are giggling all the way to the bank. The superannuated, the home buyer, small business and farmers are the bunnies. They pay the cost of the brazen rip-off. Government policies are scourging Australian investors, discouraging them from putting their money and faith in real assets for the benefit of Australia. I repeat that the Government is inexorably propelling the economy along a course of economic madness-more wasted years and more bitter disappointment for the people of this great nation.

Someone else who understands what is going to happen is the Victorian Premier, Mr Thompson, which is why he has called his scheduled State election for 3 April instead of late May when it is due. Clearly the Premier has been forewarned by his Federal colleagues that the Fraser Government cannot keep the lid on bank home loan interest rates any longer than the first week of April, no matter how far in front in the opinion polls the State Labor Opposition obviously is. In the meantime, Australians can judge for themselves just how accurate and how reliable the Treasurer's Budget analysis is, based on his 14 October statement. Of course, I feel sure the Treasurer has some artful form of words to blame someone else for getting the Budget strategy wrong. If nothing else the Government is expert in blaming others for its own mistakes and failures. For six years the Government has variously blamed the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the trade union movement, its Public Service advisers, the Opposition, weak employers, lazy dole bludgers, timid investors, the State Premiers and any other handy scapegoat for just about everything that has gone sour in the economy.

Given that taxes are at record levels, that interest rates are the highest in our history, that inflation is taking off again, that the deficit is now out of control, that unemployment is 130,000 higher than when the Government came into office, that the value of the dollar is seriously out of kilter with other currencies, that economic growth is slowing markedly, that our balance of payments is in trouble, that living standards are down by an average of $20 a week, that wages are rising sharply and that our manufacturing and home building industries are in poor shape-given all these factors, either the Government is the unluckiest government ever to take office or it is run by a Cabinet in which distortion of the truth is a deliberate instrument of policy. I do not propose to take bets on which option would attract most support in Australia today. It is a theme the Treasurer pursued with vigour on radio this morning, blaming overseas conditions. Yet it was the Prime Minister who, seven years ago, scornfully said:
I do not believe that men and women are governed by inexorable events beyond their control

When political leaders say the present situation cannot be helped, that it is part of a world situation, they are expressing the futility of their own leadership, when, if they were men of real stature, they would be saying, 'We can overcome.'

I ask the Prime Minister, in line with those loftily declared beliefs, whether he is now ready to express to the Australian people the futility of his own leadership. I mention in passing, Mr Speaker, that you no doubt remember very well the particular speech from which I have just quoted. It was made four months before you were stabbed in the back by the man who delivered it. Australia has now had more than six years of running backwards. We are now in the seventh year of Fraserism and we find that, in spite of all our efforts and all the golden promises from the Prime Minister, we are still in reverse. When the Labor Government went out of office in 1975 inflation was little more than 11 per cent and falling. Now it exceeds 11 per cent and is rising. Unemployment was then 310,000 and falling. Now it is 437,000 and rising. Interest rates on home loans were 10 per cent and falling. Now they are 12 1/2 per cent-if one can find a bank to give one a loan-and rising.

As for income tax, the family man on average award wages was paying 4 1/2 per cent of his weekly pay packet. Now he has to pay to the tax man more than 11 per cent of his income, or a massive increase of 150 per cent. Nothing illustrates more dramatically or depressingly the persistent failure of this Government than this simple fact: The dollar of six years ago is now worth only 20c.

As for housing, Australia is now in the unbelievable position where the rate of home ownership is actually falling, many families simply cannot afford even to begin buying a home, and many struggling to pay off a home are being forced to sell out on a falling market. What has been happening is that this Government, with deliberate intent, in the name of monetarist policies, has been making war on ordinary Australians. It has attacked their confidence, undermined their security and, in many cases, destroyed their self-respect. Those who have to bear the full brunt of this assault are those least equipped to bear the punishment-our pensioner Australians, our new settler Australians, our black Australians, our unskilled Australians, our young Australians and the rest of the huge disadvantaged army of at least three million forgotten Australians who now live in poverty, by the Government's own acknowledgment, in terms of its health insurance program.

But the net now goes much wider, the longer this Government stays in office. More and more in recent years, middle and working class Australians also have become victims of the indiscriminate unfairness of the Fraser Government's failed policies. Our Prime Minister, for all his supposed free enterprise attitudes, has still to learn one simple principle about basic rights in a democracy. It is the principle that a free society is one which has extended to all its citizens not only the democratic right to vote but also the fundamental right to a job, equality before the law, equality of opportunity in education, an adequate standard of living and a clear sense of security for all of its people.

Australia is a wealthy country and all our people should share fairly in that wealth. Australians in general are not mean spirited, bigoted or intolerant. They have a great and inspiring sense of a fair go. But they demand, and have a right to, a fair go from their political leaders. In recent years it has been the Australian Government-this smug, self-satisfied Government which sits opposite-which has failed repeatedly in the tests which really count, not the Australian people. It is an appalling indictment of this Government's record of neglect and failure that in one of the wealthiest countries in the world almost a full third of its people are badly housed, poorly educated, ill-clothed or undernourished.

At this time in our history we need a political revival as much as we need an economic one. We need a government determined to dedicate itself to a sense of the fair go for all our people in bringing about a sense of national renewal. To fail to recognise this, to neglect to offer hope to all those casualties of the past six and a half years of unremitting economic attrition, is not only to betray their future but also to misunderstand their patience. I am talking about taxpayers, parents, young people, small business men and women, small farmers, country townspeople and those citizens on fixed incomes, as well as the unemployed, the blacks, the poor and the migrant minorities. The Fraser Government has to cease the nonsense of behaving as though economic laws are made by nature. They are not. They are made by people, and because of this they are flawed and they can fail. The Fraser Government's record proves that. The problems to be faced will not be solved by constantly blaming other people or persistently dividing the community in the search for scapegoats. Nor will superstitious prattle about market forces remedy the defects, the mistakes and the suffering inflicted on our nation. That requires sensible, fair and creative policies, not gibberish from ideologues with fat salaries, expensive and comfortable homes and a remote indifference to ordinary Australians.

There must be a fundamental commitment by government to make the institution of government work for people-and I mean all of the people. Under this Administration, government has become an instrument of privilege and inequality.

Our single greatest task, confronted by an economy being consciously driven into recession, is to put people back into work. We accept that this is not going to be easy, but we refuse to accept that it is as difficult and as painful as this Prime Minister claims. We of the Labor Party dedicate ourselves to the restoration of full employment.

If this Government can afford its hesitant and piecemeal approach to tax avoidance, now variously estimated to be a $7,000m a year industry, then a Labor government, determined to make the rip-off speculators, the interest rate exploiters and the tax-avoiders pay their way in our society, can afford policies of genuine job creation to put our unemployed back into productive work .

The simple truth is that the great majority of Australians wants this to be done. In terms of broad economic strategy, higher taxes and government cut-backs in spending have retarded the economy at a time when it was already slowing down .
To regain growth, we need to assist consumer spending by putting money back into the hands of those many thousands of families who need to spend it simply to restore lost living standards.

This can, and should, be done by income tax cuts which favour low and middle income earners; by abandoning higher and new sales taxes; by reintroducing a universal health insurance program that replaces expensive, fixed premiums to private funds with a low health levy based on an income earner's ability to pay; and by a careful selection of housing policies geared to assist first home buyers still trying to raise housing finance, as well as to help those families caught in the interest rate spiral to meet their repayments on homes now heavily mortgaged.

The Government cannot argue that this cannot be done. Two former Ministers recently returned to the back benches-the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) and the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom)-have argued vigorously in public in support of what we have been saying for a long time.

These sorts of programs would not only generate economic activity and business confidence; they would also bring down inflation. Abandoning the Government's sales tax measures would take one per cent off inflation. The introduction of our health scheme, announced two weeks ago, would reduce inflation by another 2 per cent.

What we are now seeking is co-operation from the trade union movement in terms of restraint of wage demands in return for a government commitment to improve the social wage, a restructuring of personal income tax, a rejection of confrontationist industrial legislation, and a commitment to the principle of full employment.
No government in the present difficult economic circumstances can hope successfully to administer the Australian economy without a credible, practical prices-incomes policy.

Excessively tight money supply and mismanagement of the exchange rate have worsened our economic problems. Restrictions should be clamped on the borrowing activities of foreign investors and foreign corporations operating in the Australian money market to make more money available. The greatest single cause of the balance of trade deficit is the irresponsible revaluation of the Australian dollar by 10 per cent last year that crushed our manufacturing exports and encouraged large scale imports of cheaper manufactured goods.

That is why the case for devaluation makes so much sense. More Australian goods would be sold at home and abroad, more Australian jobs would be created, there would be more profitable Australian industry, and we would start closing the deficit.
The Government has failed in its material aims and national vision, just as it has failed in the day to day conduct of the nation's economic affairs.

Our fellow Australians are entitled to expect a full and rightful share of the bounty this country produces, and which it can expand with sensible policies. They are entitled to expect that every individual has an equal opportunity to find a productive and satisfying place in our society. They will not find that under Government policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

—I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon a parliamentary delegation from Japan led by Mr Mori, a member of the House of Representatives. On behalf of the House I extend a very warm welcome to the members of the delegation.
—Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the censure motion. I am amazed that the Government has indicated that this debate will be truncated to about three speakers. It is about time the Government realised that when it accepts a censure motion we expect the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to participate in the debate. We have a Prime Minister who travels the world and talks to people throughout the world but he is unable to debate any matter in this Parliament. That point must be of some significance to our Japanese friends who are present today. When a censure motion is debated in the Diet I am sure at least the Prime Minister would be prepared to participate. But what will happen here? There will be a short debate on the censure motion but later another matter, a statement on industrial relations, will be debated at length.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us come to the issue that this censure motion is about-the leadership of the Liberal and National Country Parties and the leadership of this nation. It is an important matter. It is about time the Government realised what is happening in the community. If Government members talked to their constituents now they would see that business is at a standstill. If they talked to people in the real estate market at present they would find that few houses are being sold , not because nobody wants to buy but because people cannot afford to buy. On first mortgages the interest rate is 20 per cent. Does the Government want to run away from that situation? What did the Government mean when, in its last policy speech, it said: 'Australia is the best place in the world to bring up a family.'? There is not enough housing for families. If honourable members want to look at tax reduction, they will see that families are about $30 a week worse off than when this Goverment came into office.

If honourable members look at the housing policies now being implemented by this Government, bearing in mind, of course, that the head of Treasury says that we are overhoused and that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) says that he substantially agrees with that situation, they will see a 30 per cent increase in the Housing Commission queues throughout Australia in the last eighteen months. The Government is giving welfare housing one third of what it gave six years ago. From the point of view of giving money to the States for housing, it is giving one-eighth of what was given six years ago. When the Government talks about what is happening in the community outside it should really be saying to the Australian people: 'We are misleading you. We will try to have a debate on some other issue such as industrial disputation.' But what about the issues and promises made on the basis that there would be full wage indexation? There was to be no objection to that policy. At present the Government has no wages policy at all in this country. It is in a complete shambles.

What do we find when we look at the tax position that has developed in this country? If honourable members look at the pay-as-you-earn proportion of general tax collected they will see that it is now 66.3 per cent whereas when the Government came into office it was 59 per cent. In other words the low and moderate income earners are paying more tax than ever. This is the Government's policy. In the Government's last Budget it proposed to increase consumer tax by a further 2 1/2 per cent on sales. At that time, luckily for the nation, that idea was rejected in the Senate. I now note that the Australian Democrats have had a change of heart and again will reject that legislation. And so they should . If they had clearly indicated that they would reject it on the last occasion perhaps we could have been having a general election now, following a double dissolution, based on the economic record of this Government. How can any government say that we have a prosperous country, that it is a great place to live and that everybody has a future when we have unemployment of 435,000, with hidden unemployment of perhaps 850,000, an inflation rate of 11.3 per cent and interest rates up to 20 per cent? Nobody in the marketplace is able to tell whether they have a future. Certainly people do not have confidence to invest in any area other than money.

What was this Government's strategy? It appears to have been to encourage foreign ownership and control. If honourable members look at some of the letters and statements made as far back as 1979 they will see that the Prime Minister wrote letters to the Premiers in this vein:

The Commonwealth Government has noted that a number of projects for electricity -intensive industries such as aluminium smelters have recently been announced and that several State governments are implementing major programs to expand electricity supply capacity to meet their requirements.

The whole thrust of the 1979 correspondence was based on resource development to assist in the aluminium area at least, and in a number of other areas. I mention the case of New South Wales in the context of Premiers conferences. When New South Wales put up a proposal for accelerated electricity generation for about $ 175m it was deferred in 1980 and then rejected. In other words, the Government has a so-called economic plan which appears in correspondence with the Premiers but is denied at Premiers conferences. Is this not the whole issue and thrust of what this Government is about? We are now virtually owned and controlled by foreign governments or foreign enterprises-foreign governments certainly from the point of view of foreign policy; foreign enterprises certainly from the point of view of economic policy. If people are to move in with their money, which they did following the previous Budget to the extent of $6 billion, they will want their pound of flesh. As Rod Carnegie said 'for every dollar of foreign investment, we pay ninefold back'. That is the position now.

We have massive competition for funds in the economic climate of this country at present. The small Australian cannot compete with the big fellow overseas or the bankers here. This Government is wedded to deregulation at all levels. One of the foremost planks of the Inquiry into the Australian Financial System espoused by the report of the Campbell committee is the deregulation of interest rates. What does this mean from the point of view of an Australian bidding even to get the chance to buy a house for his family? He is outbid at every level. Big businesses are not interested in housing. They are not interested in the average Australian. They are interested in making massive profits out of what they can get out of this country by way of resource development of the type I have mentioned.

What has happened in the world is the significant issue. The Reagan Administration has put much of its resources into armaments when nine million of its people are unemployed. With the obvious suggestion of a breakdown in community life in the United States, things are in a turmoil and nobody is really confident of what the future holds. This means that our big buyers, the foreigners, including the Japanese, are not prepared now to bid for coal or aluminium. There is a complete downturn from the point of view of the thrust of that policy. Where does this leave the strategy of the Government now? I make the point that in 1979-80 the Government was urging massive development resource projects so we could get a better life, but the projects are not taking off. The money is here to own our resources, but if there is to be some development any local capital we have will be taken. Therefore, in the domestic market the limited amount of Australian capital available is no longer available to Australians. It is picked up by the foreigner and overseas investor. That is why we are paying 20 per cent in interest rates.

What should a government be doing in this regard? Certainly, as my leader says, it should exercise some control over these matters and intervene on behalf of Australians. To what level of unemployment have we to go before the Government realises that it will be thrown out of office on the basis of not even abiding by its promises? The record clearly shows that it is now taxing Australians as they have never been taxed before. Also from the point of view of transfer of money away from the resources that should have received more, a table that can be compiled will reveal that the Government has transferred about $47 billion away from the people in both social wage and increased taxation; that is, transferred from the Australian people to the Government or to foreign ownership and control.

TALK.START.PARA: —To pay off Labor's debts.

—There is no question of debts. The debts are bigger than ever. The Government is trading at a deficit. This is why devaluation is around the corner. The Government is borrowing to try to balance the books and has been doing so for some years. On the point of a social wage, the Government should look at what it has done to the workers in this country. In 1975-76 pay-as-you- earn tax was 41.7 per cent. Today it is over 45 per cent. PAYE tax as a proportion of total income tax has risen from 59 per cent to 66 per cent. For example, a process worker would now have to cover a $37 loss in increased taxes plus a $22.50 loss in the social wage to arrive at the 1975-76 standard. In other words a process worker, because of taxation and social wage losses, is now $60 a week worse off than he was in 1975-76. Does the Government say that that is fair and reasonable? How can any government continue to avoid the issue?

SPEECH.PARA: While I am talking about avoiding the issue, let us have a look at what is happening in the tax avoidance area. It must interest you, Mr Speaker, that for the income tax years 1976 to 1979 the amount of unpaid taxes in dispute because of tax avoidance schemes is $1 billion to $1.5 billion. In other words, the Commissioner of Taxation levied taxes to that extent but cannot collect them because of the use of tax avoidance schemes. It is because the Government cannot collect its taxes-I gave as an example the amount of $1 billion to $1.5 billion- that the poor unfortunate slave on PAYE, the low income earner or the small businessman, is being soaked both directly and indirectly so that the Government can try to make up the leeway. It is about time this Government made sure that when taxes are levied they are at least paid. If the taxes are a matter of disputation a determination should be made. But to have outstanding $1.5 billion in three years is an indictment of this Government's administration. By the time the Government seeks to collect those unpaid taxes it will find that most of the companies in question will have stripped themselves of any assets or divested themselves of any means of paying the taxes. Nothing is done about such instances. The only instruction given to the Australian Taxation Office is that it should try to negotiate a settlement with the taxpayers because it is so short of staff. This is the sort of nonsense that is happening at present.

If the Government is sincere about having Australia as a worthy place for families to live in it must do something in the wages area. It should at least have a wages and incomes policy, a policy that guarantees that those who work hard for their living are able to keep more of what they earn. The Government should guarantee also that it will maintain the amount of money it is giving to health, education, transport and the like. It should guarantee the people a constant standard of living, something to which they are entitled. The Government should try to fulfil even some of its election promises whether they were made in 1975, 1977, or 1980. Honourable members will remember the famous ones: Interest rates will fall by 2 per cent; inflation will come down to about 5 per cent. Such promises are ridiculous when one looks at what is happening now .

The Government has run out of policies and ideas. That may be why it has conceded defeat in the coming by-election for the seat of Lowe. That is a surprising concession, given that the coalition has always held the seat. Of course, if it does not win it will be a clear indication of what the Australian people think of this Government. It is important that this Government have appropriate wages, prices and incomes policies to guarantee that, if there are price increases, at least the wage earner will have his standard of living maintained. The Government has deliberately berated the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission any time it has awarded a wage increase, saying that the economy could not afford it. The Government then abandoned the whole idea of wage indexation. It has been a free-for-all ever since. Is it any wonder that we have industrial turmoil! It is no good the Government touting schemes of collective bargaining on the basis that it will have some enforceable legal sanctions. Nobody will wear that when the Government does not look at what is fair.

We need a solution. The solution has to be on the basis that Australia can be a great nation and can be led properly. The solution will not be achieved through confrontation or selling out to foreign interests. It will be found by dealing with Australians on the basis of their own talents and their own resources. It will involve talking to the big businessman, the small businessman and the trade unions together about how they see their future. There is concern in the automotive industry. It knows that because of this Government's so-called back- bench policy it has no interest in maintaining the industry-none at all. Who would want to invest in that industry if the Government does not intend to persevere with it?

The whole gamut of this censure motion is an indictment of this Government. I speak here on behalf of not just the Australian Labor Party, but the whole of Australia. It is about time that this Government, half-way through its term, realised that it has a chance to do something and save something from the wreck. That will require leadership from a Prime Minister. If the present Prime Minister is unable to lead he should get out of the job and give it to somebody else. We are sick and tired of listening to what the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) would do, should do or might have done. Many of the things that he has said are worth while, but he is never here to promote them. Certainly, I do not know what happened in the past in respect of many of his decisions but we welcome the fact that he is raising his voice. This clearly indicates that, the Government, within its own ranks, has much to answer for.

—He resorted to that tired old Labor favourite at having a bash at the multinationals. When I listened to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, as I listened to the Leader of the Opposition, I wondered whether they were talking about the Australian economy or some hypothetical economy which they, for their own electoral purposes, wished existed in Australia. The most recent and objective material about the state of the Australian economy can be found in the regular Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development survey of the Australian economy. That particular survey not only gives the lie to what the Leader of the Opposition said about the quality of this Government's economic management but it confirms that the Government's present economic policies are the only way to contain inflation in this country. It records that since 1978 Australia's real growth rate on average has been twice that of the OECD area as a whole. Is this a description of an economy which in the words of the Leader of the Opposition is about 'to descend into a winter of despair and gloom'? It is about the performance of an economy--

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Treasurer is deliberately or accidentally misleading this Parliament when he quotes the OECD annual report as to the state of the economy.
—The honourable member is intruding in the debate.
—He knows full well--
—The honourable member for Newcastle will resume his seat.
—He knows full well--
—The honourable member for Newcastle will resume his seat.
—That the report is put together in consultation with the Australian Treasury.
—I warn the honourable member for Newcastle.

—Overall employment in Australia has risen strongly unlike the experience of most other OECD countries during that period. The report said that Australia is one of the few countries which in recent times has reduced the size of budget expenditure relative to gross domestic product. It said that the substantial reductions in public sector borrowing achieved through expenditure restraint had helped to balance competing demands on domestic financial markets and to dampen inflationary pressures. It states that if wage pressures are to be contained there is little alternative but to adhere to a tight demand management . In other words, the most respected international economic body in the Western world was giving a general endorsement of this Government's policies and was rejecting the alternative economic policies of the Opposition. But the hypothetical economy of the Leader of the Opposition is contradicted not only by that OECD survey but also by the most recent economic indicators that are available in Australia. These economic indicators show that gross domestic product has increased at the rate of 3.6 per cent to the six months to September 1981, that private domestic final demand has continued to grow strongly, that retail sales increased by 13.6 per cent in the year to December and that we are living in an economy in which new fixed capital expenditure shows an expected increase of 24.8 per cent-well over double the rate of inflation for the current financial year compared with the last financial year.

SPEECH.PARA: The undeniable economic fact is that in a world of very sluggish economic activity and hesitant, even negative, economic growth, the Australian economy is outperforming just about any other economy in the Western world. I know that the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition would that it would be otherwise. But this country has continued over a period of years significantly to outperform the economies of the western world. We undoubtedly live in a very difficult world economic environment. If we are to have any objective analysis of the state of the Australian economy it would be quite unrealistic and misleading-we would be living in a complete fairyland-to pretend that this country can divorce itself from what happens around the world. Does anybody seriously imagine that with an American budget deficit approaching $100 billion and with the impact of that budget deficit upon the--
Opposition members interjecting-

SPEECH.PARA: Any objective analysis of world economic circumstances would lead one to conclude that this country cannot remain unaffected by what occurs in the economies of the world, and certainly not by what occurs in the United States economy. In any debate of this kind one has to ask oneself this question: What is the real alternative to the economic policy which is being followed by the present Government? Does anybody seriously believe that a larger Budget deficit in our present economic circumstances would bring interest rates down? —Let us hear the views of the Treasurer in a future Labor government on the subject of taxation. This is what was said in 1978 by the spokesman for a party that just shouted a few minutes ago that it is a party of lower taxation:

SPEECH.PARA: If Labor does not gain office next election then by 1983, when we could next hope--
Piously-

to gain office, we would face a mammoth task in rebuilding the public sector-and maybe an equally mammoth task in convincing the electorate that it should pay a higher level of tax to enable us to do so.

They are the words of the honourable member for Gellibrand. He may have been rolled on the capital gains tax issue but I doubt whether he will be rolled on the other issue because everybody knows that to finance the expenditure programs of a future Labor government it would undoubtedly be necessary for every Australian citizen to pay a higher level of taxation. Any claim by the Labor Party that it is effectively a party of lower taxation is a false claim.

The Leader of the Opposition also raised that great area of sensitivity to the Labor Party-the area of tax avoidance. We have heard a lot from the Labor Party over recent days about tax avoidance because the Labor Party is very sensitive about the fact that when it was in office it did very little about tax avoidance . The Labor Party will have a splendid opportunity over the next few weeks to put into practice its professed belief in curbing tax avoidance when we present the legislation to take away the investment allowance which is being abused in respect of funding arrangements involving statutory authorities. The Labor Party , which has said through the words of the honourable member for Gellibrand that it is opposed to that amendment, will have an ideal opportunity both here and in another place to demonstrate to the Australian people, particularly the people of New South Wales, whether it is prepared to stand by and allow some of the largest companies in this country to take $100m to $200m from the ordinary Australian taxpayer. The present stance of the Labor Party on this issue is to oppose that amendment. It will have a splendid opportunity in the course of the next few weeks to demonstrate whether it really stands in stark opposition to tax avoidance. The economic performance of this Government over the last six years has brought to the affairs of this country a degree of stability, a degree of predictability. The economic performance of this country is looked upon with envy by a large part of the industrialised world. This Government is delivering the conditions that brought about this economy and will go on doing so.

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Prime Minister from addressing the House forthwith-

—The Leader of the House will resume his seat. I will call the right honourable gentleman on a point of order when I--

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a Joint Select Committee be appointed to inquire into the organisation , operations, functions and financial administration of the Joint House Department.

(2) That the committee consist of 10 members, 3 members of the House of Representatives nominated by either the Prime Minister, the Leader of the House or the Government Whip, 2 members of the House of Representatives nominated by either the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition or the Opposition Whip, 2 senators nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 2 senators nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 1 senator nominated by any minority group or groups or independent senator or independent senators.
(3) That every nomination of a member of the committee be forthwith notified in writing to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
(4) That the members of the committee hold office as a joint committee until the House of Representatives is dissolved or expires by effluxion of time.

(5) That the committee elect as chairman of the committee one of the members nominated by either the Prime Minister, the Leader of the House or the Government Whip, or by the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

(6) That the committee elect a deputy chairman who shall perform the duties of the chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee, and at any time when the chairman and deputy chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee, the members present shall elect another member to perform the duties of the chairman at that meeting.
(7) That the committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of 3 or more of its members and refer to any such sub-committee any matter which the committee is empowered to examine.

(8) That the committee appoint the chairman of each sub-committee and at any time when the chairman of a sub-committee is not present at a meeting of the sub -committee, the members of the sub-committee present shall elect another member of that sub-committee to perform the duties of the chairman at that meeting.
(9) That a majority of the members of a sub-committee constitute a quorum of that sub-committee.
(10) That members of the committee who are not members of a sub-committee may take part in the public proceedings of that sub-committee but shall not vote or move any motion or constitute a quorum.
(11) That the committee or any sub-committee have power to send for persons, papers and records.
(12) That the committee have power to move from place to place.
(13) That any sub-committee have power to move from place to place, adjourn from time to time and to sit during any adjournment.
(14) That the committee or any sub-committee have power to authorise publication of any evidence given before it and any document presented to it.
(15) That the committee be provided with necessary staff, facilities and resources.
(16) That the Committee have leave to report from time to time and that any member of the committee have power to add a protest or dissent to any report.
(17) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders.
(18) That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution and requesting that it concur and take action accordingly.
