SPEECH.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Wage determination and industrial relations are of the most profound importance to the welfare of all Australians and for the development of the Australian economy . Sound policies in these two connected areas are obviously critical to Australia's growth and prosperity as a nation. It is appropriate therefore that I place clearly before the Parliament the Government's policy regarding wage determination, industrial disputation and industrial relations legislation. I do so against a background of widespread community concern about the marked increase in industrial disputation which has taken place in recent times, against a background of very substantial increases in wages which have been received by much of the work force since the abandonment of wage indexation, and against a background of questioning of the traditional system, and of a desire by the community for action to ensure that a better way is found to resolve industrial matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's wages policy has been firmly established since the abandonment of wage indexation last July. It gives clear expression to the Government's basic philosophy and objectives and it is the product of a number of factors. The Commonwealth does not have direct power over wages. The Commonwealth cannot legislate for any particular wage level. As a result, the Commonwealth's role in wages determination is necessarily more indirect that with policy areas for which it has direct constitutional resonsibility. At the same time, however, the Government has a major responsibility to make sure that the growth in wages does not frustrate the achievement of overall economic objectives. It remains the Government's firm view that the sustained control and reduction of inflation is basic to the achievements of substantial economic growth and the improved living standards all Australians seek. Reasonable wage levels and competitive labour costs are obviously a key element in pursuing these economic and social objectives. The Government's wages policy needs to be seen in that context and in the light of the reasons why wage indexation had to be abandoned.

From its inception, the wage indexation could operate effectively only as long as the consensus between the parties necessary for its survival remained intact. This required the union movement to remain within the centralised wage fixing system and not to seek additional wage increases outside the system. Unless that condition was met, indexation could not survive. The work value round of 1979 was a clear indication that the system was beginning to falter. The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission warned of the threats posed by substantial wage increases outside the central system and the level of industrial disputation associated with the shorter hours campaign. But these warnings were not heeded. Disputation increased and pressures for wage increases outside as well as inside the indexation system continued to mount. The result was the abandonment of indexation in July 1981 and, as the Commission made clear at the time, the long- standing procedures whereby individual claims by unions would be heard by the Commission remained available.

The Commission also indicated that any application for adjustment on economic grounds would not be heard before February 1982. The Commonwealth Government moved quickly to consult national employers and unions as well as State governments to determine an appropriate course in the new circumstances. Following the Premiers Conference all governments called on unions to use the established system of wage determination involving Commonwealth and State tribunals. Moreover, they stressed that all governments and all parties involved had a responsibility to make the system work and that it would work if it were allowed to and if it were supported by all parties. Governments foresaw that wage claims would come before the Commission as they were pursued on an industry basis. That view was also endorsed by the Confederation of Australian Industry.

The main elements of the Commonwealth's wages policy in the post-indexation period have been as follows: Maintenance of firmly anti-inflationary economic policies to establish an appropriate economic environment for wage restraint; reliance upon established arbitral tribunals and their processes; support for the more decentralised approach to wage settlements on an industry by industry basis; to emphasise that it is the responsibility of unions and employers to use the existing system in an orderly manner with a minimum of industrial disputation, and to be willing to give maximum commitment to agreements reached and to bring them before industrial tribunals for scrutiny in the public interest; a less direct role for the Commonwealth Government in interventions in individual cases reserving the Government's advocacy for national wage cases and major industry cases; and action in its own sphere of employment to ensure that wages and conditions do not lead the market. Consistent with the overall need for wage moderation, the Commonwealth accepts that its employees' wages and conditions should be maintained in a reasonably competitive position.

In past months significant wage increases have been gained by a substantial proportion of the work force in both private and public sectors as the industry by industry approach has worked its way through industry bargaining and ratification by the Commission. On top of this there will be a national wage case later this month. The Government's response to this has to be viewed against Australia's present economic situation and prospects.
What Lies Ahead

The Government's policies over recent years have achieved considerable success in bringing about economic recovery. Let me remind the House that over the last two years living standards have risen and thousands of new jobs have been created-over a quarter of a million in the two years to December 1981. The facts are important to state at a time when the union movement and the Opposition would have the community believe the wage earner has suffered a loss of real value in earnings. This is patently not true. Seasonally adjusted average weekly earnings in September 1979 were $239.10 per week. By September 1981 they were $ 301.10 per week. In the same period the consumer price index increased by about 20 per cent. Thus in real terms average weekly earnings rose by about four and three-quarter per cent over the period. Putting it another way the annual income of a person on average weekly earnings increased by over $700 in real terms.

Between fiscal years 1979-80 and 1980-81 real household disposable income rose by 3.42 per cent. That is, the real disposable income of Australian families- their after tax income-increased by nearly $3 billion between fiscal years 1979- 80 and 1980-81. Movements in average weekly earnings in 1981-82 are expected to be broadly in line with the budget forecast of 13.5 per cent. The full impact of recent wage and shorter hours settlements will not, however, be felt until the 1982-83 financial year and may well be greater than for this financial year. The Government has emphasised to employers and unions alike the serious implications of excessive wage increases and industrial disruption for inflation, the competitive position of Australian industry and levels of unemployment.

All Australians should share the benefits of economic growth and the rising standard of living it brings, but there must be a recognition that there are limits to the growth of wages possible in any one year. Wage justice is compatible with moderation in wage settlements. Claims for wage increases have to be balanced against other calls on the resources of the community such as those for welfare beneficiaries and the need for investment funds by businesses. This view was supported by all governments at the August Premiers Conference. It is a view the Government has consistently expressed to the Australian Council of Trade Unions in economic discussions with its President, Mr Dolan, and senior union officials. It is a point of view which should be accepted and acted upon. The Government is firm in its commitment to ensure its broad economic policies work to encourage a climate of wage restraint and to dampen inflationary expectations. Let there be no misunderstanding; the money supply will not be expanded so as to accommodate excessive wage increases. Economic policies will continue to be implemented to achieve this objective.

Conditions in overseas economies make restraint in Australia all the more important for while our economy has been growing, and our national output and employment have been rising, our major trading partners have been experiencing continued recession, and growing unemployment; and, as a consequence, inflationary pressures in those countries have been falling. There is now a real prospect of inflation rates in Europe and North America dropping below Australia 's. This is a prospect which is compounded by excessive wage claims. Our international competitiveness, the profitability of Australian businesses and the confidence needed to maintain business investment are under threat. Job prospects, both for those already with jobs and for those looking for them, are correspondingly being reduced. Obviously the Government and the community want employers, unions and arbitral tribunals to act responsibly so that such an outcome is avoided. As the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development notes in its latest survey of Australia:

It is to be hoped that progress can be made in developing a better understanding between those who make and those who grant wage claims of the effects of their action, taking into account the relationships between inflation , real wage costs and employment.

The Government has been underlining to both employers and unions the broad national consequences of excessive wage increases for investment, economic activity and employment prospects for Australians. It is time then for the ACTU and its affiliate unions to take heed of the consequences of unrestrained wage demands and claims for shorter hours. Employers also have a very real responsibility to keep their work force fully informed of the impact excessive labour cost increases will have in investment, output and employment in their industry or enterprise. Against this background the forthcoming national wage case is of critical importance.

The ACTU is seeking substantial wage increases-possibly of the order of a further $25-for those wage and salary earners whose increases since the abandonment of indexation have been for lesser amounts. These increases would apply to a majority of the work force. On top of this the ACTU is seeking the introduction of full automatic quarterly cost of living adjustments commencing with the 4.2 per cent increase in the CPI for the December quarter. There is no way that the Australian economy can stand wage increases of this magnitude.

The Commonwealth's submission to the forthcoming national wage case will express our primary concern that existing wage pressures are not exacerbated by any national wage decision. The abandonment of indexation makes no less important the requirements of section 39 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission shall take into consideration the public interest and for that purpose shall have regard to the state of the national economy and the likely effects of any awards with special reference to the level of employment and inflation.

With substantial industry wage settlements having moved through most of the work force and significant shorter hours agreement made in key segments of the economy, there is no room for any general wage increases to be granted in the national wage case and there should be no return to indexation. Such claims on top of wage increases obtained and being sought through industry-by-industry bargaining run the grave risk of doubling up on union wage demands, putting the health of the economy in jeopardy and causing the opposite of what the ACTU professes it wants to achieve for the work force-lowering instead of lifting their standard of living through accelerating inflation and reduced employment opportunities.

In the transport workers decision in July last the Commission clearly indicated that the unions faced a choice as to how wage increases should be obtained: either by way of general economic cases-that is national wage cases-or by way of increases at the industry and award level. They have chosen the latter course. The unions cannot have it both ways.

The Commonwealth will submit most strongly that the industry-by-industry approach best meets the needs of the Australian economy. This approach best meets the needs of all, by offering a real chance of containing the rate of inflation while leaving open to all sectors of the work force the way to pursue their claims by negotiation or, if necessary, by arbitration where matters will be dealt with on their merits. The weaker unions will not be left out in the cold by this approach. It is wrong for the Opposition or the ACTU to say that they will be for the State and Federal tribunals are always there for them to pursue their claims. The union movement itself has a heavy responsibility for the orderly processing of claims and ensuring that the industrially strong do not gain unfair or unreasonable advantage.

Apart from the national wage case, the Government will reserve its interventions before arbitral tribunals to major industry cases where agreements setting new standards for wages or other conditions of employment and having significant flow-on consequences are involved. This course was followed in the case of the metal trades agreement where the Commonwealth recognised the special features of that agreement-its 12 months 'no extra claims' clause and the willingness of the parties 'to run the gauntlet of the public interest'. Our submissions emphasised to the Commission the need to avoid flow-on of the agreement to other industries whose circumstances were fundamentally different.

In some other industries settlements which contain 'no extra claims' clauses have also come forward for scrutiny by industrial tribunals. This development offers the prospect of a reduction in industrial disputation during 1982 provided employers and unions accept their responsibilities to ensure that such agreements are honoured. It is some distance from a true 'no strike' clause but I hope employers will in future bargaining put themselves in a position to push for such a clause. It is the ultimate test of the bona fides of the union movement. If the industry-by-industry approach is to be properly used the distinctive features of particular industries and the circumstances and terms of specific agreements reached by bargain and compromise must be recognised by employers, unions and tribunals alike. Each claim has to be weighed and evaluated by the appropriate arbitral tribunal having regard to the particular circumstances and the public interest.

The Government's decision to intervene to oppose ratification of the recent printing trades agreement on wages and hours is based on its concern for a settlement which is out of step with bargaining in other major industries. The agreement, by providing for a 35-hour week from December 1982, could lead to pressures for similar conditions in other industries when the economic situation requires the exercise of maximum restraint. The agreement to implement its terms regardless of whether or not it is ratified by the Commission brings into question the willingness of the parties to accept the obligation of justifying their agreement in the public interest before the Commission in order to render it legally binding on all parties to it.
Industrial Framework

It is not surprising against a background of a high level of industrial disruption that the institutional framework for industrial relations in Australia has been called into question. While arbitral tribunals have been ready to deal with wage claims, and have done so in a number of significant instances, the Government deplores the marked increase in the level of industrial disputation that occurred in the second part of last year. Twice as many working days were lost through strikes in the September 1981 quarter as in the corresponding period in 1980. All Australians have needlessly suffered as a result.

Of special concern were demarcation disputes and those in major industries caused by relatively small numbers of key employees. Demarcation disputes backed by unions placing bans on certain kinds of work or certain employers have become a blot on the industrial scene. The high point of such disruption has been the activity of the Builders Labourers Federation in Victoria.

The ACTU has adopted rules for self-regulation of inter-union rivalry but the glaring omission from its code is any requirement that industrial disruption cease whilst the dispute is sorted out. Unions cannot shrug off the consequences of their actions upon industry and the community. The right given under the law to organise collectively is not a licence to ravage the trade and commerce of the nation with impunity. As a result of the concern of all governments about recent trends in wage movements and industrial disputation, especially those associated with demarcation issues, it has been agreed that these matters will be a major focus for discussion at the Premiers' Conference to be held on Friday next.

Over the past few months I have engaged in extensive discussions with the major employer and trade union organisations in most States. In addition, representatives of many companies, both large and small, have discussed with me or written to me expressing their concern about such factors as the structure of Australian unions and their heavy dependence on craft unions rather than industry or even enterprise unions; the breakdown of any sense of commitment to bargains made and the spirit and intent of the conciliation and arbitration processes; the constant resort to the indiscriminate use of union power often before the parties have even reached the bargaining table, as an act of first rather than last resort; and the Federal-State division of industrial relations powers.

The development of a responsible approach by management and unions to industry wage bargaining is tied up with the shape of union structures and the rights and obligations placed by the law on each of the parties. It has become clear to me that many Australians, not only employers, are concerned at the lack of responsibility demonstrated by the trade union movement in its use of industrial action and the relative weakness of employers in the face of such action. It is now more than a decade since the Clarrie O'Shea case and the major industrial battle over absorption of the metal trades decision of 1967, during which time the union movement has declared itself against any legal restraints on industrial action and for the untramelled right to strike and impose bans in almost any situation. I believe the Australian community is saying that enough is enough, that no section of the community can be above the law.

Improving the institutional framework of industrial relations is a priority task. It is being approached in a number of ways. The implications of divided jurisdiction and ways of achieving better co-operation and consistency between Federal and State jurisdictions have been under review by Commonwealth and State Labour Ministers and will be canvassed at the forthcoming Premiers Conference.

During this session I intend to introduce a number of legislative intiatives which I discussed with the National Labour Consultative Council on 4 February and which will be the subject of further discussion at a special meeting of that Council to be held in March. The Government has been accused of seeking confrontation with the union movement because of these legislative proposals. Far from being confrontationist, the three legislative proposals are a responsible and reasonable response, both immediate and longer term, to meet a level of industrial disruption which all Australians recognise as totally unsatisfactory. The Government has a clear obligation to develop legislation which will protect the interests of Australians and provide a sound and balanced legal framework within which employers and employees can conduct industrial relations.

The Government is very much aware of the problems associated with union structures which arise in part as a result of the large number of unions that operate in individual industries and range over particular enterprises. Much of the recent discussion about amalgamation of unions has failed to distinguish between the objective of allowing the creation of industry unions and amalgamations which create big conglomerate unions, such as the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union, whose membership straddles a number of industries. Encouragement of the development of unions along those lines would not, in the Government's view, assist in reducing the level of industrial disputes to any marked degree.

The Government's long-standing objective, clearly expressed in its industrial relations platform, is the encouragement of industry-based unions. It is also the objective of the Labor Party and the ACTU. Clearly that objective will take considerable time to achieve. The legislation I intend to introduce this session will facilitate the development of industry-based unions and allow enterprise unions to be formed. The door needs to be opened to movement from within the work force so that the present rigidities and monopolies are loosened and structures created which are more suited to a modern economy and representative negotiations in industrial relations and dispute settlement.

The multiplicity of the unions involved in individual industries also means that key workers who do not belong to the major union with coverage of a particular industry can create substantial industrial disruption and effectively deny useful employment opportunities to their fellow employees. Recent disputes in the waterfront and coal industries are prime examples of the major costs that such action causes. Increasingly rolling strikes and bans from plant to plant or industrial action by small key groups of workers have been used to put intense economic pressure on a single employer, a whole industry, or the community at large. In those circumstances quite often the employer has no work for the other employees. The employer's capacity to resist a strike is reduced to nothing because his wages bill goes on running. He needs protection in that situation and the Government intends to provide it. Consequently I will be introducing legislation later this session to provide employers with the automatic right to stand-downs. Employees who are unable to be usefully employed because of the effects of industrial action by other employees of the same employer or industrial action by employees of other employers may be stood down.

It needs to be clearly understood that the stand-down clauses will operate only if there is industrial action. If unions accept the normal processes of negotiation and conciliation and arbitration instead of taking industrial action , stand-downs will not be required. The Commonwealth will be drawing on the Commonwealth's constitutional power over interstate and overseas trade and commerce and over corporations as well as its industrial powers to support this legislation. The Government firmly believes in the right of the individual to choose to join or not to join a union. We do not believe in giving unions the capacity to exercise monopoly power over the working lives of people.

This Government has broadened legislation to allow individual employees to not become members of unions where they had a conscientious objection to doing so. Freedom of association on which unionism is based should not be distorted by denying the fundamental freedom of the individual. We intend to go further and to legislate to incorporate the principle of voluntary unionism in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and to provide safeguards against intimidation or victimisation for those who exercise their freedom of choice in this matter. Moreover, I will introduce legislation withdrawing from the Arbitration Commission jurisdiction to grant union preference. This will greatly assist in reducing the incidence of the closed shop, which is a total negation of voluntary unionism.

These legislative initiatives are but the start of our program of reform. The Government, with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Confederation of Australian Industry, is currently examining the report submitted by Mr Richard Searby, Q.C., and former Deputy President Taylor on the simplification and streamlining of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. I expect that legislative action will be taken on the basis of that report later this year to bring about a substantial restructuring and simplification of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. This should be of major benefit to all those associated with industrial relations in Australia. Ultimately reform of industrial relations in Australia needs to go further than simplifying and restructuring what we now have. I will be pursuing for the Government the work already begun against the bench-mark of what I regard as two basic principles: Equality of bargaining power and the equality of legal responsibility of employers and unions.

The legislative initiatives I have outlined are essential if better industrial structures and industrial relations are to be achieved. Legislation of course sets the framework and establishes the rights, duties and obligations of the parties to industrial relations. In this sense the law can change or mould the conduct of people but fundamentally, of course, industrial relations is about relationships between people-employees and management. Unions, employers and governments have a common interest in avoiding industrial disputes and providing for a fair and equitable wage determination system. The achievement of those objectives will facilitate the development of the Australian economy which is essential if improvements in our standard of living are to be achieved. The national interest is clearly being damaged by present rates of increase in labour costs so often pursued by severe industrial disruption. Union leadership, business management and individual wage and salary earners, need to recognise this and work to improve industrial relations and to contain the inflation in labour costs. Progress towards this unity of interest and purpose will be to the common and personal good of all Australians. I present the following paper:
Wage Determination and Industrial Relations-Ministerial Statement, 16 February 1982.
Motion (by Mr Sinclair) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the honourable member for Wills speaking for a period not exceeding 32 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —What this House has just witnessed is nothing less than a tragedy. So that there can be no misrepresentation of the kind in which the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) and this Government excel, let me at the outset make abundantly clear the position of the Opposition in regard to this question of industrial relations. We of the Opposition believe that this question of industrial relations is of fundamental importance in this country. We also believe-perhaps this view is not shared by honourable members who sit on the other side of the House-that if one were to analyse sensibly, intelligently and honestly the condition of industrial relations in this country, then one would have to recognise that blame does not soley rest in one quarter. So there will be no doubt about this let me say at the outset-I suppose I can speak on this subject with more authority than anyone else in this House-that I acknowledge that at times the trade union movement or some parts of it have been at fault. They make mistakes and they make mistakes for a variety of reasons. But what we have witnessed today in this ministerial statement by the Minister who speaks on behalf of this Government is a parade of prejudices marked by a degree of myopia which is unbelievable and in which he has purported to have discharged his responsibility of analysis in regard to industrial relations by simply cataloguing charges against the trade union movement.

SPEECH.PARA: I go to perhaps a very strange scource to immediately try to get these issues into perspective. I will quote the words of the recent Liberal Premier of Western Australia, a fellow Western Australian, the Minister who has just spoken in this House. I will quote from the transcript of the confidential proceedings of the Premiers Conference held in Canberra on 13 August. It is in the statements made in those proceedings by Sir Charles Court that we can start to get an appropriate context in which we can undertake this honest, intelligent and impartial analysis of industrial relations and wage fixation in this country . Let me first of all go to page 33 of the transcript of the confidential proceedings of that Premiers Conference, which was referred to by the Minister in his speech today. Sir Charles Court refers to the fact that there have been some big increases within the trade union movement. He did not get unduly disturbed about it. But what did he go on to say? He went on to say:
. . . but in private enterprise we need to consider the literally indecent increases in executive salaries.

Sir Charles Court said that we should take account of the literally indecent increases in salaries of executives. Do we hear a word about that from the Minister for Industrial Relations who is supposed to be giving a balanced and dispassionate analysis of industrial relations? Of course we do not hear a word about it. What did Sir Charles Court go on to say? He made some reference to the fact that some people in the trade union movement have had big increases. If honourable members want one single sentence which underlies the motion that was moved by the Opposition today, and which is the heart of the issue, it is in this single sentence by Sir Charles Court which was said here in Canberra in the privacy of the Premiers Conference. He said:
A great mass of people today are not getting a fair go.

Sir Charles Court, the recently retired Liberal Premier of Western Australia, is saying that a great mass of people today are not getting a fair go. What did this man say about this question of how to approach industrial relations? We have had paraded in this chamber by the Minister in the latter part of his speech the proposition that the Government will bring in a number of new pieces of legislation. This portrays again its belief that the way to tackle industrial relations is to bring in tough pieces of law. What was said by Sir Charles Court on this question of whether one can properly approach this question of industrial relations by bringing in tough new laws? Let me again quote from the confidential minutes of the Premiers Conference and what Sir Charles Court had to say on this approach. He can speak with some authority on the subject from the way he has acted in the past. On page 22 he is reported to have said:

After looking at the matter very closely, I am convinced that there is no set of rules which we can devise which will improve the situation if we cannot change the attitudes of people involved in the system. You can lay down the most diabolical rules, the most diabolical laws and attempt to implement them; but if you do not have a spirit of co-operation in the matter nothing will work.
He went back to the same point very briefly. On page 24 Sir Charles Court said:
I come back to where I started: No system, no matter how clever the law or how diabolical it might be, will achieve a result if there is not goodwill on the part of everybody.

We could not have it any clearer. He says that it does not matter how clever one is in bringing down another piece of legislation or how diabolical one is; one has to have goodwill. Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask: Is one likely to generate goodwill on the clear understanding of the complexity and the importance of the issues involved if the Minister comes into the House and not only takes this myopic view but also in fact, puts dishonest statistics and arguments before the House? We know, as we have had this sort of problem before-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The statistics which I quoted to the House are official statistics published by the Australian Government Statistician.
—Let us test it. I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and the members of the House to turn to page 15 of the Ministerial Statement. The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Twice as many working days--
These are the words that he uttered in the House a few minutes ago.
. . . were lost through strikes in the September 1981 quarter as in the corresponding period in 1980.
That is a pretty clear statement. Let me repeat it:
Twice as many working days were lost through strikes in the September 1981 quarter as in the corresponding period in 1980.

I have read this statement. It was provided to me at only 1.30 today. I finished reading it in the House. I have asked for the statistics. I wanted as much checked as possible. What are the facts? The facts are in these terms: In the September quarter 1980, 853,300 working days were lost due to industrial disputes. In the September quarter 1981, 1,147,700 working days were lost. One does not have to be an intellectual genius to know that that is not double.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is still too many.

—What is the way out? The honourable member for Bendigo is interjecting this time. We know that to honourable members opposite the truth does not matter . The Minister comes into the House and says that the figure has doubled. What will be the weak excuse when I show that the figure has not doubled and that it is 34 per cent higher? The Government will say: 'Oh well, it is near enough. It is too many'. That is the standard of integrity of this Government. The Minister attempts to excuse a deliberate dishonesty in this matter by saying: 'Oh well, it is too many. It is too much. It is near enough'. That is the standard of honesty and integrity of this Government. It is the characteristic of the Minister, and it is characteristic of the way in which this approach is adopted by the Minister and the Government. It is their approach to say: 'Let us play politics with industrial relations. Do not let us attempt to look at the facts. Does it not sound much better when we say that there is a doubling of industrial disputes? It does not matter that it is totally wrong; let us just use that figure'. This gives honourable members an indication of how much we can rely on the Government in this matter and on the Minister.
—You have lost your place.

—I have not lost my place. I tell the honourable member that I will keep up with him and ahead of him any time he likes. If he has got the guts he can have a go afterwards on the facts instead of on his prejudices. Let us come to the facts. We had a proposition put to this House that, in fact, the trade unions were behaving in an abominable fashion. In fact, certain of them were named. I want to take up directly this question of the naming of one of the unions. One of the unions that was named in this respect was the Builders Labourers Federation.
—Do you support them?

—Honourable members will notice that the honourable member for Bendigo interjects again with the phrase: 'Do you support them'? Are they not brilliant? The reserves of the honourable member's intellectual depth are incredible. If one throws the bait, honourable members opposite will come in every time. Good on you, Bendigo! The honourable member will not be here after 1983. Let me make the position clear in regard to the Builders Labourers Federation.
—Do you support them?

—No, I do not support everything the Builders Labourers Federation does . I certainly do not support everything some of its leaders do. If honourable members want any proof of the occasional relationship between the Builders Labourers Federation and me, I invite them to undertake a careful study of some of its publications. Honourable members will find that one of their favourite hate objects over the years has been none other than me. The fact that I have had these things said about me and that they have expressed contempt for me does not deny the fact that if one were to be honourable and decent in discussing these matters there ought to be certain fundamental rules which apply to both sides. What are they? This Government expressed its concern with the actions of the Builders Labourers Federation to such an extent that it initiated two judicial inquiries to investigate what was happening. We know what they were. One inquiry was the deregistration proceedings and the other, in conjunction with the Victorian Government, was a royal commission. Fair enough; we can have arguments as to whether those were sensible things to do, but the Government made its decision to undertake these judicial processes-two of them, not one. Okay, it did it. What happened while those two processes were still going on before any report had been brought down by them? This desperate Government, knowing that it cannot in any honourable way stand up to public debate or analysis on its economic record, has decided that it is going to make an issue of industrial relations, that it is going to try to whip up in the community an attitude of fear, loathing and apprehension about the trade union movements.

SPEECH.PARA: What was the first tactic adopted by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser)? Just strangely, with his crowded program, he decided he had to go down to Loy Yang to see how the construction of the power station was going there. Of course , in the program of a busy Prime Minister, one would expect that it would be of top priority for him to go down and see how the construction was going at Loy Yang. What did he do there? He deliber- ately went out to see the workers on the job. We know it is a characteristic of the Prime Minister that he is always dying to get out and meet the ordinary working people of this country. On this occasion he particularly wanted to go and see the workers at Loy Yang. What happened when he, in pursuit of this thirst he has to meet with the ordinary people, went to see the workers at Loy Yang? When met by them and when one of them asked 'What are you going to do about the deregistration proceedings', what did he say? He said: 'You can wave goodbye to Mr Gallagher'. Where in this issue are the basic principles of decency and honesty, of a commitment to the concepts of law and order, when the man who has set up two judicial inquiries which are investigating the very question of the tenure of a trade union official, of the likelihood of his staying in office and his capacity to do so, the man who has set himself up as prosecutor and has got the inquiries going, before any report has been brought down and while both inquiries are still proceeding, brings down a judgment before those inquiries have reported? Those are the sorts of standards and the sort of integrity that we have on the part of this Government on the issue of industrial relations. It states: 'Do anything you possibly can to take away the opportunity of proper analysis of your economic performance, of your economic management; get rid of all that and just make sure you try to whip up hysteria on this issue of industrial relations. It doesn't matter that you break every canon of decency about how judicial inquiries should proceed'. It is a wonder that the royal commissioner involved and others concerned did not express their contempt for the contempt of them that had been expressed. How can any honourable member sitting on the opposite side of the chamber, particularly those with legal training, possibly justifying a situation in which they and their Prime Minister have set up their judicial processes to inquire into what is happening in regard to that union and its officials and, while the inquiry is still going on, before any report has been made, the Prime Minister, for his devious political purposes, has gone down there and announced to the people involved what the outcome of those processes will be? Their Government and their Prime Minister and any of them who support and sustain that sort of approach are not deserving of one skerrick of support from any reasonable person in this community.

But let us get away from that point of the double standards of honourable members opposite. They are talking about law and order. They request the trade union movement to obey the judicial processes. How can they possibly live with themselves when they say what they have said to the trade unions, when they make the demands they have made of the trade unions? The Minister in his speech talked about the trade unions not obeying the law, not abiding by the umpire's decision. How can they live with themselves when they do that sort of thing through the person of their Prime Minister? Of course, what we appreciate is that unfortunately the sort of thing that the Prime Minister has done is a reflection of the basic double standards of this Government and that is at the very centre and core of the problem of industrial relations in this country.

Mr Deputy Speaker, if you want a recent starting point which determines the deterioration of industrial relations in Australia I will give you the date: It occurred here in this chamber on 30 April 1981. It was on that occasion that the Prime Minister, speaking for this Government, gave the razor gang speech which outlined the philosophy of this Government. I will do the Prime Minister credit in saying the he was pretty straightforward on that occasion in outlining that philosophy. It was a philosophy which stated that the intrusion of government into industry, into regulation, was a bad thing. At page 12 of the document which was distributed subsequently, in referring to the Prices Justification Tribunal, the following was stated:
This body has outlived its usefulness as a regulatory mechanism and is placing an undue burden on industry. . . .

What a marvellous definition of 'industry' the Prime Minister and this Government have, if I may say so! 'Industry', as defined by the Prime Minister, means not everyone who works in industry, those who employ and those who are employed; 'industry', as defined by the Prime Minister, means simply those who employ. The Prime Minister talked about the strain being imposed on industry, so defined, by interventionary mechanisms such as the Prices Justification Tribunal ; so it was abolished.

I simply want to say, Mr Deputy Speaker, through you to the Government and to the people of Australia, that I believe an intellectual theoretical argument, if you like, can be created which states that it is best not to have any intervention in industry by government; let the free play of market forces run and let the prices of products that are produced be determined by those market forces; let the allocation of investment resources be determined by the free play of market forces. I believe that such a theoretical argument can be constructed. I do not agree with it; it does not persuade me. But I think that at least such an argument can be constructed. What cannot be done is to construct an argument which states, in respect of those who employ, businesses: 'We will apply a concept of non-intervention. We will abolish the Prices Justification Tribunal. You use your strength in the market to get your share of investment resources to set the prices that you think are appropriate'. The Government cannot say that on the one hand and, on the other hand, come in here and say, in respect of the other part of industry, which it is loth to recognise , that is, those who are employed: 'We will bring in more and more legislation, more and more intervention, to inhibit and regulate you in the way you operate'. The Government cannot have it both ways. If the principle of non-intervention in respect of those who employ is valid and market forces should be allowed to have their run, okay, but it has to be across the board. Now the Government, in its funny sort of way, has very vaguely started to comprehend the truth of what I am saying on this.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have to look at the fallacy of your argument.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I did not interrupt the Minister when he spoke. If he cannot be honest in his statements, at least let him be decent in his behaviour.
—You have a fallacy in your propositions. Why don't you concede it?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, are you going to apply the same rules of behaviour to every member of this House? I did not intervene once when the Minister was speaking.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, the point I make is this: If the Government is going to face up to this situation honestly, it has to accept that it does not make sense to allow the strong to exercise their power to get more for themselves, be it capital placed in a strategic monopolistic or oligopolistic position. It does not make sense for them to be able to use their power in the markets to advance their position beyond what is reasonable, any more than it is reasonable to allow strategically placed trade unions or labour the same right. If the strong in the community are allowed to exercise their power in that way the result will be very simple. Great reserves of intellectual reasoning power are not needed to know what the answer is.
—To help the other side.

—The honourable member for Swan said that, not me. The point is this: The strong will inevitably get stronger. The strong people on the side of capital will be placed in a position of having a greater command over the scarce resources of this country in terms of investment. In respect of those who are employed, those who are strategically placed by power and who may have no sense of responsibility, who may be mavericks, will have the capacity to get stronger. In the process of the strong on the side of capital getting stronger and the strong on the side of labour getting stronger, we can equally easily identify those who will suffer. They are these: The people in the work force who either are weakly organised or are not organised at all; the farmers; the small business sector of the community; and those on fixed incomes, be they pensioners or anyone else. That is the inevitable result of the application of the philosophy of this Government. I am sure that the exercising of power is an exhilarating thing for those who have the power to undertake it, but it is not so pleasant for the residuals who suffer when that power is exercised. The Labor Party thinks that it is appropriate that neither strong capital nor strong labour should have an unmitigated right to exercise that power. If they believe that they have legitimate claims upon the scarce resources of the community, there should be an apparatus in place which requires them to justify those claims. That is the policy of my party and I believe it is a policy which will be recognised by the community and will recommend itself to the community.

SPEECH.PARA: I said at the beginning of this speech that we are not here to endorse every action that is taken by every trade union in every circumstance. We are here honestly to try to recognise what is the best way of improving the industrial relations situation in this country so that the community as a whole will have the opportunity to best and most equitably utilise its resources. Without understanding the first and fundamental point, we will not begin with any series of punitive band-aids to get within cooee of an answer. That first and fundamental point is that the same principles should apply to both sides in terms of the exercise of power and the strong on both sides, not just one side, should be required to justify their claims.

In the seven or eight minutes that remain I want to address myself particularly , and necessarily briefly, to some of the other points in the Minister's statement. First of all I remind the House that the Minister created the framework of his speech by lamenting what happened to index- ation. His speech indicated that the culprits in respect of indexation are the trade unions; they did not do the right thing, they looked outside the guidelines. I remind the House of the facts, as indeed the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in some of its judgments has reminded the community of the facts. The Commission has not blamed just the trade union movement. When it has thought the trade union movement has been at fault it has said so in its judgments but it has attached at least as much blame-I would suggest more-to the Commonwealth Government for the attitude it has adopted in the indexation cases. I shall give the House the facts-

TALK.START.PARA: —Selectively.

—They are not selected facts. I do not operate like the honourable member. I know the facts are unpalatable because they feed on prejudice. Between February 1976 and January 1981 the Commonwealth Government made 10 submissions for no increase in the national wage, two for rises equivalent to only 30 per cent index- ation and three for rises equivalent to between 50 per cent and 60 per cent of the consumer price index movement. No submission in the whole of that period, covering 15 cases, ever supported full indexation, which was the promise on which the Government went to the people at the end of 1975. Finally on that point, submissions for no increase were made at nine of the last 10 indexation hearings to 1981. Who was the culprit in the fall of indexation? What chance did it have when a major intervening party-the Commonwealth Government- went in on nine out of the last 10 occasions and argued for no increase at all. Index- ation failed because the Government broke its pledges and promises. The history of this is contained in the Commission's judgments. It said quite clearly that the structure of indexation depended not only on its decisions but also on tax indexation being in place and on a situation whereby the Commonwealth played its role in respect of controlling inflation. In judgment after judgment it made reference to the fact that the Commonwealth Government had let the side down; it had abandoned tax indexation and had deliberately made decisions which, far from reducing inflation, had in fact increased inflation. We have seen this in the figures for the December quarter as a significant part of the 4.2 per cent increase was the result of deliberate Government decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: Having disposed of that partial attempt by the Minister to explain what has happened to indexation, I will spend the last three or four minutes on dealing with the specific proposals of legislative intervention which were adumbrated by the Minister this afternoon. What are the changes in the law about which the Minister is talking? The one I must deal with first is the matter of union structure. After listening to what the Minister said we must believe we are in an Alice in Wonderland situation. The Minister said: 'We have had our policy in respect of industrial unions for a long time and we are going to pass laws to give effect to it'. What will the laws be? On the one hand, the law will be changed to make it easier to have enterprise unions; that is to say, if 100 or more people are in an enterprise then those people shall have a union.

I refer honourable members to the statistics. The latest statistics available on manufacturing establishments-they refer only to manufacturing establishments- show that as of 30 June 1980 2,265 establishments had 100 or more persons. If we start looking at all the other areas of the economy, how many damned unions will we finish up with according to this philosophy? This is put forward in the name of giving effect to the Government's principle of industry unions. The Government is going to wave a wand and say: 'Flower here, flower there little unions, flower everywhere. Let's have a hundred unions here, a hundred unions there and a couple of thousand more over there; in every enterprise let there be a union'. At the same time as it is saying: 'Flower unions everywhere', it will be saying that the principle which has been contained in its policy since 1974 and which it regards as fundamental to good industrial relations is the concept of industry unions. Whom does the Government believe it is having a lend of? It is mutually self-contradictory and is a further reflection of the fact that this Government does not approach industrial relations in terms of a sensible, rational analysis of what is best for this country. It has a haphazard, ad hoc sort of approach to please every passing whim and prejudice with which it may be confronted. That is not the way to handle industrial relations in this country.

The simple fact is that there are too many trade unions in this country. We have over 300 of them. The employers, the Commonwealth Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, in the National Labour Consultative Council, have recognised that fact as a result of two of three years of mutual, constructive, co-operative work. The legislation prepared on that basis to give effect to the Council's belief was brought into this Parliament but the trogladytes knocked it off. It is time for an end to prejudice on the part of the Government; it is time to recognise that there is blame on all sides, including the Government. Let us recognise this fact-let us not think we exhaust our responsibilities by blaming one side only and see that there is a principle whereby the exercising of power by the powerful in this country, whether they be on the side of capital or labour, is brought to an end and those who claim upon the limited resources of this country have to justify those claims before tribunals where the public interest will be represented.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to give to the House some statistics which form the basis of the observation I made in my speech about working days lost in 1980 and 1981?
—If the Minister wishes to refer to a matter in which he has been misrepresented, he would be in order. If he wishes to continue the debate, he will have the right of reply.
—No, by seeking your indulgence, I do not intend to continue the debate but to take up the point made by the honourable member for Wills in which he accused--
—Order! I wish to determine from the Minister one point. Does the Minister claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes. An accusation has been made--
—The Minister should deal purely with those matters in which he has been misrepresented.
—That was the purpose for which I was seeking your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Minister is entitled to proceed only in relation to a matter such as that about which he has sought to speak when he has been misrepresented in his speech in the debate.
—How do you know what he said?

—He has just told the House. Had the honourable member been listening he would know. He can speak only if he has been misrepresented about a matter on which he has spoken in the debate in order to explain that misrepresentation. The Minister has not spoken in the debate. Therefore, that Standing Order does not apply to him.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister's speech which, as I say, sets the pattern for the next Federal election in Australia, and perhaps not astonishingly is brought in before the by -election in Lowe, tells the Australian people that their attention should not be focused on the question of interest rates, that it should not be focused on the question of the bills that they cannot pay, that is should not be focused on housing that is not available, that it should not be focused on all of the real issues that trouble the people of Australia; it tells them that their attention should be focused on the trade union movement. The Minister tells us that the great problem with which the Government is grappling is that of wages. This Government has done more to destroy a wages system in Australia than has any government since Federation.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1975 the Prime Minister of the day said, 'We will abide by wage indexation'. There was no equivocation. The Government of the day was going to live with it, and in spite of the way the submissions went before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission the Government adhered to indexation. It went along to the hearings and said that there should be no increases or partial increases, or ceiling increases-whatever they may have been-but it participated in the indexation hearings.

It was always mad for the Government to believe that the Commission would be able to minimise disputes, which is its historic role in Australia, by carrying out the will of the Government on this question of wages, by giving no wage increases at all or by giving partial indexation and adding to the insult by ignoring completely the impact of increased productivity. All of those things have been occurring in the last six years, yet Government members wonder why the crippling wage structure of the last six years completely vanished in 1981.

If they believe that the union movement, or even people who are not organised, given the impost of this economic mismanagement in Australia, are all going to sit at home and say, 'The Minister for Industrial Relations has told us that we are all much better off than we were three years ago', they must think such people are slightly mad. One cannot go anywhere in Australia and get the story that people think they are better off. The Minister in his statement, keeps talking about average weekly earnings. Everybody in this House ought to recognise that the term 'average weekly earnings' applies to 33 per cent or 34 per cent of people-the minority of wage and salary earners. If honourable members go into the great working class suburbs of this country they will find that people are earning between $150 an $250 a week. They are the people with the real problems. They are the people who cannot keep up. Even the people who are now going above average weekly earnings have another trap lying in wait for them-the Government's taxation schedules. If they go above the $17,000 income mark now they find themselves being taxed as middle class Australians. These are some of the problems that the Government ought to be attacking. It ought to be going out in the course of the by-election in Lowe and saying to the people of that electorate, 'These are the answers we have to your problems'.

What does the Government do when it comes to the Parliament? It had its first opportunity today, the first day of Parliament after four months. We are told we have now to sit 21 days in this session, the shortest session on record. Under Malcolm Fraser we will be the laziest parliament of all time. He had an opportunity to debate all day the economic policies of this Government, but he put up John Howard who talked about 1968, 1973 and 1978. This is 1982. We would like someone from the Government side to tell us what will happen to the people in 1982, in 1983 and 1984 because it is those people who are facing the problems of today. We have listened to the rhetoric of the Government. The Prime Minister of Australia is telling the people who are paying record high interest rates and who are looking at record high unemployment and a wages system which has totally collapsed: 'The Government is not in the business of hitting the pockets of the working men and women of Australia'. He should tell the working men and women of Australia that the Government is not hitting their pockets. These people are going home with less and less money to carry out the functions of a normal Australian family. People cannot pay off their homes. Those who are clinging to their homes are eating worse and worse food. They are sacrificing the proper food that a family should have in order to maintain a family home. The Government is telling them to forget about the wages system or that it will not allow massive wage increases.

The Prime Minister and his Minister for Industrial Relations have said over and over again that the real villains are the metal workers, John Halfpenny and Laurie Carmichael, Norm Gallagher and the builders labourers, and Charlie Fitzgibbon and the waterside workers. The system which this Government has now adopted is making heroes of the suppossed villains of the industrial relations in this country and the people, as the honourable member for Wills pointed out, who will miss out are the people who are not organised into trade unions or people who are in very small, weakly organised unions. They are completely dependent upon the good will of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. This Government will say to them: 'There will be no increase. Don't worry about what the others have got that have gone before you'. The Minister was not stupid enough today to tell us how many people got the recent increases which he described as massive. However, in a speech which he made outside the Parliament but which did not receive as much scrutiny, he told us that 90 per cent of the wage earners had received the increases. That is an absolute joke. He knows it is a joke and everbody in Australia involved in industrial relations knows it is a joke. This Government does not mind those with muscle getting a wage increase because those with muscle are a minority in the work force. The Government does not mind if one million in six million can leap ahead as long as it can keep control over the other five million.

This is why the Government has destroyed indexation. Too many people, particularly people in rural areas represented by the other side of the House, who did not have the muscle to keep up with the cost of living will now lose out altogether. This is why the Government has sought to bring about a confrontation on the subject of wages. No union leader in this country-it does not matter whether he is involved with shop assistants, metal workers, wharfies, transport drivers or insurance officers-can go to a general meeting of his members and say : 'We have to stop our claim for wage increases because the Government says it is bad'. The membership of every union in Australia is saying: 'We have to have substantial wage increases to keep up with the additional costs which are being imposed by Government policy'. The Minister tells us about the increase in the consumer price index and compares it with the growth in average weekly earnings. But he does not tell us that interest rates are not included in the CPI. He does not tell us that the latest increase in the CPI-the 4 per cent odd-is inclusive of the injected increase as a result of a decision made by this Government to charge every person in Australia a minimum of $10 a week for health insurance.

All of these things are coming together to bring about a militancy in the work force in this country that we have not seen for generations. Any union leader who tries to put the Government's case to the work force in this country at the moment will be sacked. He will be voted out at the next ballot if he puts forward the sort of proposal put forward in the Minister's speech today. The Minister mentioned a multiplicity of things that this Government intends to do. The honourable member for Wills has told us of the madness of industry unions. There is no real understanding by the Government of what it is attempting to do. Who will do the mass rewriting of the constitutions of all the trade unions? Which unions will agree and which will not agree?

This Government did everything possible a few years ago to destroy amalgamation , and that is still its belief. It is on a bender, as though it were full of dope, hoping that in some way it can write laws in this country that will weaken the will of organised labour in Australia so that people cannot get the increases in wages to which they are entitled. There will be no let up on the wage front in this country in 1982 and 1983. Everbody tells us, including the Australian Treasury which dictates the policy of this Government, that the economy in Australia in 1982 and 1983 can get only worse. No one can say to the work force: 'You have to make sacrifices which we are not expecting of other sectors of the Australian community'. The demands will be there, and Australia is suffering because this Government has had no policy on wages all the way through from 11 November 1975. Australia will be gratified when it does have a government that can come to grips with the proper relationship between government, trade unions and employers on the wages front.
