TALK.START.PARA: -After that high flying hyperbole from the honourable member for Port Adelaide ( Mr Young) perhaps we can return in the next 15 minutes to at least one or two of the specific matters on industrial relations which were proposed by the Government and which were not referred to by the honourable member or by the Opposition speaker who preceded him, the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke). I was pleased to hear the honourable member for Wills say that there are faults on both sides. I was pleased to hear him say that what we need in this country is some sort of consensus on industrial relations. I was pleased to hear him say that in substance there is some merit in some proposals on industrial relations that come from this side of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to give the honourable member for Wills an opportunity to state clearly that he supports the Government on one of these industrial relations matters about which there should be bipartisan agreement and about which there should be no dispute. That relates to the proposal by the Government that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission should not have power to insert preference clauses for individual trade unions in awards of the Commission, to take one modest cautious step towards reducing the power and the force of the closed shop. That is important it seems to me, not just because it is a fundamental industrial relations issue but because it is one of those factors that is clogging up and restricting the employment market in this country. It is one of those features of the employment market that must be removed, root and branch, if we are to loosen up the employment market and create more opportunities for employment.

Surely, here is an issue in which the Opposition can say to us: 'Yes, we support you. We will vote in favour of that amendment to the law. We will agree with you when you propose to take away from the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission the power to grant union preference'. The Opposition should be saying : 'We will agree with you because it is wrong for closed shops to exist'. It is wrong that a union can say to an ordinary citizen of this country: 'You cannot work in this industry or get a job in this factory because you do not have a union ticket. If you join our union-not any other union-we will allow you into our shop. We will deny every basic civil liberty, every human right of people in this country and other countries in the civilised world in order to preserve the right of the closed shop'. That position is absolutely indefensible. It is contrary not only to commonsense but also to every basic principle of human rights and law. We invite the Opposition to stand up today and say unequivocally that it will support the Government in removing this restriction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that apply to the Victorian bar, of which you are a member?

—I invite the honourable member either to interject or stand up when I have finished and indicate that the Opposition will support the Government on this very important reform. Let me also say that I would support the reform applying to lawyers as much as it does to workers in factories. I look forward to the honourable member's support on the same terms as those I have just given.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we are debating industrial relations issues and at the outset it should be made very plain indeed that many of those industrial relations issues have a direct and very substantial impact on employment in this country. To put it very briefly: Our case is that employment growth in Australia, although it has been very substantial over the last couple of years, is now being put at risk by a number of factors. The following are not all the factors but we believe they are significant factors. First of all, excessive wage increases have increased the cost to industry in this country and consequently restricted employment opportunities. Secondly, industrial disputes and strikes are deterring employers from expanding their businesses and starting new businesses. Thirdly, I mention the risk arising from claims for reduced working hours which are not being matched in this country by increases in productivity.

We say it is time that all Australians understood very clearly that the consequences of excessive and continued wage costs, of industrial disputation and the never ending demand for reduced working hours will be that employees will be priced out of their jobs. The result will be that employers simply will not be able to afford to employ either new employees or indeed many of their present employees. We say that the success of our economic policies has been reflected in the employment growth in this country over the last few years. But this success will be jeopardised -we do not deny there is a risk at this moment- if there is not more commonsense and moderation in demands for higher wages and shorter working hours. It will be jeopardised if we continue on our self- destructive course as a nation of strikes and industrial disputes.

I will look initially at the first of those factors-increased wage costs in this country. I will cite one of the authoritative sources in Australia on industrial relations who has had years of experience and who should know what generates employment and what does not and who should know those factors that militate against employment expansion in this country; that is my friend the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke). I will go back to the time when employment growth in this country was strong, a situation at the middle of last year when the honourable member gave, I think, a very enlightening interview on radio 3UZ in Melbourne. I do not say this in a churlish or carping way. I praise the honourable member for what he said on that occasion. I will read what he said because I believe it is one of the major solutions to unemployment in Australia. The honourable member's words were indeed prophetic. He said:
If you want what I think is the real answer, it really follows from what I've been saying, I think that if I were in charge--
That is not the prophetic part-

I'd be saying to the Government Departments 'now look, we've got to sit down with the trade union movement and with the employers and really try and explain to them what the state of the economy is, what capacity there is for wage movement, what sort of adverse circumstances are there going to be for everyone- including workers, if wages explode too fast. Because-
The honourable member used very prophetic words when one looks at what has happened in this country over the last six months. He said:
there's no doubt that if wages do explode too quickly, it can have adverse economic impacts on unemployment.

One can say beyond any shadow of a doubt that wages have exploded too quickly in this country and that not only can they have adverse impacts on employment but also have they indeed had very adverse impacts on employment. In the last few months we have seen employers shed labour. We have seen employers shelve expansion plans. We have seen employers obviously reluctant to take on new employees because simply they cannot afford to do so. The honourable member was prophetic when he made that remark. In the interests of the country, the workers and, above all, of all unemployed, I invite him to go to his old friends in the trade union movement-to Mr Dolan and other union leaders-and to say: 'Look, it is beyond doubt that if wages do increase too substantially the jobs of our fellows will be at risk and jobs for the unemployed will be at risk. Employers will not be able to take them on'. That is what the honourable member should be doing. We invite him in the national interest to do exactly that. We invite him and his party to go further and to say: 'We will join with you in a consensus appeal to unions and to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission'. Perhaps the Opposition would even come with us to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and say: 'This is a joint appeal for some restraint and some reason before even more workers in this country price themselves out of jobs and before this country prices itself out of even more overseas markets'.

Other features also deserve to have the spotlight put on them. I mentioned them briefly already. One of the factors which is militating against employment growth in this country is it seems the never ending series of industrial disputes and strikes. How can it be reasonably expected that employers will start new businesses and expand their present businesses when they cannot rely on getting goods and raw materials delivered, when they cannot even rely on employees getting to work? I have heard from employers in the western suburbs of Sydney that they will not employ young unemployed people in the far flung suburbs because there is no guarantee they will ever get to work-there are so many rail strikes in Sydney. Likewise is the argument in respect of reduced working hours. The union movement, or some parts of it, seems hell bent to destroy sections of industry in this country. They say: 'We want shorter working hours, the same wages or increased wages and we will do absolutely nothing to increase productivity in this country'. This is the third prong in the formula for disaster. If we do not face up to the situation-I paraphrase the words of the honourable member for Wills-in some sort of consensus way and recognise there is reason on both sides and try to adopt some of the attitudes about which , heaven forbid, there should be no argument whatever, this country is doomed.

Other honourable members want to speak in this debate. In conclusion I think it should be said in as concise a way as possible that we have achieved a lot in terms of employment growth in this country. We have achieved a lot in getting the rate of unemployment down. Although there was some interpretation from various quarters of the figures on unemployment which came out last week, the simple fact is that the rate of unemployment, in the normal way that full time employment is measured, has come down in each of the last four years. Although we say the problem is by no means over, we say, in fairness to ourselves, that at least that is an improvement and we are getting the rate of unemployment down . We invite the Labor Party to work with us along the lines that I have suggested today to demonstrate its support for the idea that we can do a lot as a nation to increase employment and reduce unemployment. If we accept some of these very basic and elementary propositions, the country will be much better off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is little wonder that the workers of this country are concerned to push for some degree of wage equity because this Government's economic policies and the effect these are having on workers are truly appalling . It was elected on promises that it would eradicate unemployment, support wage index- ation, reduce taxation and interest rates, retain national and comprehensive health insurance, and implement workable industrial policies. Yes, it made those promises to the Australian people. Instead, this Government of graziers, pig farmers, dairy farmers and suburban solicitors-anyone but qualified economists-has presided over six years of record unemployment, record tax levels and record interest rates. It has destroyed the capacity and aspirations of all the young people in Australia to own their own home because of its incapacity to hold interest rates down. It has destroyed its own concept of tax indexation and also wage indexation. It has reduced to a shambles many of the vital industries of this country, including the car industry and, unfortunately, the steel industry. It has proved incapable of implementing a just and equitable wages policy and now, partly as a consequence, it is presiding over a rocketing inflation rate. The people of Australia should note that inflation rose by 4.2 per cent in the December quarter, which is equivalent to an annual rate of 16.8 per cent. It should be also noted that the rate of inflation increased from 9.2 per cent in 1980 to 11.3 per cent in 1981.

SPEECH.PARA: To the extent that recent wage increases in a minority of industries may have contributed to a resurgence of inflation, this Government has only itself to blame. It has not kept its promises to the wage and salary earners of Australia in respect of any of the matters that I have enunciated to the House. It has allowed taxes to crush the ordinary wage earner and it has allowed the greedy to pay little or no tax by refusing to implement retrospectivity in anti-tax avoidance measures. It is no wonder that the workers of this country are concerned about lifting their wage levels.

The Government came to power on a policy of reducing taxation, yet it has become the highest taxing government in the history of Australia. Income tax collections have risen from $15.3 billion to $18.6 billion in just one year. In six years income tax paid by ordinary people has risen from 42 per cent to 46 per cent of total tax receipts. The rub is that pay-as-you-earn taxpayers pay 83 per cent of that 46 per cent of total tax receipts. Of course, the other 17 per cent consist of people such as small businessmen who can reduce their tax commitments to some degree by all sorts of schemes that are not available to the ordinary wage and salary earners. At the same time as income tax levels have rocketed for wage and salary earners, company tax as a percentage of total income has fallen over six years from 15 per cent to 13.5 per cent of total revenue.

Not satisfied with socking wage earners with increased income taxes, the Government has hit them with sales tax increases although it promised it would not do so. Is it any wonder that wage earners are concerned about their falling living standards and their level of real income? The Government promised that there would be no increases in taxes on consumption. We are still debating the sales tax measures which were proposed in the last Budget. I am pleased at the decision which I am told was taken today by some people in another place to abort some of the inequitous increases. The Government intended to increase by over $500m sales tax paid by people who can least afford to do so. I should point out that the Government promised that it would not impose such a tax. This Government has no coherent policies to restructure tax. It has ruled out tax relief this year, unless it decides to bring about a double dissolution or something like that because of fear of what might happen to the economy next year. But it has said there will be no tax relief this year. It wishes to crush pay-as-you-earn taxpayers with high rates of taxation while it goes soft on the tax avoidance industry from which it is said another $1 billion a year could be collected if proper policies were implemented.

In addition, the Government has broken its promises on interest rates. It is not so long ago-maybe three years ago-that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser ) said: 'We will have interest rates down by 2 per cent before the end of 1979'. What has happened? We have record interest rates for housing loans of 12.5 per cent if one is lucky enough to get a loan from banks and 13 per cent to 15.5 per cent from building societies. The semi-government authorities are borrowing money at 15.5 per cent plus. That is the situation faced by workers who want to own their own homes or who are already paying off home loans. The Government will find to its regret that many workers in the electorate of Lowe face this problem. Workers have faced increased repayments of between $66 and $70 a month on an average housing loan over the last two years. Is it any wonder that there are problems with regard to wages policies in this country in the light of the Government's broken promises and that workers, given the fact that the Government destroyed wage indexation as I will prove in a moment, are concerned about maintaining their present living standards? They are faced with the payment of an extra $11 to $20 per week in tax as a result of being pushed by the Government into higher tax brackets, $4 per week in increased sales taxes and at least another $15 per week if they are paying off housing loans. In addition, they are faced with rising prices generally.

This Government has no wages policy. I cannot stress this point enough. The Government has destroyed wage indexation. After promising to maintain wage indexation, between February 1976 and January 1981 the Government was involved in 15 hearings of the court for wage indexation increases. In the first five hearings the Government argued for an increase which was less than the consumer price index increase. In the seven hearings from May 1977 to June 1979 the Government argued for no wage increase whatsoever. In January 1980 it argued for less than the CPI increase and in January 1981, the Government argued for no increase whatsoever. I seek leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard a table prepared by the Parliamentary Library that sets out the Government's record with regard to its destruction of wage indexation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—I have not seen the paper.
—I thank the House. The Government has destroyed wage indexation. It has no wages policy but it bewails the polarisation and surge in some industries-I might add, a minority of industries.

SPEECH.PARA: It might be noted that the Australian Council of Trade Unions policy, as decided at its last congress, provides in broad terms for the right of unions to fight for increases on an industry basis outside the Commission. It also decided that it should run a national wage case and, also, seek quarterly adjustments. Whilst that is the policy of the ACTU, it does not necessarily happen to be exactly the policy of the next Federal Labor Government. At least we will put forward a rational wages policy which will be based on giving equity to working people. It will not be based on a return to the jungle. It will not be based on a return to collective bargaining. It will not be based upon urging those unions which have a capacity to struggle to fight outside the court and telling those unions which cannot afford to struggle to go to the court and ask for something that will not be forthcoming in the present economic climate.

Let us examine what this futile, bumbling Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) proposes. He said that his Government will no longer support wage indexation. That is no surprise to us. He said that the Government will urge for no increase in the next national wage case. That is no surprise to us either. But the question I put to the Government is: What about the lower income earners , those people in the weaker unions? The Government is advocating a return to collective bargaining. It is saying that the weaker unions will be able to go to arbitration. Yes, they will be able to go to arbitration but the question is: Will they be able to get a result or will it be the strong unions such as those in the mining and resource development industries and some of the major manufacturing industries that will get the increases? Will the increases go to the workers in the unions which are best able to pay and most able to fight in a dispute? What will happen to the workers in the manufacturing and secondary industries who are consistently and increasingly exposed to the failed economic policies of this Government? I refer to workers in industries such as the car industry, the steel industry, small businesses and the ancillary metal industries. The Minister is really arguing for a polarisation in wage levels in this country. He is saying: 'Let the weak go to the wall and to the strong shall go the benefits of industrial struggle'.

Let me examine what passes for an industrial relations policy. The Minister in the statement said that the Government would legislate to make it easier for employers to stand down workers who, whilst not involved in a dispute, might be affected by it to the extent that there is not work available for them. He should understand that such a policy is anathema to the trade union movement. It will inevitably widen disputes. If there is one thing that the Government should learn, it is this: The standing down of workers who are not directly involved in the strike decision making process can have only one result and that is inevitably to widen the dispute. The Minister said that the Government would give workers the choice of whether or not to join a union and to end the closed shop situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you support it?

—I wonder whether the Minister who asked me do I support it, supports it in his own organisation. The Minister is a member of the Bar, I think. I believe that when a solicitor is admitted to the Bar he is no longer able to practise as a solicitor. Is that not in effect a closed shop? The Minister supports a closed shop situation inasmuch as he will not and cannot go to the Bar to argue a case unless he has a junior counsel. The Minister is a member of an association which is one of the great closed shops of this country. The Minister is able to command outside this place a salary in one day which is more than an ordinary worker is able to get in one week because of their monopoly yet he has the audacity to come into this place and talk about closed union shops. I want to cite an example in the retail industry. A Woolworths shop in my electorate has decided it will have its very own closed shop because it has said to its workers -this is relevant to the Government's proposed legislation-that they must be members of the Shop Distributive and Allied Employees Association. Woolworths is sacking women who for 20 to 30 years have been members of another union, the Storemen and Packers Union of Australia, because they will not become members of the employers closed shop union. Will the Government's legislation cover that sort of situation?
—Do you support this change?

—Will the Government's legislation allow workers to choose the union of their own choice in a situation in which two unions have coverage or will there be one law for the employees and one law for the employers? This Government says that its industrial relations policies are designed, in the national interest, to protect industry, to create employment and to protect individual workers. In reality its policies do none of those things. They are not designed to achieve those ends. They are designed to achieve the maximum inefficient results in industrial disputation.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

TALKER.NAME: Mr N.A. BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do. May I briefly say that I said in the course of my remarks that I would support the removal of preference clauses and closed shops whether they applied to lawyers or anyone else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make it clear first that we are discussing a ministerial statement by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) on wage determination and industrial relations. Having listened to the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) one could be forgiven for believing that we might be discussing a paper on taxation but I wish to assure the House that we are not; we are discussing an important paper on wage determination and industrial relations. I am not one who would ever shy away from discussing any topic and in relation to those matters the honourable member for Cunningham raised I would have to say that taxation is an issue upon which the Government parties have no shame at all. We are the party that is committed to low levels of taxation in Australia, and remain so. We are not the party that is committed to high levels of government involvement and high levels of government expenditure. We are the only ones who recognise that if we reduce government expenditure we will have a capacity to reduce taxation. If we want to maintain expenditure at an excessively high level we will have no such capacity.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to lose much of my debating time so let me look quickly at some of the matters upon which members of the Australian Labor Party recently indicated their adherence to the view that expenditure must be maintained at high levels.

TALK.START.PARA: —And increased.

—And increased, of course, as my colleague points out. One need only look at one of the related areas. The honourable member for Cunningham was one of those people who opposed attempts by this Government to reduce expenditure by making substantial savings in the area of so-called welfare benefits that are paid to the wives and perhaps husbands of strikers-benefits that are paid to strikers' spouses. The fact of the matter is that that adds a significant cost and members of the Opposition want the Government to continue paying unemployment benefits to the spouses of those who by their own choice want to go on strike. Not only that but also members of the Labor Party rejected important legislation to impose fees in relation to those people who might seek to pursue professional courses such as postgraduate degrees, for instance my colleagues in law who might want to do a Master of Laws degree to help improve their capacity in advising people on tax avoidance. In respect of people who want to increase their income in that way the Opposition said: 'No, we should not put fees on them' and that second, third, fourth, fifth and sixth degrees on some occasions that people might want to pursue should still be paid for by the taxpayers. There is no way a course like that can be sustained. Yet the Opposition would have us believe that we can maintain these sorts of extravagances and a host of others and we can commit ourselves to reduce the levels of personal income tax as well. It is a nonsense and the arguments put by the honourable member for Cunningham are a nonsense and he knows them to be a nonsense. It is about time he committed himself to lower levels of government expenditure. Then we might believe some of the rhetoric on taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: In pursuing the debate I wish to make it very clear that I strongly support the positive program that has been outlined by the Minister for Industrial Relations to improve our wage determination system. The fact of the matter is that not so long ago members of the Opposition were criticising the Government for having no stated policy in this area. It is quite clear that there is a very determined policy in this area and one which is there for everybody to see and read and one which we are here to debate. One could be forgiven for believing that today the opposition wanted to debate anything at all except wage determination and industrial relations. I listened with a great deal of interest to the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young). He said he did not believe anything the Minister had to say in debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is true.

—If the Minister said 'Today is Tuesday', members of the Opposition would not believe him. We on this side understand the way they think. The fact of the matter is that they are basing their arguments in this debate only in prejudice. The fact of the matter is that they ought to have listened to the policy statement because if they had they would understand that there are clear issues which could be discussed and not simply brushed over by the sort of rhetoric that we have heard to date. The honourable member for Port Adelaide wanted us to believe that the Government parties wanted to avoid discussing any other questions but industrial relations. The fact of the matter is that whilst members of the Opposition might want to discuss taxation and all sorts of other things the people of Australia are interested in industrial relations-the people of New South Wales are interested in industrial relations. I wish to point out to the honourable member for Port Adelaide that Mr Wran is interested in industrial relations.

SPEECH.PARA: I have here a newspaper cutting. It might have been useful if the honourable member for Port Adelaide had had a look at it before he entered this debate. He would have seen the comments of the President of his own party. What did Mr Wran , the President of the Australian Labor Party, have to say? I read from the Sydney Morning Herald of Monday, 15 February 1982. Perhaps the honourable member for Port Adelaide has not caught up with his reading yet. The article is in Monday's paper if he would like to have a look at it. It is headed: 'Wran's lash at unions; a tinge of ''lunacy''.' If I used such terms I would be accused of union bashing. The fact of the matter is that this is what Mr Wran was saying. One can understand it. He said:
. . . there was a 'tinge of lunacy' about strikes which have halted all trains in New South Wales and threatened supplies of petrol and power.

Describing today's rail strike as 'unnecessary and unjustified,' he said that some elements of the trade-union movement appeared to be inviting the type of draconian industrial legislation that the British Government was enacting.

I have not had a close look at the legislation yet. I will have a close look at it because Mr Wran may have something there. These were the comments of the Labor Party President. Industrial relations are an issue. The people of Australia are concerned. During this debate people have attempted to avoid discussion of who the real culprits are for the breakdown of the important industrial principle of comparative wage justice. I must admit that I have been persuaded that in the past comparative wage justice was an important principle. I believe that while wage indexation was in place there was a prospect of that being achieved. The fact of the matter is that through a determined campaign by the trade union movement of this country comparative wage justice has been destroyed. This has not happened through the actions of this Government, not by attempting to say that the Government did not want full wage indexation and by suggesting that was some promise of the Government. But by steadily making statements of that sort, the Opposition and the trade union movement undermined the very credibility of the wage indexation system which the Government supported in its entirety. Because members of the Opposition had never read the guidelines that were to operate in that area and were totally unfamiliar with them, they always wanted to argue that indexation was something other than what the Commission itself had said indexation was.

We know that the reason that system was put aside was because a large number of unions were unwilling to accept indexation as a principle and were unwilling to accept the principle of comparative wage justice and went outside that system, sought over award payments outside the system and defeated the objectives of the system. We know also that others, through anomaly arguments, sought to advance their case. Ultimately the number of anomalies became so numerous that they were , in fact, the rule. Employers, of course, in some cases acquiesced in that matter. The shorter working hours campaign of a number of unions in New South Wales was in direct contravention to the spirit of wage indexation, a campaign that brought about its end.

We know that if employees argue for shorter hours and then expect when that has been achieved still to work the same number of hours but at overtime rates, they are arguing for a higher salary than they would otherwise obtain under the indexation system. That has put intolerable pressure on the system. The system did not end because the Government went out and argued against it; the system came to an end because the people in the trade union movement who had no conscience, no concern-the people who, the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke ) called them the strong trade unions, when he made an analogy with the strong capital-were prepared to put aside the system of comparative wage justice. The shorter hours campaign initiated by the metal and power industries in New South Wales in particular were a direct cause of the end of indexation. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will call me short in a moment for the suspension of the sitting. I intend to resume my speech by discussing the particular disputes that brought this system of wage indexation to an end.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting, I was endeavouring to erase once and for all the myth that the Australian Labor Party has endeavoured to perpetuate that in some way this Government was responsible for the end of indexation. That is a myth. Earlier in my speech I made a large number of points . I do not intend to reiterate them, but I do note what today the President of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Wran, said. He also has endeavoured to perpetuate that myth and to put on to somebody else the blame for his difficulties in New South Wales and the difficulties he obviously has got himself into with his colleagues, particularly colleagues such as the honourable member for Port Adelaide, who no doubt does not see industrial relations as any sort of issue, but of course Mr Wran does. Mr Wran said that in his view it was Mr Fraser who got rid of wage indexation.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that union pressures led to the demise of indexation, in particular four cases that were under way in July last year. I refer to the Telecom Australia disputes, of which there were two. One involved the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association and the other involved the Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union. There were also disputes within the Overseas Telecommunications Commission involving a union claim. There were also disputes in Australia Post and disputes involving the Transport Workers Union of Australia. We know that a significant settlement was made in June and the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission failed to ratify that agreement.

When wage indexation was abandoned in a decision handed down on 30 July, the Commission stated that it abandoned the system because of the lack of commitment of the participants to the system and the high level of industrial disputation. I do not know how anybody can dispute that it resulted from agreements people were negotiating outside the Commission. The decision to abandon comparative wage justice was made by the trade union movement. Wage indexation was put to death as a system for delivering comparative wage justice when the unions were not prepared to accept the decisions of the Commission and wanted to go outside the system to settle their claims. I do not intend to pursue that issue any further.

In the statement by the Minister for Industrial Relations, which we are debating this evening, some important legislative reforms were highlighted. I endorse all three of them because I believe they will be important reforms, reforms that will be welcomed throughout Australia. Interestingly enough, no honourable member on the Opposition benches, except the Opposition spokesman on industrial issues, the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), directed attention to those legislative proposals. The honourable member for Wills in his discussion mentioned only one of those reforms and that was the first of the legislative proposals, that which seeks to provide for the formation of industry -based unions and to allow enterprise unions to be formed. He did not discuss the proposal in any detail; he simply heaped scorn on it by suggesting that there is a large number of manufacturing enterprises in Australia and if all manufacturing enterprises were to have an industry-based union that would mean that an enormous number of unions would be created. By heaping scorn on the proposal in that way, he endeavoured to suggest that it was not a viable proposition.

The fact is that the Minister was not saying that all enterprises ought to have a union or that such unions ought to be compulsory. What he was saying was that the relevant legislation would allow for enterprise unions to be formed. Clearly there are a number of situations in which to have such unions would be a positive advantage. One need only think of the very major manufacturing enterprises in the motor vehicle field, for instance. I refer to firms such as the Ford Motor Company of Australia Ltd, for which such a union would be appropriate. One need only think of, say, some of the firms that operate in the ports areas, where our overseas trade has been held up significantly because of the very significant demarcation disputes that have been taking place there. I think the reasons I have advanced highlight the fact that that reform, the first one mentioned by the Minister, is essential.

The second one mentioned by the Minister is, in my view, more important, namely , the proposal to establish a system whereby employers can invoke stand downs when a selected number of employees-I use that word advisedly-go out on strike in order to bring a firm to its knees in an endeavour to further a particular industrial situation. The honourable member for Wills mentioned in his speech-I thought wisely-that there were strong unions in this country and, of course, there was strong capital. He mentioned the reasons that for a long time legislation advanced the cause of the industrial trade union in this country and throughout the world against strong capital. It did so because strong capital was acting in a way which was not altogether appropriate for the membership of the unions. Equally, when the bargaining situation has changed there is a need to review that balance. That is what has happened in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a pathetic attempt we have heard tonight from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) and the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) to defend what they called the Government's wages policy. The truth is this Government does not have an incomes policy, a wages policy. In fact, one of the biggest problems in Australian industrial relations today is the Minister for Industrial Relations. I think if one were to take a straw poll in Australian industry one of the first steps that most employers would think would be advantageous to improved industrial relations would be the removal of the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Viner) from the industrial relations portfolio.
—You are talking to the wrong people.

—The Minister says I am talking rot. I am not talking rot. I see as many people in industries as he does. They probably do not have the courtesy to say to him that he is not wanted. I am telling him what they say to me. Perhaps it would be good if a few other people told him that. His Government destroyed indexation. It took a Labor government to sell indexation to the unions after the wages push of 1974. A sensible government coming to power after that period of using indexation for wages would have tried to maintain that system by making certain that any decisions it took did not have a detrimental impact upon the index. In other words, if that government were able to contain inflation it would impact positively upon the index, which would mean that there would be a lower rate of increase in wages.

SPEECH.PARA: People have argued, I do not think persuasively, that indexation just generates more inflation. If we had had a sensible government sensitively making certain that its decisions did not impact detrimentally upon the index, we could have reduced the rate of inflation in Australia, had much more stability in industrial relations and wage fixation, and when there were real productivity gains they could have been spread to the joy of everybody concerned. Instead of that what we have is a government which has run out of all its election promises . It promised to maintain wage indexation, it promised to maintain tax indexation, it promised to maintain Medibank-it promised to do all those things. In fact, what we have seen in the past is impost levied upon the work force which the Government has argued through its counsel at the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission hearings should not be passed on by way of indexation.

Then we heard the term 'partial indexation'. Indexation is either real or imaginary. It is either real, full indexation or no indexation. Partial indexation is a misnomer. The unions, to their credit, even tolerated partial indexation for a very long time before it became quite clear to everybody that the Government was bent upon destroying it, as the honourable member for Wills ( Mr Hawke) pointed out earlier in the debate this afternoon. The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, in judgment after judgment, called upon the Government to stay with the sense and the spirit of the indexation policy and to try to contain itself in terms of the kinds of decisions that were being made by the Government which had a detrimental impact upon the index. The Government obviously was not playing the game. The Commission knew this and so did the unions. Finally, the system broke down. The actions of the Government illustrate that it never learns. It is still adding to the index by its own actions. In the December quarter of last year the index climbed substantially-by 4.2 per cent. Almost half of this increase was due to Government decisions. In the area of health it was 1.3 per cent, of sales tax it was 0.4 per cent and of State and local taxes it was 0.4 per cent. The increase in State and local taxes was occasioned by increases by State and local government bodies because of cutbacks in Commonwealth funding. Those figures account for over 2 per cent of the increase for that quarter.

I turn to the costs the Government is asking wage earners to bear. Family allowances have not been indexed since their inception in 1976 and are probably worth less than half of what they were worth then. Pay-as-you-earn taxation is increasing markedly. The great burden of Australian taxation is falling upon pay -as-you-earn taxpayers while other classes of individuals and corporations are being exempted from contributing to this massive growth in tax revenue. Sales taxes are increasing all the time. This year the crude oil levy will raise $3, 500m, most of which will come from the motoring public. At no stage did the Government have a mandate to increase petrol taxes but it did so. The petrol tax is a completely new tax and a real impost on wage and salary earners. In the last two years rising interest rates have cost persons with a mortgage of $30, 000 about $15 a week or $60 a month, yet the Government has the temerity to say that these increases should be borne by wage and salary earners and that wage increases should not be pursued. This Government's wages policy is basically to screw the economy to the floorboards, to hold back the rate of growth in the money supply so that it is difficult for employers to pass on any increases in wages. The Minister said in his speech:
Let there be no misunderstanding; the money supply will not be expanded so as to accommodate excessive wage increases.

In fact, at the moment the money supply is growing at about 7.7 per cent and inflation is running at 11.2 per cent or more, so we can be certain that the money supply will not be expanded to accommodate anything; it is actually contracting. The point at issue is that this Government has no wages policy whatsoever. There is no point in the Minister coming in here and trying to tell us otherwise. Average weekly earnings are expected to move from the 34c in the dollar tax bracket to the 42c in the dollar bracket later in the year. This will add to the burden on wage and salary earners and they will seek a resolution of that problem. The situation can be alleviated only by the Government bringing in some taxation relief. The Minister spoke in very contradictory terms. I will read a passage of his speech. He said:
On top of this the ACTU is seeking introduction of full automatic quarterly cost of living adjustments commencing with the 4.2 per cent increase in the CPI for the December quarter.
The Minister went on to say:
There is no way the Australian economy can stand a wage increase of this magnitude.
Over the page, he said:

The weaker unions will not be left out in the cold by this approach. It is wrong for the Opposition or the ACTU to say that they will be for the State and Federal tribunals are always there for them to pursue their claims.

On the one hand the Minister talks about an industry by industry approach to unions and the capacity of industry to pay and on the other he says that the employees in weak industries who are not able to extract those kinds of wage movements can go back to the State and Federal tribunals. When the Australian Council of Trade Unions puts a case to the Arbitration Commission for the introduction of full automatic quarterly cost of living adjustments for those very people who are in weak unions and weak industries and who are seeking a 4.2 per cent increase as compensation for the December quarter consumer price index, he says that there is no way the Australian economy can stand this. One cannot believe that that kind of inconsistency could be argued within one page of a ministerial document which purports to be a serious attempt to look at the problems of industrial relations and wage fixation, yet we find that in this document. The Government obviously is just kidding itself if it thinks it has any kind of wages policy.

We come then to this new concept of enterprise unions. That is a joke. As the honourable member for Wills pointed out very capably before the suspension of the sitting, statistics in regard to the categories and levels of employment about which the Minister was talking show that there are 2,265 such enterprises in the manufacturing industry alone. That means 2,265 individual unions. Obviously there is no way one can get any union management structure in enterprises of that size. There is no way that one can get the kinds of efficiency that should be seen in union managements, particularly in relation to wage fixation, movements in inflation or the economy and the things for which union managements are responsible. There is no way that 2,265 unions could afford the sort of advice or expertise required. They cannot be compared to the local unions in the United States because those unions are parts of much larger unions. The Government intends here to have individual small unions in an enterprise. That is no solution to the problem.

Whenever we have looked at the amalgamation of unions to try to get away from the proliferation of unions in Australia we have always had opposition from the present Government. Amalgamation was opposed by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) when he was the shadow Minister for Industrial Relations and he has continued that opposition. In the first couple of pages of the speech the Minister laments the fact that the Commonwealth does not have direct power over wages. When the last Federal Labor Government proposed a referendum giving the Commonwealth a wages power, the present Government as the Opposition of the day vociferously attacked and opposed the proposal. At no stage has it sought to clothe the Commonwealth with adequate constitutional power over wages. At every turn it has opposed the amalgamation of unions. That has been done basically on advice given by the National Civic Council to the Prime Minister on the basis that the amalgamation of unions ends up in big left wing unions being formed. That does not have to be the case at all. It would be very much in Australia's interest to have an amalgamation of unions rather than the proliferation of unions which are part of our history and which produce so many demarcation problems within industries.

Obviously the Government is now desperate to try to light upon a wages policy to save its political hide. However, nothing will save its political hide. The Budget is now in tatters. The heavy levels of capital inflow upon which this Budget is premised are not arriving. The money supply is growing at a very slow rate. A major credit squeeze is running and the Commonwealth is offering 16.5 per cent for securities. In this morning's newspapers the institutions are offering 17 per cent interest and are on-lending at 19 per cent, 20 per cent and 21 per cent. Who in this country believes that enterprises can be financed with interest rates of 21 and 22 per cent and still maintain growth. Growth is plummeting. The only growth left is that which comes from mining sector investment and that is receding as well. The economy is going deeply into recession. Prices and inflation are going up, unemployment is rising, pay-as-you -earn taxation is increasing and sales taxes are increasing. All of these imposts are rising. In this climate, with a very pessimistic community and a declining economy, wage and salary earners are looking for compensation to try to keep kith and kin together and to make ends meet.

This Government has completely run out of ideas. It has had it. It is ready to leave power. It will lose office very soon because there is nothing that it will be able to do now to resuscitate the Australian economy. It is doomed to languish for some time and we will see a change of government in this country. When we see that we will see some industrial relations with sense, based upon the respect between the ALP and the Australian trade union movement. There will be some real meeting of minds in arriving at a sensible wages policy based upon a mutual understanding of problems and not the bash and barge sessions we have had from the talking head, the honourable member for Stirling, the present Minister for Industrial Relations who represented the unions when he was a barrister. He would do anything to make a quid. He is now on the other side of the House belting the hell out of them whenever he gets a chance in fulfilment of the philistine views of the Prime Minister. This Government will never make the grade in industrial relations. This document is a joke. It will be regarded as a joke by any sane commentator on industrial relations. It gets no respect from the Opposition. We completely oppose the sentiments contained in the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement this afternoon by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) on wage determination and industrial relations outlined the Government's very clear and succinct policy on this important issue . It must be recognised from the outset that the Commonwealth does not have direct power over wages, nor can it legislate for any particular wage level. But it does have a very heavy responsibility to make a contribution to the proper processes in this important segment of the welfare of the Australian nation. This afternoon we listened to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) in what could be described only as a ranting and raving session about the problems of the Australian economy and about the trend of the situation in this country in many respects. One can assume only that this was really deliberately designed to overshadow one of the major considerations that has to be debated by this Parliament, that is, the statement made this afternoon by the Minister for Industrial Relations.

SPEECH.PARA: It is patently clear that the Opposition is floundering on this matter. It is patently clear that the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) has failed to put forward any constructive proposition. Likewise, his one and only admission was made during the contribution by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs ( Mr N.A. Brown) when he reminded the honourable member for Wills of a statement he made last year on the importance of some reality in the determination of wage levels. That was the only sane admission made by the honourable mumber for Wills today in this debate.

I want to deprecate the approach, which we have just witnessed, of the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) who, above anyone else, ought to be the last person to engage in personalities in this Parliament. He asserted that there was some underlying campaign against the Minister for Industrial Relations in the arena of the industrial sector of this country. What he does not admit, of course, is that it is just part of a campaign on the part of the Opposition to try to denigrate the approach by the Government to these very important questions of where we go on wage determinations, what policy should be proposed and what processes should apply in order to bring some sanity into what is really a runaway situation at present.

The Government has a responsibility to make a major proposition at all times in this matter. It has that responsibility because it is the responsibility of the Government. We were told this afternoon in no uncertain terms to accept responsibility for the economic climate and for those matters of administration by government that affect the economy. It remains very clear indeed that one cannot divorce this question of the processes of wage fixing from the overall question of management of the economy. So the Government since it came to office , has made a very clear proposition-certainly it has in this statement-as to the ways and means by which these things should be approached. We deprecate the collapse of the system as it has operated for several years past. We do so on the grounds that the parties involved did not honour their word in many respects and did not accept the reality of sticking to agreements or to some form of arrangements.

Among the militant sections of the trade union movement a belief has grown up that if they go out in support of a single cause for some section of the work force of this country it does not matter about the rest and that if they gain what they want to hell with what happens to the rest of the country. It is little wonder that we have heard the honourable member for Wills this afternoon quoting some statement made by the then Premier of Western Australia six months ago. It was equally interesting to find that he made no reference at all to the statements made this week by the Premier of New South Wales, who also happens to be the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party. I ask whether he forgot or whether he was deaf when the Premier of New South Wales, in very clear terms, said that some union leaders are showing twinges of lunacy, are being bloody- minded and are kicking the public in the face with their unjustified bout of strikes. If we look State by State at the industrial situation today it is little wonder that the statement made this afternoon by the Minister underlined in particular the importance of having some cohesive approach to this matter when the Premiers Conference takes place later this week. That is the venue that should follow the enunciation of policy by this national Government on behalf of the respective parties which constitute this Government. At that Premiers Conference there ought to be reality about where we are going economically, what the needs of this period are and what will be required if we are to keep this country out of dire economic trouble in which wage fixation could be the Achilles' heel to a dilemma that we just do not want to see occur.

I am sure that the Premiers will show reality when they meet at the end of this week because the expressions from the majority of them indicate very clearly that they understand the problem and recognise the needs. Certainly what they are saying individually is very different from what we have heard from the Opposition in this House today. I put it to the House that a course can be followed which will accommodate the aspirations of those who represent the workers of this country, which will accommodate a sane approach on the part of industry, which will provide the jobs and the economic climate and which, at the same time, can be taken as part of an overall encompassing approach based upon the statement that has been made today. It was a reasoned statement and not one that is one-sided. It was a reasoned statement which states the facts as to what has occurred, what has put us into the position we are now in in this country and what moves can be made to further us along the track of getting a fair deal for all sections of the community.

Let us remember that under the present trend there is a consistent and, unhappily, a non-rewarding approach by sections of the trade union movement to avoid at all costs, the proper processes of arbitration and to use the strike weapon and all of the other devices which are many and varied today. Let us remember that the damage being caused to the average Australian citizen is now really far beyond what is reasonable and far beyond what the average Australian citizen can understand. I refer to the impact at all levels. It is well known and well understood, certainly in most of the States. In New South Wales-my own State-we face the most drastic effects upon the economy because of industrial blackmail in the electricity industry. I refer to the bans which have been placed on the bringing into service of 25 generators needed to carry the load in the electricity field in the coming winter. The ban was deliberately imposed in respect of those 25 generators ordered by the New South Wales Labor Government. What is the Opposition saying about that? What did the honourable member for Blaxland say about that? He said nothing. There was deathly silence as far as he was concerned. Of course he, as one of the executives of the Australian Labor Party, would work, I expect, in very close liaison with the President of the Australian Labor Party, the Premier of New South Wales. Surely those two men recognise the damage done to their party, to their Government in New South Wales and to the people of that State; yet we have heard not one word of condemnation in this debate concerning this major issue. That is but an example of what we are witnessing in this period. Obviously, it is part of the price paid by the respective sections of the Labor movement in trying to accommodate the extreme Left in many instances, extreme groups in many instances and, overall, the price for failing to recognise that if political expediency alone is taken into account in the matter of industrial relations we jeopardise the chance of saving this country from what can only be described as real disaster-disaster for the future of employment, disaster for a fragile economy and certainly grave hardship for those sections of the community which are less able to withstand the effect of these things.

I refer to those on fixed incomes. I refer to those who are participants in small business. I refer to the farming community. I refer to all of the sections which, under no circumstances, are in a position to pass on the drastic effects of cost increases which must flow as a consequence of the kinds of things that are occurring at present-unless we adopt a sane approach of the sort that has been suggested today, the kind of approach which would put the Arbitration Commission back into business on a sensible basis in regard to wage determination, one that would provide a chance of restoring some equilibrium in the matter of industrial disputes. Time does not allow me to explore some of the proposals that the Government is putting forward.

What a tragedy it is for this country that Opposition spokesmen, in particular the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), should condemn any suggestion that some change might be made. The honourable member, who was for so many years the leading advocate for the trade unions as the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, had never-ending trouble-which he has admitted and which in saner moment he refers to in slightly more practical terms as the impossibility of managing the system as we have it today. Despite this, any suggestion that a move be made towards making a change that might bring about a better balance is immediately attacked, without even the chance being given to see what its terms are on the excuse that the Government is making a deliberate move towards confrontation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course you are.

—The honourable member for Wills, as does the honourable member for Hindmarsh, who has just interjected, knows clearly that it is absolute kite- flying on the part of those who express that view. They know perfectly well that the proposals for amending legislation-thus far outlined in general terms, with the details to be given at the appropriate time for debate in this House-will provide an opportunity to overcome the real difficulties that all sections face today and that, in fact, they represent the real reason for the statement to which I referred earlier by the Premier of New South Wales. It is not the first time that that kind of statement has indicated very positively that there is a problem, that there is a need for a sensible approach to the updating of the system as we have it today.
—Tell us about the statement by the Premier of Western Australia.

—It is necessary to go back and look at the rest of the circumstances. One then sees that the statement made by the Premier of Western Australia was made in the context of a discussion at a Premiers Conference and that a range of other issues related to it. It has been quoted out of context this afternoon, and in no way can stand on its own if one makes a comparative assessment of the situation-if one looks at the whole picture of industrial relations in Australia today, State by State, remembering that about 50 per cent of the responsibility in the matter rests with the States because of the break up of the unions and awards that come under State jurisdiction, as distinct from those that come under Federal jurisdiction.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, I support strongly the Government's policy as outlined this afternoon by the Minister for Industrial Relations. I believe it offers us some hope to resolve major issues which this nation faces at present-the great problems of unrest and discontent, the great problems which, as I said earlier, are affecting every section of the community-problems which must be remedied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The timing of the statement on wage determination and industrial relations by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) has not really much to do with industrial relations at all, but it has a great deal to do with the Lowe by-election. In that by-election voters will have an opportunity to express their outrage about interest rates, housing shortages, excessive rates of taxation on people receiving less than average weekly earnings and the savage imposition of sales tax. On 13 March voters will pass their own vote of censure on the Fraser Government. However, the one issue that the Government hopes it can use to its own advantage to reduce the expected margin of defeat is that of industrial relations or, as practised by this Government, and this Minister, the art of union bashing.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been one of the traditional stocks-in-trade of Liberal governments since 1949, and their United Australian Party and National predecessors dating back to the 1920s, to blame the trade unions for everything that goes wrong in this society and this economy. The trade unions, the siren voices shriek, are too strong-and by implication the industrial-political oligarcy must be too weak. The reactionaries of our society, like the Minister, call for a basic redistribution of wealth and power, a redistribution which will strengthen those who are already strong and weaken those who are already weak.

The Poverty Commission report, actually published under the aegis of this Government, found a basic distribution of wealth in Australia in which, so far as income was concerned, the top 10 per cent had 22 per cent of all income, the middle 40 per cent had 47 per cent of income and the lowest group, the 50 per cent at the bottom of the socio-economic pyramid, had less than 30 per cent of the total income.

The view of the Government is that if only you could change this, if only you could reduce the income received by that 50 per cent, if only you could cut it down to 20 per cent, everything would be all right; if you could only redistribute up. It is like a diversionary tactic-someone crying, 'Fire, fire!' Once it was the Reds under the bed. Now it is, 'Too much power for the trade unions'. It is miraculous that they have been able to get away with it for so long but, in fact, they will say anything.

It is the genius of the Liberal Party-I refrain from using that word about the National Party because it would not be appropriate-to teach lower income people to lack confidence in themselves and to feel that if anything goes wrong it must be people like themselves who are to blame. It is extraordinary to compare the kinds of things that the Minister was saying this afternoon, when he talked about trade unions with their excessive power holding up the nation to ransom and so on, with what was said by an authority who would certainly be respected by members of the National Country Party. I quote from a speech given in January 1981 by the Right HonourableJ. D. Anthony, the Minister for Trade and Resources and Deputy Prime Minister. The speech about industrial relations in Australia, was given in Japan on Australia Day. He said:
There is one aspect about Australia that is sometimes raised . . . and indeed was raised at last week's discussion.
That is the industrial relations situation in Australia.
I acknowledge there are too many strikes in Australia but the position in Australia is not as serious as the position in the U.S., Britain or a number of other large industrialised countries.
In Australia strikes are generally of a short duration compared with other countries.
Furthermore, in terms of man days lost the impact of strikes in Australia is small compared with that of public holidays and normal holidays of workers.

TALK.START.PARA: —And much lower than industrial accidents.
—Much lower than industrial accidents, as the honourable member for Melbourne Ports points out. He is absolutely correct. Mr Anthony continued:

SPEECH.PARA: It is also important to recognise the different social/political history and context in Australia compared with Japan.
In summary, I believe that the industrial situation in Australia is given too much prominence by some people.
We can include the Minister for Industrial Relations amongst those 'some people' .

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the squire of Nareen?
—Yes, the squire of Nareen, certainly, although he is no longer using negro slaves. I will say that for him. Mr Anthony continued:

SPEECH.PARA: Despite industrial disruption, Australia has remained a reliable supplier to Japan and still offers advantages of price, quality, transport costs and stability . . .
Even though we have strikes, Australia is a very stable country and strikes do not lead to fundamental changes in the social and political order.

The concerns that people in Japan might have about our industrial relations should be kept in perspective. Australia's problems are relatively minor when compared with the problems that exist in so many other resource exporting countries around the world.
Who do we believe? Do we believe Doug Anthony or do we believe the Minister, Ian Viner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Doug Anthony was speaking in Japan.

—That is the difference. They will say anything. It depends on the audience. If a Minister goes to Japan he tells the Japanese one particular line. In this case, the line was correct. However, when there is a by-election in Lowe and there is an issue which the Government thinks may be sensitive or inflammatory, it tells the people something completely contradictory. I will guarantee that Doug Anthony will not be doing down to the Lowe electorate--
—The honourable member will refer to the Deputy Prime Minister as such.

—The Deputy Prime Minister will not be going to the Lowe electorate and telling the people there what he told the people in Japan, but that is exactly what he ought to be doing. The Government thinks that the electors in Lowe are gullible, but they are not. The effect of the by-election precipitated by the unfortunate resignation of the right honourable former member will give the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) a punch up the bracket that he will long remember.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to take up one or two of the points made by the Minister for Industrial Relations this afternoon. I will follow up the point made so eloquently by the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) and the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) about that fallacy of average weekly earnings. The Minister said that in September 1979 average weekly earnings were $239.10 a week and in September 1981 they had risen to $301.10 a week. The implication was that such an enormous rise must be attributed to the trade union movement, and that it must have a terrible effect on inflation. It has to be remembered that 66 per cent of all wage earners, and that includes the overwhelming bulk of people in the trade union movement, receive less than average weekly wages.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't want to know about that.

—Of course the Government does not want to know about that. We have to remember that the average wage is not the same as a median wage. The Government talks as though that figure of $301.10 is a median wage. I dare say that the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) thought that the two figures were the same, but they are not. Let me illustrate how this comes about. Let us imagine a group of five people. One earns $1,000 a week, two earn $250 a week and two earn $100 a week. Between them their gross earnings are $1,700 a week. Therefore, the average wage, dividing $1,700 by five, would be $340 a week ; yet four of the five earn less than that average figure-two of them marginally less and two substantially less.
—They don't care about that.

—No, honourable members opposite do not understand at all. There is a tremendous fallacy about average weekly earnings but there is no fallacy about one of the things for which this Government deserves the severest censure, and that is the way in which the income tax squeeze penalises lower and middle income earners, particularly in marginal seats such as the seat of Isaacs and many others throughout Australia.
—And all those people in Lowe.

—Absolutely. The income tax squeeze is the result of course of tax rates which were set basically many years ago. They were then appropriate enough because an income 10 years ago of, say, $200 was comparatively significant. But now an income of $200 a week is not regarded as being a very good income.
—It is regarded as disadvantaged by the Government in its medical insurance measures.

—Yes. The tax rates set are quite oppressive and middle and low income earners are paying far too much tax. Our taxation system which was designed to be progressive has in fact become regressive in practice. The glib assumption is often made that wage rises are a unique contributor to inflation as though the wage rise was the base figure on which all other charges were added leading to a total inflationary figure which is far greater than the wage rise itself. To use a phrase that used to be hurled around a lot by the Minister for Industrial Relations, it is as though the wage rise has a kind of multiplier effect. In other words, if we have a wage rise of 5 per cent we might expect double that figure as the total inflation figure. In fact it does not work out like that. The conventional economic wisdom certainly links the growth of inflation in the 1970s, especially in Australia, with wage rises and deficit budgeting. However, a comparison of inflation-as measured by consumer price index figures-increase in average weekly earnings and the size of domestic budget surpluses or deficits for the 1970s suggests that the links are apparent in some years, but not always, even allowing a time lag of 12 to 15 months for flow-on to occur. I seek leave to incorporate a table prepared by the Parliamentary Library on the comparative impact of wage rises and budget surpluses or deficits upon inflation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The table read as follows-
Wage Budget surplus(+ Year
Inflation rises or deficit(-)
*Inflation was at its highest in January-March of 1975, when it reached 17.6 per cent (falling to 13-14 per cent within twelve months).

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Let me take, for example, the annus mirabilis of 1975 when there were wage rises of 25.4 per cent. The inflation rate at its height reached 17.6 per cent, which was certainly deplorable enough, but over the whole year the total inflation was 15.1 per cent, considerably lower than the overall wage rise.

SPEECH.PARA: The final point that I want to make before I conclude is that I thought the Minister gave an extraordinarily simplistic explanation as to why one of the problems in this economy of ours was that people were reluctant to start new enterprises, and that was the line which was also taken up by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N.A. Brown). I can tell them why people do not start up new enterprises in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is because they do not trust this Government.

—It is because they do not trust this Government and in many ways they recognise that Australia is a classic example of a client economy, the important areas, the commanding heights of the economy, are already in foreign hands and there is considerable timidity about capital formation in Australia which has led to a major discouragement in the setting up of new enterprises. We have a list of major enterprises in Australia dealing in coal, copper, aluminium , uranium, motor manufacturing, food processing, computers, drugs, chemicals, plastics, petrol and advertising. What have they all in common? They are either totally or overwhelmingly in foreign hands. That is why I say that we in Australia have a client economy. Malcolm Fraser is the Australian Quisling in this sense.
—Order! The honourable member for Lalor will refer to the Prime Minister as such.
—All right. The Prime Minister is Australia's Quisling who has--
—Order! The honourable member will withdraw the remark.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to justify the remark, if I may.
—Order! The honourable member is not free to justify a reflection on a member of the House.
—I thought it was an accurate historical description which perhaps we could take up--
—The honourable member will simply withdraw the reflection.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, because of the profound respect that I have for you, I will withdraw. We can talk about it some other time. In this client economy of ours, it is true that, where labour shedding is concerned, of course wage levels are a factor that have to be taken into account. One cannot isolate that element and consider it alone. As well one has to take into account the impact of technology, foreign competition and, of course, the withdrawal of capital, because so much Australian capital has in fact left this country and gone off-shore.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one other point I want to make in the minute that remains. I want to say something about the Minister's advocacy of enterprise unions. I think that this is a crazy idea. I agree completely with the honourable member for Wills. The idea is based essentially on the Japanese model; but, as honourable members know, Japan has a very different industrial history. It comes out of the feudal tradition-in fact it comes out of the bushido or samurai tradition-in which there is the tradition of lifetime employment and national enterprises such as Sony and Toyota are owned by the Japanese themselves. There is no corporate raiding. Also there is company involvement in education, housing and health none of which are part of our tradition. I think to suggest that we could simply pick up the Japanese tradition of the enterprise union and simply graft it onto the Australian social environment is talking nonsense but it is exactly the kind of nonsense that one would expect to hear from the Minister for Industrial Relations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.

The Bills that I now re-introduce into the Parliament will impose sales tax of 2 .5 per cent on a range of goods that are at present exempt from the tax. The measures represent the last of three groups of sales tax changes proposed as part of the 1981-82 Budget. The other two-an increase of 2.5 percentage points in sales tax rates and the correction of a number of anomalies and inconsistencies in sales tax classifications-are now law, operative on and after 19 August 1981. In my Budget speech, I drew attention to the clear advantage that lies in effecting some change in the mix of direct and indirect taxes. I spoke about the potential that such a change generates for desirable reductions in direct taxes, particularly personal income tax, as economic and budgetary conditions permit. The prospect of doing that depends very much on a broadening of the indirect tax base. In particular, the measures in these Bills must be brought into effect. One simply cannot discard measures designed to raise some $ 300m a year without jeopardising the capacity to accommodate other desirable measures in the Budget. Despite some things which have been said against these Bills, the Government, after full consideration, is of the view that there is a clear balance of advantage in proceeding with them, and I therefore resubmit them for passage.

As honourable members know, it is for constitutional reasons established practice to enact nine separate Acts when imposing sales tax. Constitutional considerations also lead to these Bills being in exactly the same form as the Bills of the same title that were last year passed by this House but not the Senate. The Government trusts that on this occasion the Bills will be approved by both Houses. The delay in their passage means that it will not be practicable to adhere to the planned commencement date of 1 January 1982 and, as I have already indicated, a new operative date of 29 March 1982 has been set. It is the Government's intention that, as soon as these Bills have been passed by both Houses, a further Bill will be introduced to change from 1 January 1982 to 29 March 1982 the date on which these Bills come into operation.

The approach in each of the nine Bills now before the House is to impose tax of 2.5 per cent on goods that are identified by reference to items in the First Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act, and which at present exempt the goods from tax. The technical effect of the Bills will be to levy the tax on goods that are at present exempted by items 51, 53, 54, 58, 60, 82 to 90F inclusive, 96, 105, 107, 113F, 120 and 120A in the First Schedule.

The broad classes of goods concerned are books, magazines and newspapers, building materials, packaging and wrapping materials, hand tools, clothing, footwear, drapery, soft furnishings, manchester goods, motion picture films, servicing equipment and construction equipment.
