I emphasise that goods falling within any of these categories will still be exempt from sales tax if they are sold in circumstances in which an overriding exemption in the First Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act applies. By way of example, where a school entitled to exemption under item 63A purchases books for the school's use, the books will remain exempt from tax. Similarly, where a manufacturer purchases hand tools for use as 'aids to manufacture', as defined, the tools will remain exempt under the 'aids to manufacture' head of exemption.

I take this opportunity of clarifying further my announcement of 18 December in which I said that arrangements had been made to extend to schools, universities and other organisations exempt from sales tax the operation of the regulation which already permits some tax exempt bodies to reclaim from the Commissioner of Taxation a rebate for the sales tax component where goods are acquired at tax inclusive prices from retail suppliers. Some education authorities have read my statement as a compulsory alteration of existing arrangements under which suppliers provide goods without charging sales tax on production of a sales tax exemption certificate. I wish to stress that this is a misreading of my statement of 18 December. The extension of the regulation to cover organisations not previously covered is an option available to them, and there is no compulsion upon these organisations to change the arrangements they have with their suppliers.

An explanatory memorandum covering technical aspects of the Bills is being made available to honourable members and, as this sets out more fully the goods affected by these measures, I think that I do not need to provide further detail at this stage. The net result of the changes will be an increase in revenue estimated at some $330m in a full year. The original estimate of the increase in revenue in the current year from those proposals was $132m. The delay in implementation means that only some $53m will be collected in the current year, a shortfall of $79m from that projected in the Budget Papers.

As I indicated earlier, the present Bills complete the Legislative framework for the sales tax changes announced in the Budget, and it is desirable that they soon become law. It is now some six months since these proposals were announced in my Budget Speech, and Bills in the same form as the present Bills were introduced into this place. I therefore trust that the Parliament will now give these Bills a speedy passage. I commend the present Bills-the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) 1981-to the House.
Debate on motion (by Mr Willis) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourchier Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to talk about this statement I, like the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), go back some time to seek a point at which to start. I select as the point the principle that used to be one of the main planks of the trade union movement, namely, a fair day's pay for a fair day 's work. Unfortunately even the honourable member for Wills, with the great intellect which I acknowledge he possesses, would be hard stretched to try to relate the unions' present attitude to that principle. In fact the principle today possibly could be amended to read 'as little work per day for as much pay per day as can be forced from the employer'. It is unfortunate that the word ' productivity' is not in the vocabulary of either the trade union movement or the Australian Labor Party. To back up that statement one has only to look at Australia's abysmal record. One need only quote some of the latest International Labour Organisation Figures which are current to 1979. The International Labour Organisation figures compare the number of working days lost per 1,000 employees in the mining, manufacturing, construction and transport industries in some 19 countries. The International Labour Organisation series shows that, in terms of working days lost Australia's industrial disputes performance puts it sixth highest in the world. On the basis of an average over the five years from 1975 to 1979 the countries with higher averages than Australia were Spain, Canada, Italy, Ireland and India. After Australia the next highest were the United States of America and the United Kingdom. The statistics show that by any standard Australia is at the top end of the list in respect of industrial disputation. What is not readily apparent from the statistics is that our disputation is highly visible internationally. Our disputes impact on other countries because they often occur at the point of export or in respect of an export commodity. Of course, added to that is the effect that those strikes, those industrial actions, have on our own businesses, perhaps not the ones directly connected with the particular strike situation but the flow on to the actual manufacuter, the rural industry of the other sectors that suffer so badly . Then, of course, we have a chain reaction in that the more strikes occur in this country, the more industrial disputes we have, the more there is a lack of job opportunities because employers just cannot cope with the cost of running a business and trying to keep a business going when so many hours are being lost because of strikes and still put on extra people.

SPEECH.PARA: New South Wales, which is under a Labor Government, is now known as the strike capital of Australia. The figures I have, which no doubt the honourable member for Wills will verify are correct, indicate that in the year to September 1981 almost half-approximately 45 per cent; I said 'almost'-of the working days lost in Australia were lost in New South Wales. Almost twice as many working days were lost in New South Wales as were lost in Victoria over that period.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is Victoria doing better?

—Victoria, under a Liberal Government, is doing better. The comment can be made, of course, that Labor gives in to strikes because the unions own the Labor Party. Perhaps they do not own it but they finance it, they direct it, and they state the policies and force them home. Of course, when there are strikes of more or less national importance or concern we never hear from the honourable member for Wills or the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden), and I have put them in their right order. They have been very silent on strikes called in New South Wales by key Telecom and postal employees and by employees in the coal and power industries, as well as the on-going waterfront and seamen disputes. We never hear any complaints from them about that. That is a quite acceptable factor for the ALP. The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N.A. Brown) addressed himself to the belief that the people on the other side of the House should begin at some time to say that there should be equality, there should be some levelling, some meeting ground. They should be able to come to taws with us and go to the employers as well as to the unions and try to get some balance in the whole situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner), on behalf of the Government, has announced that he will introduce certain legislation. Some of the proposed legislation will effect stand-downs. It is absurd that in a work place of some 500 or more persons an employer should have to pay wages to keep 480 people employed when he has no work for those people simply because some demarcation issue or some industrial action has resulted in 20 people staying on strike and frustrating the whole effort.

We heard the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) make a comment which I thought was rather interesting. He said that if the people on this side of the House feel that by bringing in stand-down clauses that will have a positive effect they would be totally wrong and that in fact it would create a widening of a strike situation. I do not totally disagree with that concept but I put to the honourable member for Cunningham-I am sure the honourable member for Wills would agree with me-that there is a danger in the situation which I have cited where a large number of employees have to be paid at a time when there is no work, in other words when there is no productivity and no money coming into the company. The employer might be forced to go out of business and that would be far worse than a widening strike situation because there would be no work place to which the workers could return. That situation is fast being approached and that is why some action of a positive nature has to be taken by this Government to try to break this constant stream of strikes that is occurring.

Another area that the Minister is looking at is industry unions. It is hopeful that one thing can be achieved in this area. There are many problems in this area. I accept that. I am not closing my eyes to the problems that occur because of industry unions but there is no doubt that one of the greatest problems we face-I believe that some honourable members on the Opposition side would agree- is demarcation disputes which are the most frustrating industrial issues that we have in this country for the simple reason that they are created between two union bodies of employees. The employer suffers, the employees suffer and the public suffers. In many cases it is not a dispute over wages; it is purely a dispute as to which is the king union in the area. There is also that very touchy subject of voluntary unionism. I am sure that many of us have seen the effect on people who have been forced not to take a job because of the principle in which they believe and that is that they do not wish to join a union. There is a closed shop and they cannot get a job. I think we have a right to protect the people against that sort of discrimination.

Earlier in my speech I did mention the rather interesting statistics by way of comparison between New South Wales and Victoria. Victoria is, I think, considered to be the major manufacturing State in this country. One-third of Australia's employees in manufacturing industry work in Victoria. Some 418,000 as registered in November were employed in Victoria. Victoria produces about 60 per cent of Australia's motor vehicles. Victoria is a major force in engineering , chemicals, textiles, food processing and so on. The reason Victoria, from where I come, is a major State in these areas is that it has a good government and that good government has taken actions in the past to try to stop industrial unrest. If I may compare the industrial relations situation in the two States just briefly, New South Wales as the strike capital under Chairman Wran lost almost twice as many working days-again I use the word 'almost'; one has to be so careful-as Victoria through industrial disputes. From January to September 1981 the working days lost in Victoria amounted to 584,000 and in New South Wales the number of days lost was 1,151,000. There is quite a difference. Victoria with some 20 per cent of the Australian work force had 22 per cent working days lost and New South Wales had some 45 per cent. It can be seen that the good performances in Victoria are at risk because of two factors. Firstly, the trade unions in the area are definitely trying to cause industrial unrest. They are being led by militant left wing unionists who are the backbone of the Labor Party in Victoria. Secondly, in Victoria we have the Labor Party which is notably controlled by the extreme left wing and which promoted a man named Cain as their leader.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there an election coming up?

—There must be. The Leader of the Opposition in Victoria who was promoted by the extreme left wing and who has the backing of the militant left wing trade union movement has committed himself to taking action that, if the Labor Party were unfortunately elected to the Parliament in the forthcoming election in Victoria, he would repeal the positive measures which have already been introduced by the Victorian Government, such as the Vital State Projects Act. That legislation was used for hastening the completion of the Newport power station. I would like to add that the present Premier of Victoria in his earlier capacity as Treasurer and Deputy Premier was the man who, acting as Premier, took the action that allowed this absolutely essential power station to proceed despite the threats and the actions of the unions.
—That is like New South Wales.

—Absolutely. Another piece of legislation introduced in Victoria related to secret ballots which enables the new industrial relations commission to order a secret ballot on its own initiative. This legislation has already displayed a marked degree of success with the speedy resolution of the strike at the Ford Broadmeadows plant. Another Act that the Labor Party Leader Mr Cain in Victoria would try to delete is the Essential Services Act. That Act was invoked by the Premier, Lindsay Thompson, in July 1981 to end the transport workers strike. If my memory is correct, that strike is the one which affected milk deliveries in the State. The unions were absolutely heartless as was the Australian Labor Party in respect of concern for the mothers of young children who needed milk, hospitals and so on. It did not worry them one bit as long as they went out on strike and achieved their aims.
—Can they get the New South Wales trains back?

—I think that if we had a Victorian Liberal government in New South Wales it would be a much better State. The people of New South Wales are obviously starting to learn that because unfortunately I did have to make a visit to New South Wales. It always used to be a pleasure to stop over at Sydney for a night. It was quite a pleasant place to stay. Now when you go there you cannot even stay in a hotel because it is so hot and you are not allowed to have the air conditioning on because of the power strikes in Sydney. Not only will people be leaving Sydney but also the business people will be leaving New South Wales in droves unless there is a change of government in that State.

SPEECH.PARA: Getting back to the positive State of Victoria under the control of Lindsay Thompson, the Victorian Government introduced another Act called the wrongs Act- the Public Contracts Act. It was introduced in December 1981 to get the Builders Labourers Federation bans at Loy Yang lifted. That Act enables Ministers or statutory authorities to recover on behalf of the people of Victoria losses for damages caused by workers being induced to break their contracts of employment. I hope we can do something along that line in this place because obviously that is one of the great problems that face industries when they have to suffer great losses incurred through no fault of their own. They have done nothing wrong and they have tried to co-operate but because the union has a demarcation strike or some sort of action industry loses and great damage is caused to a company and ultimately to the people generally. Mr Cain has stated quite clearly that if he is elected this legislation which he has said is provocative and a threat to the conciliation and arbitration system as long as it is on the statute books will be removed. It goes without saying that if he were unfortunately to be elected he would get rid of that legislation, that so-called threat. To suggest as he has that legislation to protect the community from union anarchy is pointless, provocative and stupid I think almost puts him in the same bracket as some honourable members from the Opposition side tonight from whom we have heard comments.

The Minister referred on page three of the ministerial statement to wage indexation. The honourable member for Wills and certainly the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) made some comments about that point. I would like to refer to the remarks of the honourable member for Port Adelaide because he honestly believes that the Australians in the street and in the work shops, the ordinary Australians, will tell everybody including us-they tell us loud and clear-that they are not the slightest bit concerned about the number of strikes that are occurring in this country. I have got news for the honourable member for Port Adelaide. He ought to get out into the streets. He claims that people come to his office. Obviously the people who go to his office are only his bunnies because the genuine people are fed up to the teeth over the strike situation in this country. They want the Government to do something about it and this is the Government that will do it. As the Minister said in his speech, wage indexation could operate effectively only as long as the consensus between the parties necessary for its survival remained intact and that has not occurred because the unions kept pressing for increases inside and outside--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government kept pressing for no increases.

—Just be patient my friend. They kept pressing, hammering, threatening and cajoling until they got wage increases outside the guidelines and of course that broke the whole of the arbitration commission system. The unions were warned time and again that the system could not work unless they stopped that. That is exactly what happened. The ultimate result was that disputation increased, as did pressures for increased wages outside as well as inside the system. As a result, there was an abandonment of wage indexation.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, there is no doubt that this Government will proceed with legislation to help toughen the situation with regard to the trade union movement and those particular sections of the trade union movement that wish to destroy this country. That is what they are about, make no mistake. They want to pull this country down so that they can form a totalitarian country. That is what it is all about. We are not going to let that happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Make no mistake, Mr Deputy Speaker; today this Government, through the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner), has set or attempted to set the ground rules for the next federal election. This has not been a statement about good industrial relations but, in fact, it is the first salvo in an attempt to rescue this Government from the economic mess it finds itself in. If we are to give any credence to the remarks of the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Bourchier), I think it is the first salvo in the lead-up to the next State election in Victoria. For one minute I had to think about whether I was in the Federal Parliament or the Victorian State Parliament. All I heard about was Mr Thompson and Mr Cain and what the dreaded Labor people are going to do to the State of Victoria. No mention has been made of the economic mess the Victorian people are in after 27 years of conservative government. On 3 April the Victorian people will sweep the Liberal Government out of power because of the mess in education, transport, industrial relations and the like right throughout the Victorian community.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the statement of hot air rhetoric that we heard today. All we have heard about is how the workers and the unions are to blame for everything that is bad and for every industrial dispute. How ridiculous can one be? Are all disputes caused by unions? Every reasonable thinking Australian will have to think for only one second to come up with the answer, no. No one group, as the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) pointed out quite correctly and succinctly earlier today, is responsible for all disputes. However, this Government continues to portray the picture that no matter what it is, the unions are to blame. I do not think it will hold much credence any longer because the people of Australia are starting to wake up to that situation. They are starting to ask themselves the questions that I am asking and coming to the same conclusions. Of course, it cannot be the fault of the unions all the time; other factors must be causing this situation. It is not always the employers. One can go back over the last few years and cite a number of disputes, one after the other, that have been deliberately inflamed by the actions of this Government.

In general, Australian management would be among the most inefficient in the world as far as industrial relations are concerned. I do not include all management, but to put it in plain English some do not have a clue about how to handle any industrial problems whatsoever. If the hot air rhetoric from the statement of the Minister for Industrial Relations was bad enough, we then had to put up with 10 minutes before the suspension of the sitting for dinner with the speech of the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). I am glad he is in the chamber because his speech was absolutely unbelievable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hopeless.

—One could say that. That would be a mild expression. He actually had the audacity and the affront to attack the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) for talking about taxation. According to the honourable member for Dundas these matters had nothing to do with industrial relations. Little does he know that he needs some teaching from some decent people like the honourable member for Wills. He will tell the honourable member that there are a number of issues such as taxation, interest rates and health that have not just an indirect but a direct effect on industrial relations in the country. One cannot separate them all and say: 'We will not talk about that or we will talk about this dispute here'. It does not work that way and it cannot work that way. Let us turn to page 7 of the Minister's statement. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Movements in average weekly earnings in 1981-82 are expected to be broadly in line with the Budget forecast of 13.5 per cent.

There must be some mistake because he has left out a line. He has left out the line that pay-as-you-earn taxation will rise by nearly 22 per cent. I will quote from page 230 of Budget Paper No. 1. It states:
. . . gross pay-as-you-earn receipts are estimated to increase by 21.9 per cent.

Average weekly earnings are going up by only just over 13 per cent. One might say that there is a slight gap there. If that is not bad enough, we find that the health situation has been in a complete mess since 1975 when we had that great quote from the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) that we will maintain Medibank Private. In the latest concoction there is a minimum payment a week. In Victoria one can get a basic cover for $10 a week. The average family has to front up with that amount.

I turn now to two other areas that are not included in the consumer price index . The first one is in the forgone money that families should have. I refer to family allowances. I think the responsible Minister at the time was Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. She said that that was the greatest social innovation in our history, or words to that effect. The latest statistics show that because of the failure of the Government to index family allowances-including the latest Budget figures-a family with two children today is $25.75 a month worse off in forgone money; a family with three children is $30.75 a month worse off; and a family with four children is $35.75 a month worse off. We can go right through to a large family of six children who would be $47.85 a month worse off in forgone revenue. These amounts are not taken into account in the consumer price index.

We come now to another area that is not in the consumer price index; that is, interest rates. A lot of people do not realise that this does not come into the CPI figure. Interest rates are the highest in Australia's history. That is not a political statement; it is a fact. Honourable members opposite know that as well as I do. As has been mentioned here today, they are ranging to over 20 per cent. It is absolutely wonderful for people with money to lend because they can get over 20 per cent interest on their money, but we, the vast majority of the population, are the ones who have to pay those high interest rates. In the area of housing, 14 per cent to 15 per cent would be a common figure for interest rates so far. I think that will rise in the time ahead.

I estimate that the average family-compared with three years ago-is now paying anything between $50 and $150 a month more in mortgage payments. Of course, that varies according to the size of one's loan, but many people are having to take out sizable loans and $150 a month is not an outrageous figure to cite. One will find many, many thousands of people paying much more a month now than they were three years ago. We find a lot of families do not get to that situation because they cannot afford to take out home loans. The reason rental charges are rising is because the rental market has been flooded. All these matters have an effect on industrial relations. The honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) pointed out earlier that many people come into his office, as they do to mine and I think the offices of most Labor members, and say 'we just cannot live because the economy is in such a depression that the Government is really squeezing every last drop out of the average worker and his family'. All these things I have mentioned come together to squeeze family budgets. When people are , in fact, eating minced steak and minced sausage one day instead of the steak that they were able to afford, the real standard of living is dropping. That is why workers-not union officials as is the great myth-are asking for and demanding more money. While that may happen in some circumstances, a multitude of ordinary workers are puting a great deal of pressure on their officials and saying: 'We just cannot live; we must have wage increases'. One cannot step back and argue against wage increases as a government, without taking into account all the government policies connected with the economy and the pocket of the average Australian person.

As I have said in this House before, the attitude of this Government to industrial relations has been one of confrontation. It has been one of confrontation since 1975 when this Government took office. Here we are again. The Government is in trouble electorally. It will find itself in trouble leading up to the 1983 general election. Lo and behold, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industrial Relations have now got together in this wonderful concoction of 20-odd pages of drivel to tell us that they are going to bring wonderful peace and some wonderful things to the industrial relations area that will make Australia a great country again. It just will not work. People cannot be bashed over the head to win a dispute time and again. It has not worked before and it will not work now.

On amalgamation, as the honourable member for Wills pointed out last year, amalgamation legislation was ready last year but the Government refused to bring it down. I am sure that when it is brought down in this autumn session of Parliament we will find it not in line with the original amalgamation legislation. I point out at this stage that the honourable member for Dundas and the honourable member for Bendigo, who spoke previously in this debate, voted against amalgamation legislation when it was brought before this House by the Labor Government. Mr Clyde Cameron was the responsible Minister at the time and the honourable members for Dundas and Bendigo, who were then members of the Opposition, voted against the amalgamation legislation. Now they are saying: 'We will have amalgamation and we will have enterprise unions'. What a lot of drivel . They are not serious and they are not being honest.

TALK.START.PARA: —They never have been.

—They never have been. I turn to voluntary unionism. Again, it will not work to apply a stick and put pressure in one area without looking at the matter realistically. Whilst I agree that the individual has a right to decide what he or she wants to do, let us carry that the full length. Whilst individuals have a right not to join a union, people who have a right to join a union and do so also have a right to decide whether they will work with the non- union members. If there are 100 people in a work place, 95 of whom decide to join a union and five of whom decide they do not want to, each of the 95 has a right, which honourable members opposite support, not to work with the five who do not want to join the union. Honourable members opposite talk about democracy. They come into this place, with the support of a fraction over 50 per cent of the voting Australian public-let us not forget that 49 per cent of the people voted against them-and say: 'This is the will of the people of Australia. We are allowed to do this'. On the other hand, when 95 per cent, or even 99 per cent, of the work force say one thing honourable members opposite say: 'That is not right. We will not cop that. That one per cent has to be able to do what it wants to do'.
—What would happen if the majority around him decided not to work with him?
—That is fair enough if the other 99 per cent agree with it.
—I defend your rights.
—How would the Government work if the other 49 per cent--
—You want us to be totalitarian. You don't believe in democracy.
—Order! The honourable member for Dundas will maintain his quiet.

—One does not worry about rabbits like that. What would happen if the other 49 per cent of Australians said: 'We didn't vote for that Government; we will not take any notice what it says'? It does not work. I think the drivel the Minister has gone on with today in this statement is outrageous. At least the people of Australia are waking up to the Government. This issue will not be the big election issue the Government is going to try to make it out to be. The Government will not be able to bash the New South Wales Government into defeat. The Government will not be able to save the Victorian Government from being swept away, as it should be after 27 years of inept and incompetent government. It will be swept out quite swiftly and cleanly on 3 April. Any attempt to use any of these types of debates to help the Victorian Government will not help it one iota. The confrontationist attitudes of this Government have been shown again by the Minister and the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: I make one further point before I close. There has been a bit of talk about a lack of constitutional powers, that the Federal Government does not have constitutional power in several areas so it is doing its best under the circumstances. But why has it not done anything about the situation? The Government parties have been in government for 30 of the past 33 years. It cannot blame anyone else. It has had ample opportunity-30 years-to sit down and work out some constructive policies and to put them to the people. We will put constructive policies to the people when we become the government after the Federal election in 1983, or whenever the Government calls the next election. The attitude of this Government will not work. The situation is rather disgraceful. The economy is in a mess and undoubtedly people will pass judgment on the Government at the next Federal election. After that election, we will have a Federal Labor government and sensible consultation in the industrial relations area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ministerial statement which has been put before the House by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) deals with two topics: First of all, the Goverment's wages policy which moves towards a greater decentralisation in wage fixing; and, secondly, specific legislative proposals dealing with preference clauses, stand down by employers and enterprise or industry-based unions. Having listened to the debate this evening, one might be pardoned for thinking that this was the Budget debate we were engaged in rather than a debate on that ministerial statement and on those proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look first of all at wage fixing. On 10 September in this House, in the course of the Budget debate, I advocated the view that the centralised wage fixing system had come to an end. There are many reasons for that. One of the reasons is the failure of the parties concerned to adhere to the system and the absence of any sanctions to enforce such a system. That view, I am glad to say, has in effect been accepted by the Government. What is the answer given by the Opposition? Opposition spokesmen have said that the centralised wage fixing system somehow came to an end as a result, it would seem, of some plot. It has been put-sincerely put I assume-by the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) and the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) that submissions made by the Government in the course of wages hearings somehow affected or worked to the destruction of the centralised wage fixing indexation. Also, according to the honourable member for Wills, the Government broke promises.

That demonstrates two things: First of all, a complete misunderstanding of the functions that submissions have in wage cases; and, secondly, that neither of those two gentlemen has either read the very short statement of reasons handed down in the national wage case of 31 July or, if he has, he has not understood them. A submission made in the course of a case is simply a view that is put and the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission either accepts or rejects it, or it accepts it partly or rejects it partly, or it discards it entirely and comes to an independent view. It has no effect other than that. It is something said in the course of argument. The decision in the national wage case of 31 July 1981 was referred to by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to have a copy of the reasons for decision in that case incorporated in Hansard. Leave has been given by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) for that course to be followed.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
IN THE AUSTRALIAN CONCILIATION
AND ARBITRATION COMMISSION
Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904
NATIONAL WAGE CASE
Melbourne, 31 July 1981
Sir John Moore, President
Mr Justice Robinson
Mr Justice Ludeke
Mr Deputy President Isaac
Mr Acting Public Service Arbitrator Watson
Commissioner Griffin
Reasons For Decision

Since April 1975 the Commission has operated a centralized system of wage fixation based on indexation. It was expected that such a system would be more orderly, more rational, more equitable and less inflationary and would therefore reduce industrial disputation.

The essential feature of such a system was the need to regulate and limit wage increases outside national wage to allow high priority to be given to the maintenance of real wages. It was accepted by all that a set of rules would be necessary to achieve this priority.

The viability of the system depended on the voluntary co-operation of all participants in industrial relations including those not directly represented at National Wage hearings. Monitoring of sectional claims through the processes of conciliation and arbitration was fundamental to its operation.

From time to time since 1975, the Commission has pointed to the fragility of the package and in June 1979 the Commission came to the brink of abandoning the system. A decision about whether we should persist with the system was given as recently as April this year. The Commission refashioned some of the principles to strengthen the priority for the maintenance of real wages but the essential requirements of the package were otherwise unaltered.

The events since April have shown clearly that the commitment of the participants to the system is not strong enough to sustain the requirements for its continued operation. The immediate manifestation of this is the high level of industrial action in various industries including the key areas of Telecom, road transport, the Melbourne waterfront and sectors of the Australian Public Service. In many cases action was taken on the pretext that the claims could not be processed because of the principles. Some of these disputes have resulted in substantial increases being agreed without regard to the test of negligible cost or the implications of flow-on.

To accommodate these strong pressures the ACTU and the Commonwealth proposed widening the safety valve provided by the principles dealing with anomalies and inequities. The belief that the answer lies in greater flexibility of the kind proposed is illusory. Such flexibility would resolve sectional claims at the expense of national adjustments and destroy the priority expected of a centralized system. It cannot be otherwise.
For these reasons we have decided that the time has come for us to abandon the indexation system.

Now that we have taken this step the guidelines will no longer apply in proceedings before the Commission or the Public Service Arbitrator. The Commission will deal with applications as filed, members of the Commission will sit alone or on Full Benches and the various provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act will apply. For instance the concept of the 'interests . . . of society as a whole' (section 4) will still permeate activities of the Commission and of course Full Benches will still be required pursuant to section 39 to have regard to the state of the economy with special reference to likely effects on the level of employment and inflation.
Any application for adjustment of wages or conditions on economic grounds will not be heard before February 1982.

TALK.START.PARA: —As was pointed out by the honourable member for Dundas, there is nothing in that decision to support either of the two propositions advanced by the Opposition speakers, particularly the honourable member for Wills. The Government, having accepted the decision in the national wage case, has sought to place major responsibility for fixing wages with employers and employees. Given the system we have, given the division of powers between the States and the Commonwealth and given the limitations on the Commonwealth power-they are there and cannot be overlooked-it is eminently sensible that those directly concerned should have more responsibility for wages and conditions of pay. After all, if employers and employees do not as a general rule know what their interests are, who does, and who is the Government to give them a better view of what their interests are? What does the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) say to this. Insofar as he addressed himself to the Minister's statement-he managed to spend about three or four minutes on this topic-he said, amonst other things, that what is proposed favours the strong, that the strong would get stronger and the weak would get weaker, and that the Government had no wages policy. I am sorry to say that I missed the first few minutes of his remarks, but I could not discern from his speech what wages policy he proposed. From listening to members of the Opposition address the House, it is perfectly plain that they will conjure up their wages policy at some propitous occasion shortly before an election, or else it will be their old policy which has been rejected by the commission itself. It seems that they are really saying that there should be quarterly adjustments, a national wage case, industry bargaining and, as well , shorter hours. That is what has been put in the national wage case and that kind of approach which has been discarded. Given that situation, given those facts, they have the effrontery to say the Government has no policy when all they advocate is a return to a policy which they helped to sabotage, and sabotage most effectively.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not suggest that what is proposed is the perfect system. Of course it is not. Any system involving relations between employers and employees is bound to be imperfect and to remain imperfect because it is inherent in dealings with human relations that the problems which arise will constantly need fresh views and fresh answers. But it is important to remember that, against the criticism which has been made of the Government, the conciliation and arbitration system remains in place. It is suggested that the weak will have no answer. In a decision of 31 July 1981, the Commission said:
The Commission will deal with applications as filed, members of the Commission will sit alone or on Full Benches and the various provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act will apply.

The conciliation and arbitration system remains in place as well as the system of State tribunals which, as it so happens, deals with a greater percentage of awards binding on the Australian work force than the Federal system. As well as that, features are built into our wage system which can only assist the weak. I refer specifically to the concept of comparative wage justice, of people in the same jobs getting the same pay and the flow on which we always experience from major wage settlements and major award decisions. Those will remain to help, so far as they need it, the weak. Of course the weak always do need help.

I now turn to the specific proposals that have been put by the Government as foreshadowed legislation. I refer firstly to provisions allowing employers to stand down employees for whom they have no work as a result of industrial action . The fact is that technology has advanced so far that strikes or industrial action by a small number of people can effectively immobilise very large areas, communities and factories. One has only to throw one's mind back to what has taken place in Victoria with the power blackouts and the transport strikes in New South Wales. If, as a consequence of strike action, an employer has on his hands 1,000, 2,000 or 3,000 people, perhaps 90 per cent or 95 per cent of his work force, for whom he has no work, what is he meant to do? Is he to keep on paying them? Is that the answer? Who is to pay? What is the justice in that? Is that the kind of industrial society the Australian Labor Party proposes. What are the economic effects for the future? What does this mean? It means that the objective of the Labor Party in that area is to ensure that the employer carries the cost of industrial action and has to pay people for standing around because he has no work for them. That is an Alice in Wonderland view of the way in which the economy should work. The honourable member for Cunningham said that is anathema to the trade union movement. It may be but it is common sense and it is just. The reverse proposition is simply a recipe for economic suicide.

I now turn to the question of preference clauses. The honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) objected heatedly to the proposal to get rid of preference clauses. Is it not fundamentally wrong that the right to work should be conditional on membership of a union? Is it not just as fundamentally wrong that the right to work should be conditional on race, religion or political views? Is it not a basic right that a man or woman should be able to compete in the industrial market place equally with all others for his or her livelihood?

TALK.START.PARA: —Lawyers!

—We have had that. I adopt entirely what is said by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N.A. Brown) on restrictive practices. I return to the matter with which we are dealing, which is preference clauses which prevent people from working. Is it not absolutely wrong that a person who objects to being a member of a union for a conscientious reason, because of objections to the leadership or political objectives of that union or for any other reason should be told that either he joins a union or does not work? Is that a recipe for industrial democracy? Even if that is consistent with the views of the Opposition on the way in which democracy should work, it is a view of democracy which this country does not hold.
—It is a fact of life, except for lawyers and doctors.

—The honourable member for McMillan says it is a fact of life. What does that mean? It means the use of industrial muscle. For what purpose? For the purpose of closing the shop to people who say: 'I do not want to be a member of this union or any other union but I want to work; why should I not have the right to work?' I am glad that that proposal will be put before this House.

SPEECH.PARA: On the subject of enterprise unions, I merely refer to what the Minister said in his statement. Page 19 refers to the fact that this would facilitate the development of industry based unions. Undoubtedly enterprise unions would present some problems, particularly in smaller organisations. Maybe those problems could be overcome, as they have been in Japan. The move towards some more coherent and rational form of organisation is welcomed. In conclusion, it is a pity that the honourable member for Wills, with his wide experience, had nothing to offer on the details of the proposals that have been put forward. If he has a position on these matters he has skilfully avoided revealing his thoughts. Given his long experience in industrial relations, it is a pity for this House and for his country that he has done nothing but present to us a collection of empty and irrelevant generalisations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it fascinating that to date Government spokesmen expounding upon the merits or the demerits of the trade union movement have thrown into the list to support their somewhat notorious Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) two Queen's Counsel, one solicitor and a member of the National Country Party who solved his problems with industrial relations in an electorate which has one of the highest numbers of female unemployed in the Commonwealth by putting his wife on the payroll. That is the level of it. I will not sit here and be lectured on the problems of closed shops by members of a profession, which constitutes the most closed shop in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sorry that the learned Queen's Counsel who represents North Sydney is about to leave. It is all very well for him to say that he takes a certain view of the legal profession. But will he give the House an undertaking that the next time he is briefed he will say to the Bar Council: 'Because I do not believe in closed shops I insist that I will appear without a junior'? Will he say: 'I will take that well-known solicitor, a fellow member, and he can be my junior'? The honourable member knows as does the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs ( Mr N.A. Brown) that they operate on very high salaries and that they maintain one of the greatest closed shops of the professions. What we are talking about are not just wages and conditions. We are talking about real living standards. I should also say that amongst the distinguished lawyers who spoke on behalf of the Government the only one who has any background at all-I acknowledge it-in industrial affairs is the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs who is sitting at the table. He has been a consistent and, I must say, able advocate in the industrial courts, but always for the employers.

If one goes to the heart of this statement what it comes down to is simply this : This Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), who has been in office for longer than any Prime Minister since Robert Gordon Menzies-longer than Holt, Gorton, McMahon and Whitlam, and for most of that period has had control in both Houses- has been in a situation where, on behalf of all the gentlemen opposite, was going to solve the problems of inflation and provide full employment. On 16 February 1982 we have had the spectacle in this Parliament which I doubt has ever been seen in any parliament which espouses the Westminster tradition. The Westminster tradition is not the Speaker getting dressed up in nineteenth century robes and walking in through Kings Hall. It is members of the Government discharging their obligations to this House.

Has there ever been a prime minister in the Westminster system whose total fabric of economic policy was under attack in a censure motion in which it was pointed out by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden)-I will not repeat all the points-that inflation, which was going to be brought down, is now 11.2 per cent? The people who were going to provide full employment are now presiding over the highest level of unemployment in our history and interest rates are at an all time high. Confronted with that situation this Prime Minister sat mute and stony faced and relied upon his numbers in the Parliament to avoid any effective debate. Of course, later in the day he sent in the Minister who, as has already been pointed out, we have some difficulty in believing. I think only his mother believes him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is that?

—I would not want to name him. It might be unparliamentary. I simply say that the Minister who is the author of this document walks into the Parliament and he has the answers. Despite the Government's record period in government and despite the fact that in the latter years of the Whitlam Government there was not a Minister who now sits opposite who did not say that control of the economy was the responsibility of the government of the day the position is different now. The then Opposition would not hear any arguments about inflation being caused by overseas pressures. We could not blame the employers or the trade unions. We had to accept responsibility as that was the Government's responsibility. Today we have heard a statement. When we go to the heart of it, what does it say? It says that all the economic problems in Australia can be put at the door step of the trade unions.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another aspect about this debate which I think needs to be canvassed because I for one am concerned about a situation which is a permanent feature of the approach of this Government when it is dealing with the trade union movement . The Government continually speaks about unions as though it were speaking about a group of martians, a group of people who live and operate outside Australian society. When I hear the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Bourchier) say that he wants to start at the level of a fair day's work for a fair day's pay-

TALK.START.PARA: —He has never done it in his life.

—As I am reminded, he would not know much about it. Because I have been into the factories and the workshops in the electorate of the honourable member for Bendigo. I know a great deal about his electorate. I challenge him-I am happy to go to Bendigo to meet the challenge-to name that section of the work force in Bendigo that he says does not give a fair day's work for a fair day's pay.
—There would be a lot of them not getting a fair day's pay.

—There are many of them not getting a fair day's work when most of them want work. There is no attempt in this statement to meet what I believe is a genuinely felt need amongst the trade union movement, employers and most sections of our society to see a new approach to industrial relations and a lessening of industrial confrontation. This statement promises an increase in industrial confrontation because it is promising the trade union movement more pains and more penalties. I find it extraordinary. How is it that since I have been a member of this Parliament a single strike has never taken place anywhere which this Government has said had some merit. The only strike I have ever heard praised and the only section of the union movement I have ever heard praised is the strike in Poland and Solidarity. It is all right if a person is a Polish unionist. It is oppressive if one attempts to strike. There has never been a single occasion when this Minister, the Prime Minister or any member of the Government who sits opposite, has ever been prepared to stand up in this Parliament and say that there is some merit in the action of unionists and because of the merits in their claims they were forced to take industrial action .

SPEECH.PARA: It has been conceded by the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) as it would be conceded by responsible trade union spokesmen throughout Australia that the history of unionism in Australia shows that there have been a number of strikes which have been without merit, but they are by far the minority. When we are talking about unionists-this is something that I think needs to be said-we are not talking about some alien enemy. We are talking about average Australian citizens who are trying to maintain their living standards. Let me say to members of the great party of private enterprise, that when they say that they believe in the private enterprise system, they believe in a competitive system.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, every New Year's day and around the Queen's birthday I await my daily newspapers with great eagerness and excitement , only to find out, after I open the newspapers with great expectation, that our far-away monarch has omitted to include my name in the honours list. It is some consolation that, since the Order of Australia was introduced, one's chances are somewhat enhanced.

SPEECH.PARA: This year, if you are a Victorian and a migrant, you might be entitled to a consolation prize, as the Victorian Minister for Ethnic Affairs has introduced a special list of Australia Day honours. Although it is true that it is somewhat second-grade honour that our good Minister has introduced under the name of Victorian Voluntary Service Awards, and although this innovation came in an election year, it still may be considered as an attempt at belated recognition of those who are not usually found on our hospital or charity boards, thus forever forfeiting their chance for an O.B.E. or a damehood.

However, it is not the award itself that I wanted to talk about tonight, but about the two recipients of Yugoslav origin that the Victorian Liberal Government found so meritorious. It just cannot be a coincidence that both gentlemen, if I might so call them, belong to fascist organisations. It is true that they belong to two different fascist organisations. Nevertheless, they are fascists all right.

One, Jozo Pavlovic, who was presented with the award by the Deputy Premier of Victoria, Mr Borthwick is, according to the Spremnost, a Croatian weekly, the secretary of H.O.P., the Croatian Liberation Movement for Australia and New Zealand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The remarks that are being made at the moment by the honourable member should, in my submission, be made only when speaking to a substantive motion, of which notice should be given.
—The Chair is not of a mind to accept the point of order without hearing the honourable member for Hotham further. I call the honourable member for Hotham.

—It is a flippant point of order, but I will go ahead. We find from the same copy of Spremnost that Jozo Pavlovic was one of the speakers at the commemoration service to Ante Pavelic which was held in Gippsland, Victoria, last December, to pay tribute to the wartime Croatian Fuehrer. H.O.P., the Croatian Liberation Movement, was established in 1948 by Pavelic in Argentina. Pavelic was the most notorious war criminal in Yugoslavia, probably the second most brutal killer in Europe, after Adolf Hitler.

SPEECH.PARA: Pavelic was installed by the nazis on 10 April 1941 as the Fuehrer of the Croat puppet state during the occupation of Yugoslavia. His government declared war on Hitler's enemies, including Australia. He was the leader of the Ustasha and responsible for the brutal murder of more than one million innocent men, women and children in wartime Yugoslavia.

I do not want to bring up the past. I was one who suffered from nazi persecution and it is painful for me to talk about those times but I am, like other Australians of Yugoslav origin, incensed by the cynicism of the Victorian Liberal Government in honouring types such as Jozo Pavlovic, who are glorifying brutal murderers and advocating that further atrocities be committed against the Yugoslav people.

As for the other recipient, Borislav Petrovic, he is known in the Yugoslav ethnic community as the former president of the Ravna Gora movement, and a supporter of Chetnik Draza Mihailovic, a Serbian quisling.

The Yugoslav community in Victoria is understandably incensed by the action of the Thompson Government in choosing, amongst the 150,000 Victorians of Yugoslav origin to honour, even with an award of dubious value, two fascist scoundrels. Of course, such a choice will defeat the Liberal Government's cynical exercise in introducing these second-rate awards for vote-catching purposes. The Yugoslav community of Victoria, the third largest migrant group, is well aware of the Liberal Party's manifested connections with the Ustasha and other fascists.

A party that chooses to nurture, support and honour people who are preaching hatred and who glorify fascist leaders such as Pavelic and Mihailovic-who between them were responsible for the brutal face-to-face killing of well over a million people of wartime Yugoslavia-cannot expect any support from the Yugoslav community in Victoria. Indeed, their demise at the next State election will be welcomed by all Victorians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I do not believe that we in this House would ever forget that living in the Australian community today are several thousand survivors of one of the most monstrous crimes in history, the nazi holocaust.

SPEECH.PARA: One of these survivors is a constituent of mine, Mr Nicholas Melkman. Mr Melkman, who is of Dutch-Jewish origin, was imprisoned in concentration camps between 1942 and 1945. He was, for most of that period, a slave labourer. According to the Netherlands State Institute for War Documentation-I have a copy of the documentation before me-Mr Melkman was arrested on 3 September 1942 in Amsterdam and was deported to Germany, where he had to work as a forced labourer in the camps of Niederkirch, Siebersdorf and Flossenburg. During the same period his wife and family were murdered by the Nazis.

Mr Melkman came to Australia in 1951 and since 1970 he has received a Dutch Government pension-paid out of West German reparation payments to Holland. These payments, and the Dutch Government payments arising out of them, are designed to give some monetary compensation to the victims of Nazi crimes. In Mr Melkman's case, this compensation can only cover most inadequately years of torment, as well as the anguish of the loss of his family. I should also mention that Mr Melkman has told me that he has suffered from epilepsy, which he believes to be due to the ill-treatment he received in Flossenburg concentration camp.

However, because this sort of pension would be taxed in the Netherlands, and because of the provisions of a double taxation agreement between Australia and the Netherlands, since 1975 Mr Melkman has been taxed on his pension by the Commonwealth Government. Is it not understandable that Mr Melkman and others in his position feel that this particular piece of revenue raising shows a serious lack of generosity towards the victims of nazism? They are also distressed at the peculiar situation whereby pensions such as Mr Melkman's are taxed in Australia while pensions paid by the West German authorities to Australians are not.

Mr Melkman's case, and cases of the same sort, have been taken up on several occasions. In replying to these representations, Treasury has said that to exempt such pensions as Mr Melkman's from taxation would be to make such payments stand out in contrast to Australian pensions which are not exempted from tax. It is also pointed out that the West German pensions that are exempted from taxation in Australia obtain such exemption because they are exempted from taxation in the Federal Republic of Germany itself.

I recognise the force of these arguments and, in particular, the argument that to exempt the pensions of Mr Melkman and other such victims of nazism from taxation might create serious anomalies in the operation of the double taxation agreements between Australia and several other countries. However, the fact is that we are here confronted with a unique situation which is without clear precedent and one, we hope, that is not likely to give rise to any precedents.

Mr Melkman and others-his estimate is that there are in Australia about 200 of them-are the survivors of something that is almost unique in the annals of the human race-the institutionalised insanity of an attempt at the genocide of the Jewish and other peoples. Surely those who have suffered in this most terrible of massacres are justified in their pleas that they should receive some special measure of our compassion. The number involved is not large, nor is it increasing.

It must continue to be an agonising question for our civilisation whether more could have been done to prevent the crimes of nazism. Let us not also have to agonise over whether more could have been done to help and compensate the victims of nazism.

I do not believe that such recognition on our part will be to the detriment of our double taxation arrangements with other countries, for we will only be applying unique redress to unique injuries. It is wrong to talk of anomalies when we are faced with one of the most horrible anomalies in history and are trying to sort out in some small degree its aftermath.

I commend the case of Mr Melkman, and those of others in his situation, to the attention of this House and this Government as deserving of their fullest compassion. I hope that before long some acceptable reply can be made to the victims of nazi persecution who have made their homes in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMahon Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to address the House tonight and present a case for millions of Australians who are finding it increasingly difficult to keep their heads above the financial waters . Two weeks ago I listened with interest to the replies of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in a Sydney television interview to questions relating to the difficulties facing Australians on low and middle incomes. His response was essentially that Australia is still a lucky country. That is small comfort to 17 -year-olds on the dole trying to survive on $36 a week or to a family forced to sell its house because it cannot afford the interest rates. I believe the statements by the Treasurer pointedly reflect the general attitude of the Government. They clearly demonstrate how out of touch with the real world it is.

SPEECH.PARA: When so many of the Government members are near millionaires who own not only their main houses but also holiday houses and whose only financial troubles are how to maximise their investment returns and avoid tax, how could we expect them to understand what it is like for those people who move home every few months because rents keep rising or, as we know, who eat pet food because that is all they can afford? When the Treasurer talks about it still being a lucky country, he means it is a lucky country for himself, his friends and his associates because they are the ones who are enjoying the rising company profits, the capital gains and the tax loopholes. They are the ones who are enjoying the substantial shift in national wealth away from pensioners and beneficiaries and wage and salary earners.

In my electorate in the inner city of Sydney I am confronted time and again by the results of the Government's elitist policies. I see a community being gradually uprooted and scattered towards the outskirts of Sydney where housing is cheaper. I see families breaking down under the strain of the rising cost of living. Just last week an unemployed constituent, Mr Bert Ekholm, burned himself to death in his tiny flat rather than face eviction through his inability to keep up rent payments. Finally, last week pensioners decided that they had had enough of the Government's iniquitous policies and called a mass meeting in Sydney Town Hall and invited the Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, to hear their complaints. More than a thousand of them told him in no uncertain terms that they were not happy with the $69 to $70 a week that they receive on a pension. They told him that this amount was not enough to live on with dignity. They told him that the income test was unreasonable and had fallen well behind rises in average weekly earnings. To all this the Minister replied that they were better off than they were 10 years ago, which was met by hisses and jeers from the pensioners.

The Fraser Government has been blatant in its disregard for the welfare of Australians on low incomes. Just look at who has borne the brunt of the razor gang cuts. With the cutbacks in staffing of government services, the selling of government properties such as the Glebe Estate and the proposed increases in indirect taxes, it is the lower income earners who are most affected. I believe a country can be judged by its treatment of its elderly. In Australia the Government's approach to people, once they cease to be economically useful, is to give them a pittance and to let them fend for themselves. I think this is scandalous. It is particularly scandalous when the Government refuses to increase pension rates but at the same time enables elderly millionaires to receive a full pension and entitlements by the use of tax avoidance schemes and property trusts. When will the Government begin to apply some justice? Many of my constituents are elderly and in receipt of age pensions. Those paying rents are now finding it impossible to compete for housing with the middle class professionals moving into the inner city. With little bed sitter accommodation available at a cost of less than $45 a week, they are forced to spend in excess of 65 per cent of their pension on accommodation, leaving very little for food and other necessities.

Those people fortunate enough to own their own homes are finding it increasingly difficult to keep them in repair. For many of them Techelp is the only agency able to help but it is unable to keep up with the demand because of its shoestring budget and no assistance from the Federal Government. Other domiciliary services such as home help and home nursing have likewise suffered funding cutbacks and are unable to satisfy completely the demand. If the elderly are not able to be supported in their homes, nursing home and hostel accommodation is all that is left. However, in this area, too, the Fraser Government has implemented cuts, leaving not enough beds to meet the needs. The grim picture I am painting is the reality that exists in Australia, and it is particularly visible in my electorate of Sydney. In my electorate a sharp contrast is developing between the haves and have nots. A wave of gentrification is occurring in many of the suburbs. Those houses not being renovated are obviously owned by the elderly or rented by a low-income family. Is this the type of divided society that we want Australia to have? If not, we should be moving quickly to reduce the wealth imbalance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise briefly tonight a number of matters which highlight problems which Australia is confronting now and which the Government is seeking to avoid or even not to recognise. The difficulties which are buried by the rhetoric which is facing many Australian families are difficulties which one would have hoped governments would be concerned about. We are all aware of the difficulties of employment. In fact, in my area it has been a problem for a long time and the government has now found a means by which that problem can be minimised. It has stopped publishing or collecting statistics and has refused to give that information even to the Geelong regional commission which is the planning authority and which, in seeking to cure or to minimise the problems of unemployment, is not able to use basic information which should be available and which is vital to any consideration by a planning authority or an expert body. The information is not even available on a confidential basis.
—Your Party has said time and again that the figures were no good when it was in government. Hayden said that.
—The Minister always has a smart answer.
—It is true. I will show you the Hansard extracts.
—Order! The Minister will remain silent.

—I want to deal with a number of other matters. We are all being inundated with publicity about wage rises and about how if wages did not go up all the problems of the world economy would disappear. If I may say so, this is just plain rubbish spoken by people who refuse to face up to the facts or the problems. They are not in a position to deal with or to solve them. What is the effect of a continual reduction in the disposable income of a large number-the majority-of Australian families? Every person in the Australian community and every family which has an income of less than $13,000 a year is currently paying a higher proportion of income in taxes than was the case a year ago. This pious Government came into office on a promise not to tax by stealth but to be honest about tax and index the scales so that governments would have to increase them when they wished to raise revenue. Not now. This year the Government will accumulate large amounts of taxation revenue by forcing people into higher tax brackets when their incomes relative to the general cost of living have not increased.
—You did that.
—This Government came into office on a promise not to do so. If it were honest it would tell the Parliament why it is not prepared to carry out the obligations for which it was elected.

SPEECH.PARA: Another area in which there are serious problems and which may be tinkered with is the area of home loan repayments. It affects not only those who are first home buyers but also many families in which four years ago husband and wife were working and their income levels were such that they could meet home loan repayments. Those income levels have been destroyed either because one partner has not been able to work because of family commitments or unemployment or because the major breadwinner's status in the community has disappeared because of lack of opportunities in the work force. Those people are in desperate trouble. The once proud boast of this country of the dream of home ownership has under this Government in the last 12 months become a nightmare.

Lastly, I want to mention those least able to defend themselves in the community. While the large income earners walk away with tax avoidance, the Government is progressively reducing the relative level at which tax is applied so that this year a pensioner will have $6 above his pension in taxable income. Above that level, the Government will confiscate one-third of every dollar over $6 that a pensioner earns. That rate is higher than any other section of the community is asked to pay. The Government has really scraped the bottom of the barrel, and now we learn that it cannot even pay its bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.
—I call the honourable member for MacKellar.
—Oh, no.

—(10.20)-I am grateful for that vote of confidence from the Opposition benches. I could not let pass the remarks of the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) because I am absolutely sick and tired of members of the Australian Labor Party standing up and suggesting that, because the economic climate round the world and essentially and necessarily in Australia is difficult, by reversing the policies currently being pursued things would--
—When you were in Opposition you said it was our fault, not a world problem.
—I remind the honourable member--
—Double standards again.
—Order! The honourable member for Corio will remain silent.

—I do not recall having been in Opposition in this Parliament so I will let the remark of the honourable member for Corio pass. It is not my intention to be part of an Opposition in this Parliament if I can do anything about it. I am tired of hearing arguments to the effect that, because things are not as everybody would wish and because things are quite difficult around the world at the moment, it necessarily follows that by reversing existing policies one would do any better. It is absolutely not on to stand up in this Parliament every day and to suggest increases in government expenditure in every conceivable area, which is what the Opposition does. The Opposition says that expenditure by the Government in this area, this area and this area is insufficient, implying that government expenditure should be increased. At the same time the Opposition suggests that taxes are too high and should be reduced and that interest rates are too high and therefore--
—Do you think they are? Do you think they should not be reduced, that they are not too high?

—I remind the honourable member for Chifley that everybody in Australia would be in agreement on two things: One is that taxes are always too high. And the second is that interest rates are always too high. The honourable member and I would agree on this. The sums are as follows: If it is wished to increase government expenditures in each of the areas suggested by the Labor Party, one either increases taxes or expands the deficit. If taxes are increased , the results of that action are quite obvious. If the deficit is expanded, that has an upward pressure on interest rates. If interest rates are too high at the moment, under government by the Labor Party and with increased expenditure and a higher deficit, interest rates would increase.
—That is kindergarten economics and you know it.

—Exactly. That is kindergarten economics as the honourable member for Corio said, and the example is correct. If the Opposition wishes to increase government expenditure-Opposition members are suggesting increases in every area of expenditure even including defence, which is the area that the honourable member for Corio worries about in this Parliament-it must increase taxes, deficits and interest rates. Tax avoidance is the other matter raised by the honourable member for Corio. One treasurer has done more in terms of trying to reduce tax avoidance than any other treasurer in the history of Australia. That treasurer is not one of the many put forward by the Labor Party when it was in office. I cannot recall quite how many Treasurers it had-I think it was at least three. Not one of them introduced a single tax avoidance measure in this Parliament. Since the present treasurer has been in office, extraordinary tax avoidance Bills have been brought in which have been designed to reduce the incidence of tax avoidance. I do not know of any way one could totally eliminate this practice. But there has been only one treasurer I can recall who has done anywhere near as much as has been done by the present treasurer. Not one of the three Labor Government Treasurers did a single thing. When the present Government came into office what tax avoidance measures were on the book for it to use?
—What was the level of tax avoidance when you came into office?
—It was probably at least as high as under the honourable member's administration.
—What about under the Curran scheme?

—Curran was rampant before we came into office. There was not a single measure on the statute books which enabled the Liberal Government to deal with Curran. The legislation for that was introduced under this Government. Successive measures have been introduced since then to deal with tax avoidance. When we talk about tax being high, people avoiding tax and interest rates being high, let us understand that the Labor Party wishes to increase Government expenditure in almost every area that will result in higher taxation and higher interest rates.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's policies are bleeding the pensioners of this country white, as I have indicated by practical examples on a number of occasions in this House. Tonight I wish to describe the financial circumstances of one of my constituents, Mr Robert Luff, who, as a result of spinal injuries, was forced to retire at the early age of 50 years with a weekly workers compensation payment for himself and his wife. He also receives a war veterans pension representing 40 per cent of the service pension. Whenever possible I will use extracts from Mr Luff's letter to me as I cannot improve on his graphic description of his position, a position which is being experienced by thousands of pensioners all over Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Luff refers to a $11.35 a week workers compensation cost of living rise as paid from 1 September 1981. He points out that he suffers a 50c in the dollar deduction in his veterans pension. While his cost of living rises, he is taxed at 32c in the dollar leaving only a balance of $1.98 out of the original $11 cost of living adjustment. In effect Mr Luff has suffered a tax rate of 82c in the dollar on his $11 cost of living adjustment. Mr Luff stated:

At this point, it would be right to assume that most Australians expect to be taxed by some means or other, and don't mind contributing to the running of this country, it is a personal contribution, although it is demanded of him, he pays up . . . When you look at the over all complexities of the Taxation scheme one is utterly confused and bewildered at the systems and above all the percentage of tax demanded of the man in the street, it sounds so small just a mere 32 percent, for the sake of the argument one could say a third of a wage is taken in tax. Where the basic wage is paid in some cases $203 approx $63 is taken as tax leaving a balance take home of $140. In the case of a married man he could take home $160, pay $75 home loan, run a small car, bring up 2 children, have a few of the necessities of life that the Western world offers us . . . Is that living??? No way . . .

It is stated that the Australian form of Taxation is the second highest in the world . . . You know looking at those rates of taxation, you get absolutely NOTHING . . . no medical relief, no future pension schemes, or hospital benefits just a plain 32 per cent take.

The Government is not concerned how frustrated I am, whether I am in debt, I have ceased to progress, suffer pain and immobilisation, and be further aggravated by ILL CONCEIVED plans of taxation and other means of well engineered rip offs by Government Departments . . .

There are thousands like me so effected, having recovered a bit I take up the challenge and appeal to those in command to hear the appeal especially from those who are too aged, too ill and dissillusioned to appreciate just what is happening to them . . . A certain respect seems to have been lost for these people, especially the Ex Servicemen who's services both Australian and Overseas were once readily accepted in the time of war, and now so readily forgotten . . . his valiant effort faded so conveniently into oblivion . . . just another story how we are taken for granted, the old and sick, their effort, deeds, and contributions all swept under the carpet . . .

Back to DEMANDS . . . At 65 there is another crunch . . . I am 63 been retired over 13 years with spinal injuries, having survived several operations, I rank among the more fortunate as I am mobile . . .
