I ask where are these 'Golden Years of Retirement' for those who want to grow old gracefully and financial . . . Let them do it . . .

There are repercussions all along the line, I and those whom I represent hope for a better deal . . . There is no need for banners and protests . . . all we need is a fair hearing, I don't think that is too much to ask for . . .

During the meeting of the Estimates Committee D on 16 September I referred the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to the real hardship suffered by the hundreds of people in my electorate as a result of the low threshold levels for taxation and the low threshold levels for fringe benefits. In effect, the Treasurer's reply was that if the Government had the capacity the raising of such levels would be considered. It is appalling that in Mr Luff's compensation payments of $143.85 per week he should only receive, in effect, $1.98 of his $11 cost of living adjustment.
I will quote once again from Mr Luff's letter. He said:

There are thousands of people in this situation, forced into early retirement due to accident or ill health, it is sudden, one minute you are working, formulating your families destiny, then crash, your out, in most cases no planning, like normal retirement, it is then that your troubles really begin . . . most can't cope with the complexities that arise, some are more handicapped than others, then comes the Migrant he is so confused, he is soon lost in the confusion of it all . . .

The Treasurer must know that the Government has the capacity to redress the appalling financial situation of many thousands of Australian pensioners and should immediately lift the threshold levels for taxation payments, fringe benefits and full pensions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
House adjourned at 10.29 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 1 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can sports men and women who receive any form of payment, however small, for their sports activities, receive payment of medical benefits under section 18 of the Health Insurance Act.
(2) In some States, notably Victoria, are sports men and women precluded under State workers' compensation laws from making a claim for injuries sustained while playing for a sports club.
(3) Will he publish the guidelines, definitions and legal opinions used by and prepared for his Department, in assessing eligibility for medical benefits under section 18 of the Act.
(4) Are there any instances in which persons may not receive medical benefit payments by operation of both the Health Insurance Act and the Workers Compensation Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Section 18 of the Health Insurance Act provides that Commonwealth Medical Benefits may not be payable, wholly or in part, in respect of professional medical services related to injuries or diseases which attract compensation or damages. Hence sports men or women, whether paid for their sporting activities or not, may be refused payment of part or the whole of Commonwealth Medical Benefits in regard to treatment of compensable sporting injuries.

(2) My understanding is that all States and Territories have legislated to exclude professional sports persons from workers' compensation cover. In the case of Victoria, legislation was enacted in 1978 to exclude persons engaged in sporting activities from coverage under the Workers' Compensation Act.

(3) Commonwealth benefits may be precluded under this section of the Act where a person has received, or established his right to receive a payment by way of compensation or damages. This in effect means that where a person has an entitlement to claim compensation or damages, it is expected that the claim should be pursued fully. However, departmental practice in this area has regard to the considerable period of time that may elapse between the date of the action giving rise to a claim and the date of completion of any subsequent litigation. To avoid any unnecessary hardship, provisional payments of Commonwealth benefits are usually made in respect of treatment expenses incurred during this period, providing the patient gives an undertaking that all such benefits will be repaid upon completion of any claim for damages. My Department is currently formulating guidelines to be used in assessing Commonwealth benefit claims in compensation cases. Although the Department has received legal opinions, it is considered inappropriate to publish such opinions furnished by the Government's legal advisers. My Department is willing to explain to persons affected by the operation of section 18 the reasons behind the Department's decision in such cases, but the basic reason is to avoid the Commonwealth or insurers with registered medical benefits funds having to meet medical expenses for which third parties have a legal liability.

(4) As indicated in (1) and (3) above, if people are eligible to receive payment by way of compensation or damages under the Workers' Compensation Act of a State or Territory (or other eligibility) in respect of professional medical services related to an injury or disease, Commonwealth Medical Benefits may not be payable under section 18 of the Health Insurance Act. In other circumstances, provided the person has eligibility for Commonwealth Medical Benefits and/or fund benefit through being in possession of a Pensioner Health Benefits card or Health Care card or being enrolled in a registered health fund, medical benefits will be payable for services, provided they fall within the ambit of the Medical Benefits Schedule.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have total appropriations for the Family Planning Program grown from my initial grant as Minister for Health of $750 000 to $837 962 in 1980-81 including approved carry over of $57 962 unexpended from 1979-80.
(2) What were the increases or decreases in real terms during the lifetime of each government concerned.

(3) Are clinical services under the program funded (a) on a no growth in health services policy so that clinics and services cannot be expanded and (b) on a deficit basis so that self-help fund raising has negative effects except to reduce government contributions.
(4) Do clinic attendances reflect this policy despite growing demands.

(5) Do health services in Western Australia perform sterilising operations and use Depo-Provera injections for illiterate patients without ensuring that patients (a) are aware of the risks and implications and (b) have full opportunity to be trained in the use of alternatives by adequate employment of persons of their own language and culture.

(6) Has his Department monitored the performance of subsidised family planning in providing adequate access for Aborigines to the services as required by my original conditions of approval of the program.
(7) Does Australia subscribe to World Health Organisation and United Nations principles which provide that all parents should have the right to choose the number and spacing of their children.

(8) Is he able to state whether evidence anywhere in the world suggested that a dearth of family planning information increases rates of (a) abortions, (b) unwanted birth, (c) child abuse or (d) problems of health, family and social adjustment, education and employment, at greater cost to society than the alternative of more adequate family planning.

(9) Is the result consistent with the Government's budgetary strategy of reducing public spending, or is this consideration outweighed by the aim of increasing births to Australians whose access to family planning information is limited by the strategy.
(10) Have family planning organisations been advised that they may expand services only if they can prove that this expansion is financed by improved management of money and resources.

(11) What Government examples or assistance have been given to improve management, evaluation, monitoring, assessment and peer review in (a) subsidised health services and (b) government health services.
(12) What Government or private services provide the smear tests, pregnancy tests, supplies, counselling and services available at family planning centres but more cheaply.
(13) What steps have been taken to implement the 1979 recommendation of the National Women's Advisory Council to provide health services to women in workplaces.
(14) What encouragement has been given to public outpatients' departments to provide adequate family planning (a) advice and (b) supplies to (i) all who seek them and (ii) all who need them.

(15) Is the only public hospital family planning clinic in Queensland (a) a half day weekly at Royal Brisbane Hospital for referred hospital patients only and (b) providing a very limited range of services; if so, will appropriate adjustments be made to Commonwealth grants to Queensland.

(16) Is adequate training for family doctors in family planning available only within the Program and restricted to present levels with the result that Australia's general practitioners cannot extend their formal training in this field.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Family Planning Program appropriations since 1972-73 were as follows:

The honourable member refers to an approved carry over of $57 962 unexpended from 1979-80 allocations. Included in this amount was a sum of $36 432 which was , in fact, a carry over relating to revised accounting procedures, in the case of one Family Planning Association, for Health Program Grant payments and payments from the Family Planning Program.

(2) Two statistical series have been used to 'deflate' the annual appropriations for the Family Planning Program from 1972-73 to 1980-81 using the 'Average Weekly Earnings' and 'Gross Fixed Capital Expenditure-Public' as a basis for the calculations. Accordingly, the pattern of appropriations for the Family Planning Program is as follows:
*This estimate assumes a 10 per cent increase in Average Weekly Earnings over 1979-80.

Any appreciation of the Family Planning Program, however, must recognise that by far the major element of patient education in this area is through the ongoing activities of medical practitioners, particularly general practitioners, throughout Australia, and in the course of the clinical programs of the Family Planning Associations which, as indicated in respect of question (3), have been funded separately through Health Program Grants.

(3) (a) and (b) Clinical services are funded under Health Program Grants. These grants have been subject to a no growth policy since 1976. However, some minor expansion in clinical activity has been approved and funded where special justification has been demonstrated.

The basic approach to the funding of clinical activities of Family Planning Associations under the Health Program Grant arrangements is one of deficit funding; income generated by the Associations' clinical activities (sale of contraceptives, health insurance payments, etc.) is deducted from the amount of grant payable. However, the Health Program Grants for associations have provided a considerably higher level of funding than would be received from bulk billing for eligible patients under the Health Insurance Act.

(4) Although Health Program Grants arrangements are operating under a 'limited funding' policy, trends in all States imply an increasing number of clinical attendances. For example, in the honourable member's own State of Queensland the details are as follows:

(5) (a) and (b) No. The State health services in Western Australia advise that they do not perform sterilising operations without full counselling of the concerned parties by such persons as hospital staff, community health workers, Aboriginal health workers, and health workers from other ethnic groups. The operations are then only proceeded with if they are both warranted and wanted.

In relation to Depo-Provera injections, this drug is still considered to be investigational, and is not generally available as a contraceptive. Where it is used in individual cases, there is a responsibility on the part of the doctor to adequately inform the patient or the guardian, of any possible adverse consequences of the therapy. Aboriginal and migrant women, like any other Australian women, should have access to Depo-Provera where its use is considered to be in the best interest of the individual patient.

Aboriginal health workers and health workers from other ethnic groups are trained and employed by the Western Australian Public Health Department to assist in the delivery of health care to their own people, including the interpretation of language and culture in the sets of circumstances referred to.

(6) Since the introduction of Health Program Grants for Aboriginal Medical Services (AMS), family planning for Aboriginals has been integrated with the health services provided by AMS. Consequently, there has been no specific monitoring of the family planning services provided by AMS. Family Planning Associations co-operate wherever possible in training resource personnel working with Aboriginals, and the education and information programs the Associations conduct are available to the general community.

(8) (a), (b), (c) and (d) There is evidence that a comprehensive family planning education program can be an important factor in reducing the number of unwanted births and abortions. Other social factors, such as education and social status of women, are also involved, It is reasonable to assume that a decline in the birth rate represents a decline primarily in unwanted and unplanned births. There is evidence that 'unwantedness' is one factor in the aetiology of child abuse. There have been several studies in Australia and overseas which have shown that there are cost-benefits, through family planning programs, in medical and social health terms.

(9) In Australia, most family planning advice is provided by general practitioners in the course of day-to-day consultations. However, the Family Planning Program seeks to improve the level of community awareness and the quality of family planning advice generally, including that given by Family Planning Associations, private medical practitioners, and natural family planning organisations. Through the Family Planning Program, the overall policy of the Government is to provide better methods of dissemination of family planning information to both men and women.

This has been demonstrated by the fact that, notwithstanding the government's economic strategy of continuing financial restraint, it was possible to increase the amount provided under both the Family Planning Program and Health Program Grant arrangements to enable, broadly, the continuation of existing levels of activities during 1980-81.
(11) I assume that the honourable member is referring to subsidised and government family planning services.

(a) State and Territory Family Planning Associations conduct internal peer reviews of their clinical staff and evaluation of their training programs. In 1975-76, a comprehensive review of the teaching and practice of natural family planning methods was funded under the Family Planning Program. In 1979-80, a survey of characteristics of clients attending Family Planning Association clinics and the Adolescent Counselling, Treatment and Information (ACTION) Centre, Melbourne, was carried out by the Australian Federation of Family Planning Associations, with funding from the Family Planning Program.
(b) The Commonwealth Government has no direct responsibility for providing family planning services.

(12) Smear tests, i.e. the cytological examination of smears for evidence of pathological change, are referred by Family Planning Associations to government or private laboratories equipped to perform this specialised work. Most of such referrals would be to the various State Government cytology laboratories which are established for this purpose. In the Australian Capital Territory and Northern Territory, cytology laboratory services are provided by the Capital Territory Health Commission and the Northern Territory Health Department, respectively.

Similarly, pregnancy tests are available from State, Commonwealth and private pathology laboratories: urine specimens would generally be referred to such laboratories for initial or confirmatory testing.
Supplies and counselling services are not provided at Commonwealth laboratories .

No direct cost comparisons are available. However, for privately insured patients, Family Planning Associations charge the Schedule fee for these services. Costs for patients such as pensioners and their dependants, and people in special need, are met under the Health Program Grant.
My Department is concerned that these costs are more than if the Family Planning Associations bulk-billed the Department. This matter is currently under review.

(13) In 1979-80 and 1980-81, a Family Planning Program grant of $10,000 and $20 ,000 respectively, was allocated to Action for Family Planning, a Melbourne- based organisation which provides family planning information and education services specifically to migrant women at their places of work. The provision of education and information services by Family Planning Associations, at the work place, varies from State to State.

(14) The provision of hospital services is the responsibility of State and Territory Governments and arrangements vary. However, I understand that the major public hospitals provide outpatient family planning clinics, mainly for patients confined in those hospitals. In some hospitals, clinics are run by Family Planning Association staff, as required, while in others, family planning is integrated into general medical and gynaecology outpatient services where these exist.
(15) (a)Yes. However, the range of services provided at the hospital concerned is primarily a matter for the Queensland Government.

(b) The needs of the Queensland Family Planning Association will be considered carefully, together with other requests for financial assistance under the Family Planning Program made by other organisations.

(16) The Royal Australian College of General Practitioners has, since 1975, endorsed a policy of recognition and support for Family Planning Associations. The College's Family Medicine Program, funded by the Commonwealth under the Community Health Program, has worked closely with Family Planning Associations in each State and Territory in conducting training courses in family planning for general practitioners and medical undergraduates.

University postgraduate medical education programs include segments on family planning, in co-ordination with family planning and specialist organisations. Restrictions on the level of support for training programs funded under the Family Planning Program must be seen in the context of the general constraint on Commonwealth Government expenditures.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When did his Department learn of the discovery in New Zealand of the infection in pigs, which could have been foot and mouth disease.
(2) When and what decisions were made by him and his Department immediately on receipt of this information and to whom were these decisions advised.
(3) Was the Australian High Commission in Wellington advised of these decisions ; if so, when.

(4) What was the reason for it being impossible for me to obtain any information from the High Commission in Wellington on Friday, 13 February 1981, 24 hours after the public announcement of the infection by the Deputy Prime Minister of New Zealand and three days after actual discovery of the infection.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The first unconfirmed report of the suspected vesicular disease in New Zealand was received by officers of my Department at 10.30 am on 12 February 1981 Australian Eastern Time (AET).

(2) The Quarantine Division of my Department placed a telephone call to New Zealand authorities at 10.40 am (AET) to seek confirmation of the report. Telephone contact with Wellington was established at 11.13 am (AET) when the presence of the suspected vesicular disease was confirmed by the New Zealand authorities. Quarantine arrangements which Australia would implement forthwith were conveyed to the New Zealand authorities during the course of the telephone conversation. In summary, these arrangements covered measures to ensure that animals and animal products of concern would not enter Australia from New Zealand; upgrading of quarantine screening arrangements for passengers and baggage to levels equivalent to those in routine operation for passengers and baggage from FMD risk countries; quarantine of any New Zealand consignments received of animals or animal products pending identification and source of the infection in New Zealand. New Zealand authorities undertook not to certify animals (except cats and dogs) or animal products of concern for export to Australia until further notice.

At the conclusion of the telephone call at 11.30 am (AET), Chief Quarantine Officers (Animals) in all States and the Northern Territory were advised immediately by telephone with confirmation by telex. Telex advice was also sent to the Commonwealth Directors of Health in each State (Chief Quarantine Officers (General));the Department of Transport, The Bureau of Customs and Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Close liaison was maintained throughout with the Bureau of Animal Health.

All necessary quarantine precautionary measures were in place by 12.30 pm (AET) , that is, one hour after completion of the confirmatory call with New Zealand authorities. At Kingsford-Smith Airport, Sydney, these measures were in place at approximately 11.50 am (AET) (that is, approximately 20 minutes after confirmatory call).

It was essential for the initial media reports of the suspected disease outbreak to be confirmed with New Zealand authorities before Australian quarantine measures, with their substantial implications for both countries, were implemented. In previous months simulated foot and mouth disease exercises in both Australia and New Zealand had been incorrectly reported by sections of the media as actual outbreaks.

(3) Advice of the suspected outbreak was first made public in New Zealand at 0930 New Zealand time on 12 February by way of a statement by the New Zealand Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries. The Australian High Commission in New Zealand advises that, after obtaining a copy of the press release, officers in the High Commission contacted the Department of Trade and Resources, the Bureau of Animal Health and the Department of Health on 12 and 13 February to confirm that the relevant authorities in Australia were aware of the suspected outbreak, to inquire about what steps were being taken by the Australian authorities and to seek press guidance. The steps being taken by Australia were confirmed by cable despatched to the High Commission by the Department of Health on 13 February.

(4) The High Commission in New Zealand has advised that it has no record of any contact with the honourable member on this matter, nor can any officer recollect such contact. The High Commission's information section, after telephone contact with Canberra, informed all callers that there had been a temporary halt to all imports of meat and meat products from New Zealand into Australia and that this would last until such time as the matter had been resolved.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Have systematic evaluations of the effectiveness of quarantine screening procedures applied to postal packets from overseas been carried out as recommended in the Report entitled Review of Australian Quarantine Arrangements prepared by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in 1976; if so, what were the results of the evaluations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Present quarantine screening procedures for postal articles are based on the declarations of senders; on the experience and intuition of screening officers and on other information which becomes available from time to time. Bearing in mind the large volumes of postal articles involved and other measures in operation, these arrangements are regarded as a cost-effective method of quarantine screening for these items. All practical measures are taken to screen out illegal and dangerous imports.

Following receipt of the Report referred to, screening procedures were reviewed . Whilst it would have been difficult and costly to fully implement the recommendation, action was nonetheless taken to amend the relevant legislation to increase penalties. Further, a major public awareness campaign was developed. It was felt that action envisaged in the Report would not necessarily lead to improved quarantine security particularly in view of the large volume of unsolicited material reaching Australia and the large numbers of recipients of postal articles.

In practical terms it is considered that the most effective way in which quarantine screening arrangements can be enhanced is by the development of a well informed responsible and co-operative Australian public. The current quarantine publicity campaign has this as its major objective.

This campaign and the increasing penalties for quarantine infringements introduced in 1979 are positive elements of the total approach to this and other problems of quarantine security. Information received from recipients of unsolicited articles of possible quarantine concern from overseas consignors is used as a basis for ongoing review of the intelligence base available for screening officers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many (a) primates, (b) dogs, (c) cats, (d) horses, (e) rodents and (f) other animals were used in experiments during the last year for which figures are available.
(2) How many of these experiments were for (a) medical and (b) non-medical purposes.

(3) Were any animals (a) subjected to electric shock, (b) deliberately deprived of an adequate diet, (c) kept in conditions which did not allow them to satisfy their natural behavioural needs or (d) subjected to any painful procedures while not fully anaesthetised, in any of the experiments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The only figures available are those relating to Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, Commonwealth Institute of Health and the Australian Capital Territory (which includes the number of animals used by the National Biological Standards Laboratory). The figures for these areas are:
In 1980 the numbers of animals issued from the breeding units at Commonwealth Serum Laboratories to specific user laboratories was as follows:
primates 25 dogs 196 cats 23 horses 1 rodents 140,900 other animals 208
The only animals used in research in 1980 were 164 mice and 11 rabbits.
primates 5 dogs (dingoes) 8 cats 373 horses nil rodents 93,891 other animals 10,275
(2) All the experiments at Commonwealth Serum Laboratories and the Commonwealth Institute of Health were for medical purposes.
In the Australian Capital Territory 86,272 animals were used for medical purposes and 18,280 for non-medical purposes.

(3) (a), (b), (c) and (d) In regard to Commonwealth Serum Laboratories and the Commonwealth Institute of Health the answers are no except that some experimental procedures are carried out without anaesthetic where there may be only trivial pain, for example that caused by the giving of an injection or the taking of a sample of blood. In some experiments related to LD50 procedures anaesthetic would not allow the end point of the tests to be determined.

(3) (a), (b), and (c) In regard to the Australian Capital Territory the answers are no. (d) No, except that in accordance with the conditions determined by the Minister for Health under the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Ordinance 1959, with which authorised persons performing vivisections and experiments on animals must comply, it is permissible not to render an animal completely insensible to pain only in circumstances where insensibility cannot be produced without frustrating the object of the experiment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 12 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the reasons underlying the Government's decision to cease the regular collection and publication of Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) statistics on unemployment and vacancies (Hansard, 30 April 1981, page 1844).
(2) Does this decision mean that his Department's Monthly Review of the Employment Situation will (a) be no longer published or (b) be published irregularly.

(3) Will offices of the CES continue to collect unemployment and vacancy data relating to their local labour market area and prepare consolidations on a regular monthly basis; if not, on what basis will the activities be conducted.

(4) Will monthly consolidations of labour market data at a (a) State level and (b) national level still be prepared within the CES; if not, will his Department continue to undertake consolidations on an irregular basis.

(5) Does his Department intend to continue using CES labour market statistics for internal management decision-making purposes; if not, how does his Department intend to monitor and assess the business performance of its CES offices.

(6) Will CES labour market data at any level of consolidation be available for public scrutiny; if so, what data will be available, and what groups or individuals outside his Department will have access to these data.
(7) Will there be any staff savings within the CES as a result of the Government's decision; if so, what is the likely magnitude of these savings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The decision to discontinue the collection and publication of the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) series of registered unemployed and unfilled vacancy statistics was based on an examination of the costs and benefits of continued collection of these statistics.

The statistics were not required for CES management purposes and have been shown to lack validity as labour market indicators. The reports of the Advisory Committee CES Statistics (1973), the OECD Review of Manpower Policy (1975) and the Review of the Commonwealth Employment Service (1977) each expressed concern about the adequacy of CES statistics for purposes of labour market analysis.
(2) The Monthly Review of the Employment Situation will no longer be published.
(3) Statistics will continue to be collected, on a regular basis of transaction series which reflect the workload of the CES.

(5) CES 'stock' figures of unemployed awaiting placement and unfilled vacancies are not required for management purposes and their collection ceased as from the date of the decision to implement the recommendations of the Review of Commonwealth Functions. Data on CES transactions, which are essential management tools to monitor and assess the business performance of CES offices, will continue to be collected as in (3) above.
(6) Data relating to the operations and performance of the CES will continue to be published in the Annual Report of the CES. Other forms of release, and their frequency, are presently under review.
(7) Yes. It has been estimated that staff savings of the order of 50 will be made from the decision.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 3 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the National Acoustic Laboratories' role with respect to the identification of significantly hearing-impaired infants in the Australian community.
(2) What is the present average waiting time for pensioner clients seeking NAL aids.
(3) What is the average number of visits actually provided for pensioner clients, including follow-up visits, hearing aid orientation, aural rehabilitation and so on.

(4) What is the cost of each NAL aid dispensed including (a) all salaries and related costs, including superannuation, (b) payment of clinical and related developmental personnel and (c) the provision and maintenance of clinical and support facilities.
(5) Is he able to provide a reliable figure of confirmed usage rate of NAL aids with the number of aids issued.
(6) How many aids are issued by NAL.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The National Acoustic Laboratories' (NAL) role in the identification of significantly hearing impaired infants is to provide testing and other evaluations, including ear nose and throat Specialist examination, of referred children suspected of being hearing impaired. Referral is accepted from any source which has reason to suspect a hearing impairment in the infant. This includes parents, medical practitioners and the State health authorities. NAL encourages early identification and referral, and provides statistical coverage of achievement. Further, NAL has devised and/or developed for local use, most of the test techniques in use in evaluating infants in Australia.
(2) The estimated average waiting time for individual pensioner clients at the end of September 1981 was 6 months.

(3) Average number of visits per pensioner fitted including new and replacement fittings, during the year ended 30 June 1981, for testing, fitting, follow-up, and orientation, rehabilitation and aftercare was 3.25.

(4) The cost of each NAL aid dispensed is $219.58. This is the latest available figure as determined by a cost survey over the period July to December 1979 the results of which are shown below. All costs relative to the manufacture, issue and repair of aids were included in the survey as well as those costs specified by the honourable member, namely, all salaries and related costs including superannuation, payment of clinical and related development personnel and the provision and maintenance of clinical and support facilities.
$ Manufacturing 57.11 Research and Development 10.86 Fitting 53.24 After Care 34.56 Earmould 8.50
Total cost to supply and fit 164.27

(5) The most recent figures on hearing aid use by adults in Australia appear in the Australian Bureau of Statistics 1978 Survey entitled 'Hearing and the use of hearing aids (persons aged 15 or more).' This survey showed aid use rates as at September 1978.

A use rate of more than four hours per day by elderly clients is regarded as a very successful fitting, one of less than once a week as unsuccessful. The following figures, quoted as percentages of total persons with aids, show NAL distribution use rates.
More than 8 hours a day 25.7% 4-8 hours a day 29.3% More than once a week but less than 4 hours a day 22.6% Less than once a week 9.4% Never use 12.7% Total persons with NAL hearing aids 77,800
NAL now has an estimated 105,000 adult persons with hearing aids.
(6) Total number of hearing aids issued by NAL for the 12 months to 30 June 1981 were as follows:
New children 1,800 Replacements to children 3,485 New adults 24,593 Replacements to adults 11,579
From 1976 to 1981 (inclusive) a total of 172,798 new and replacement hearing aids have been issued.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 4 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What steps are being taken to limit animal experimentation in Australia to genuine medical and scientific purposes only.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Other than in the Australian Capital Territory it is the responsibility of each State or Territory Government to ensure that research involving animals is conducted strictly in accordance with its legislation.

So far as the Australian Capital Territory is concerned, all animal experiments are controlled under the Australian Capital Territory Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Ordinance 1959 and may be performed only for genuine medical and scientific purposes. Vivisections or experiments on animals may only be performed in laboratories at the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, the Australian National University, the National Biological Standards Laboratory (NBSL) and in the Capital Territory Health Commission's hospitals in accordance with the conditions determined by the Minister under the Ordinance.

In addition, research involving animals, funded by the National Health and Medical Research Council or undertaken by Commonwealth organisations such as Commonwealth Serum Laboratories is conducted only for genuine scientific purposes including the development of standards for therapeutic goods for both human and veterinary use.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Primary Producers: Taxation Values for National Increase in Livestock

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the cost of allowing primary producers to adopt artificially low values for natural increase in their livestock under section 34 (1) (b) of the Income Tax Assessment Act for each year from 1975-76 and what is the estimated cost for 1980-81.
(2) How long has this or a similar provision existed in the Act.
(3) What is the reason for providing this allowance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The absence of statistics of the values used by primary producers in the valuation of natural increase in their livestock and information on the true value of natural increase makes it impossible to provide a reliable estimate of the cost involved. However, although adoption of higher values would result in increased income tax being payable in respect of income of the year in which the change in basis of valuation occurred, it would have little effect on the primary producers' tax liability in subsequent years.
(2) A provision of this kind was inserted in 1936.

(3) This provision was inserted into the law following a recommendation of the Royal Commission of Taxation, 1933-1934. Recognising the difficulty of determining the actual cost of natural increase, the Commission considered the adoption of uniform minimum values to be an appropriate course.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the estimated cost of 20 per cent prime cost depreciation allowance provided for most new plant and machinery used in primary production operations under section 57AH of the Income Tax Assessment Act for 1980-81 and the first full year of operation.
(2) What is the reason for providing this allowance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The cost of the 20 per cent prime cost depreciation allowance provided under section 57AH of the Income Tax Assessment Act was estimated at $20m in the first full year. It should be mentioned that the estimated revenue forgone took account of the change in the method of allowing depreciation whereby a full years' deduction at 20 per cent replaced the deduction that otherwise would have been allowed pro rata from the date of purchase of the asset. The allowance of accelerated depreciation does not confer greater deductions over the life of the asset than would otherwise have been allowed. There is, however, a cost in the sense that the concession confers on the taxpayer the equivalent of an interest- free loan resulting from the postponement of payment of income tax that, in the absence of the concession, would be payable at an earlier time. Estimates on this basis are not available.
(2) The allowance was introduced as part of a package of measures foreshadowed in the Prime Minister's 1980 Election Policy Speech to assist the long term stability of rural industries.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Primary Producers: Depreciation Allowance for Structural Improvements

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the cost of the 20 per cent depreciation allowance provided for structural improvements for the storage of grain, hay and fodder under section 57AE of the Income Tax Assessment Act for 1979-80 and what is the estimated cost for 1980-81.
(2) What is the reason for providing this allowance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The estimated revenue forgone in the first full year resulting from the 20 per cent prime cost depreciation allowance provided under section 57AE of the Income Tax Assessment Act was $6.0m. The allowance of accelerated depreciation does not confer greater deductions over the life of an asset. It does, however, have a cost to revenue in that it confers on the taxpayer the equivalent of an interest-free loan due to the postponement of payment of income tax. Estimates on this basis are not available.

(2) The allowance was introduced to encourage the construction of grain, hay and fodder storage facilities to ease the pressure of bulk grain facilities in years of heavy harvests and also to encourage the holding of hay and fodder reserves against the requirements of poor seasons.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Primary Producers: Cost of Allowing Spreading of Income

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the cost of allowing a 5 year spreading of assessment in (a) insurance recoveries for the loss of timber or livestock provided under section 26B of the Income Tax Assessment Act; (b) income from forced disposal of livestock under sub-sections 36 (3)-(7), and (c) income from the compulsory destruction of livestock under section 36AA, for each year from 1975-76 and what is the estimated cost for 1980-81.
(2) How long have each of the provisions, or similar provisions, existed in the Act.
(3) What is the reason for providing each of these allowances.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The amounts of income deferred under section 26B, sub-sections 36 (3) to 36 (7) and section 36AA of the Income Tax Assessment Act are not tabulated and it is thus not possible to provide estimates of the revenue forgone through the operation of these sections.
(2) (a) Section 26B first applied in the year of income ended 30 June 1952.
(b) Sub-section 36 (3) to (7) have been progressively introduced into the income tax law to meet differing circumstances since 1945.
(c) Section 36AA first applied to assessments in respect of income of the year of income ended 30 June 1961.

(3) (a) Before the introduction of section 26B it had been found in many instances that, where the whole amount of an insurance recovery was assessable in the year of receipt, the amount absorbed by taxation could mean that an insufficient sum remained to finance the restocking of the property. The inclusion of 20 per cent only of the amount in the year of receipt and 20 per cent in each of the next four succeeding years helps to overcome this difficulty .

(b) The election available under sub-sections 36 (3) to (7) serves a similar purpose in respect of the proceeds of a disposal of livestock to which the section refers as section 26B does in respect of an insurance recovery.
(c) Section 36AA also serves a similar purpose in respect of compensation or other amounts received as a result of the death or destruction of livestock due to disease.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Primary Producers: Cost of Income Averaging

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the cost of providing general income averaging to primary producers under sections 149 to 158 of the Income Tax Assessment Act for each year from 1975-76 and what is the estimated cost for 1980-81.
(2) What would be the cost of allowing taxpayers to opt out of the average system in years when it is to their benefit.
(3) How long have these or similar provisions existed in the Act.
(4) What is the reason for providing these provisions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Information on which to make reliable estimates of the effect on income tax revenue of the averaging provisions has only become available since the provisions took the form of a rebate in 1979-80 and 1980-81 was estimated at $ 180m and $215m respectively.
(2) There is no benefit to be gained by a taxpayer opting out of averaging because, since the introduction of the rebate system, averaging can only operate to benefit the taxpayer.

(3) From 1921 to 1937, income averaging applied to all taxpayers except companies. For the income year 1937-38 and all subsequent years, the general averaging provisions have applied only to individual primary producers.

(4) Primary production income is subject to a relatively high degree of fluctuation from year to year, largely because of sharp swings in seasonal and world market conditions. Fluctuating incomes, combined with progressive rates of tax, would normally result in excessive tax burdens in high income years which would not be off-set in times of low income. The averaging system is designed to ensure that, over a span of years, a primary producer does not pay any more tax than other taxpayers with the same average income.

(3) The allowance is restricted to expenditure on buildings situated at or adjacent to the area where the timber is felled. It recognises that the value of such buildings is related to the period of use of the timber stand and diminishes as the stand nears exhaustion.

(2) How long has this or a similar section existed in the Act.
(3) What is the reason for providing this allowance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Statistics that would enable the cost to income tax revenue of allowing deductions for losses carried forward for more than seven years to be measured are not available.
(2) Sections 80AA, 80AB and 80AC became part of the law in 1966.

(3) Primary production losses due to various industry-related factors, particularly drought, often persist beyond the normal seven year recoupment period to which taxpayers generally are limited. Primary producers subject to these limiting factors could be unreasonably restricted in fully recouping past losses. The absence of any limitation on the carry-forward of losses for primary production gives recognition to the tendency in that industry for long periods of loss to occur between periods of sometimes high incomes.

The amount of tax deferred, the effect of the deposits and withdrawals on the application of the averaging system and tax payable on the interest yielded by deposits are all matters that affect the cost of the scheme. Estimates that take account of all these factors are not available.
(3) The Income Equalization Deposits Scheme first applied in relation to the 1975-76 year of income. Before that a similar scheme in relation to Drought Bonds had applied from 1969.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Taxation: Deductions to Co-operative Companies for Bonuses, Interest or Dividends

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the cost of the deductions allowed to co-operative companies for amounts distributed to members as bonuses, interest or dividends provided under section 120 of the Income Tax Assessment Act for each year from 1975-76 and what is the estimated cost for 1980-81.
(2) How long has this or a similar provision existed in the Act.
(3) What is the reason for providing this allowance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Statistics that would enable an estimate to be made of the cost to revenue of allowing deductions to co-operative companies under section 120 of the Income Tax Assessment Act for amounts distributed to members as bonuses, interest or dividends are not available.

(3) Under the income tax law in force from 1915 until 1923 all companies were allowed a deduction for the amount of profits distributed as dividends to shareholders. In other words, companies were taxed only on the profits which they retained. In 1923, this deduction was discontinued and companies were taxed on the whole of the profits earned, irrespective of the amount distributed to shareholders. It was, however, accepted that this basis of taxation placed a heavy burden upon the many small co-operative societies and a return to the earlier basis was adopted for these bodies.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The revenue forgone in the years from 1975-76 to 1980-81 as a result of the deduction allowed under section 73A of the Income Tax Assessment Act for expenditure on scientific research were estimated as follows:

These amounts are not a measure of the total cost borne by the revenue in respect of expenditure on scientific research, since scientific research expenditure is in some cases not readily distinguishable from other business expenditures which are allowed as losses or outgoings necessarily incurred in carrying on a business for the purpose of gaining or producing assessable income . The figures relate to the deduction of capital expenditure allowable under section 73A but not the ordinary provisions of the income tax law. Revenue was also forgone to the extent that certain deductions for the cost of plant were allowed over shorter periods of time than would have been the case if the plant had been subject to depreciation allowance at normal rates.
(2) The deductions conferred by section 73A first applied for the income year ended 30 June 1946.
(3) The allowance recognises the relevance and importance of related scientific research in carrying on a business.
