ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Program of Aid for Disabled Persons

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jenkins Dr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 25 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the cost of an electronic cardiac pacemaker approximately $1000, and the cost of a replacement hip prosthesis, $500-$600.
(2) After 1 September 1981, will his Department contribute any of the cost of providing these appliances to patients who are (a) disadvantaged, (b) insured or (c) uninsured.
(3) Will health insurance organisations contribute any of the cost to the insured.
(4) Has he been advised of what action each of the State Governments intend to take or the cost of these appliances in their hospitals; if so, what are the details.
(5) Does the Program of Aid for Disabled Persons apply to these appliances; if so, under what circumstances.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. I understand that there are about four different types of electronic cardiac pacemakers used in Australia which range in price from around $1,500 to $2,500 each. I also understand that the most common type of replacement hip prosthesis costs about $200.

(2) Yes. Under the new health funding arrangements which were introduced on 1 July 1981 in all States other than South Australia and Tasmania, the Commonwealth provides an identifiable health grant within general revenue grants to the States in lieu of specific funding for public hospitals, the Community Health Program and the School Dental Scheme. The grants are calculated at the same level as the funding provided in 1980-81 plus 10 per cent less a share of the revenue that the States can reasonably be expected to raise by the application of appropriate inpatient and outpatient charges from 1 September 1981. To the extent that electronic cardiac pacemakers and replacement hip prostheses were provided by public hospitals under the cost sharing arrangements they are included in the base figure for the allocation of Commonwealth funds to the States under the new arrangements. For South Australia and Tasmania hospital cost sharing arrangements continue and Commonwealth payments include components for these services as provided by those States. The Government therefore continues to contribute towards the cost of these services for all States and the Northern Territory. All States will, under the new arrangements, be required to provide pensioners having Pensioner Health Benefit (PHB) entitlements and persons in special need (as defined) and the dependants of those people with public hospital services without charge. These would include surgically implanted prostheses.

(3) Specific benefits for cardiac pacemakers and hip prostheses are not provided from basic tables of insurance benefits. They may be provided from ancillary tables. The nature and extent of benefits provided from ancillary tables and, up to a point, the terms and conditions relating to such tables are usually determined by the organizations themselves. Most funds provide some level of ancillary benefits towards the cost of these items. In some cases such benefits are limited to surgery carried out in private hospitals.
(4) The information available to my Department on the proposed supply of medical and surgical aids and appliances generally under the new health arrangements from 1 September 1981, is as follows:
Victoria-In Victoria all registered inpatients of public hospitals will receive without charge all internal splints and prostheses; artificial, mechanical and electrical devices placed internally.
Queensland-Charges raised for prostheses in respect of private and intermediate patients.
New South Wales, South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania-Charges are not raised for surgical aids and appliances provided to inpatients and registered outpatients of recognised hospitals.
(5) Electronic cardiac pacemakers and replacement hip protheses are not available under the Program of Aids for Disabled People.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Miniser for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 26 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the Second Directive 68/151 on Co- ordination of Safeguards of the Council of the European Communities which has recently been implemented and has the force of law in the United Kingdom; if so, will he give urgent consideration to having these important and protective provisions inserted in the Companies Act.

(2) Will he have the following Article relating to the matters indicated included in his reply so that they may be available for the information of Members and interested persons and organisations: 6 (minimum capital), 7 (non- cash consideration), 10 (non-cash consideration-valuing assets), 11 (promoters), 15 (payment of dividends), 17 (serious loss of capital), 25 (authorisation of new share issues), 27 (non-cash consideration), 29 (pre-emptive rights to new share issues) and 35 (maintenance of capital).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I understand that the main object of the United Kingdom Companies Act 1980 was to implement the directive of the European Economic Community known as the Second Directive on Company Law Harmonization. (Second Council Directive 77/91 of December 13, 1976 on Co-ordination of Safeguards which, for the Protection of the Interests of Members and Others are Required by Member States of Companies within the Meaning of the Second Paragraph of Article 58 of the Treaty, in Respect of the Formation of Public Limited Liability Companies and the Maintenance and Alteration of their Capital, with a View to Making such Safeguards Equivalent.)

This Second Directive and the U.K. Companies Act 1980 contain provisions which I expect will be considered in due course by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities in its on-going assessment of proposed amendments to the initial legislation under the co-operative companies and securities scheme.

It is expected that the first series of substantive amendments to the co- operative scheme legislation will be included in the proposed Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1983. Current planning within the Ministerial Council is that a draft of this Bill will be exposed for public comment for about three months during the second half of 1982.
(2) As requested by the honourable member, the text of the articles he has referred to is as follows:

Second Council Directive 77/91 of December 13, 1976 On Co-ordination of Safeguards which, for the Protection of the Interests of Members and Others are Required by Member States of Companies within the Meaning of the Second Paragraph of Article 58 of the Treaty, in Respect of the Formation of Public Limited Liability Companies and the Maintenance and Alteration of their Capital, with a View to Making such Safeguards Equivalent.

Article 6 (Minimum Capital) 1. The laws of the Member States shall require that, in order that a company may be incorporated or obtain authorisation to commence business, a minimum capital shall be subscribed the amount of which shall be not less than 25,000 European units of account.

The European unit of account shall be that defined by Commission Decision 3289/ 75. The equivalent in national currency shall be calculated initially at the rate applicable on the date of adoption of this Directive.

2. If the equivalent of the European unit of account in national currency is altered so that the value of the minimum capital in national currency remains less than 22,500 European units of account for a period of one year, the Commission shall inform the Member State concerned that it must amend its legislation to comply with paragraph (1) within 12 months following the expiry of that period. However, the Member State may provide that the amended legislation shall not apply to companies already in existence until 18 months after its entry into force.

3. Every five years the Council, acting on a proposal from the Commission, shall examine and, if need be, revise the amounts expressed in this article in European units of account in the light of economic and monetary trends in the Community and of the tendency towards allowing only large and medium-sized undertakings to opt for the types of company listed in Article 1.
General Note Article 6 requires a major amendment of British company law which at present does not prescribe a minimum subscribed capital for any type of company.

Article 7 (Non-cash Consideration) The subscribed capital may be formed only of assets capable of economic assessment. However, an undertaking to perform work or supply services may not form part of these assets.

Article 10 (Non-cash Consideration-Valuing Assets) 1. A report on any consideration other than in cash shall be drawn up before the company is incorporated or is authorised to commence business, by one or more independent experts appointed or approved by an administrative or judicial authority. Such experts may be natural persons as well as legal persons and companies or firms under the laws of each Member State.

2. The experts' report shall contain at least a description of each of the assets comprising the consideration as well as of the methods of valuation used and shall state whether the values arrived at by the application of these methods correspond at least to the number and nominal value or, where there is no nominal value, to the accountable par and, where appropriate, to the premium on the shares to be issued for them.
3. The experts' report shall be published in the manner laid down by the laws of each Member State, in accordance with Article 3 of Directive 68/151.

4. Member States may decide not to apply this article where 90 per cent of the nominal value, or where there is no nominal value, of the accountable par, of all the shares is issued to one or more companies for a consideration other than in cash, and where the following requirements are met:
(a) with regard to the company in receipt of such consideration, the persons referred to in Article 3 (i) have agreed to dispense with the experts' report;
(b) such agreement has been published as provided for in paragraph (3);

(c) the companies furnishing such consideration have reserves which may not be distributed under the law or the statutes and which are at least equal to the nominal value or, where there is no nominal value, the accountable par of the shares issued for consideration other than in cash;

Article 11 (Promoters) 1. If, before the expiry of a time limit laid down by national law of at least two years from the time the company is incorporated or is authorised to commence business, the company acquires any asset belonging to a person or company or firm referred to in Article 3 (i) for a consideration of not less than one-tenth of the subscribed capital, the acquisition shall be examined and details of it published in the manner provided for in Article 10 and it shall be submitted for the approval of the general meeting.
Member States may also require these provisions to be applied when the assets belong to a shareholder or to any other person.

2. Paragraph (1) shall not apply to acquisitions effected in the normal course of the company's business, to acquisitions effected at the instance or under the supervision of an administrative or judicial authority, or to stock exchange acquisitions.

Article 15 (Payment of Dividends) 1. (a) Except for cases of reductions of subscribed capital, no distribution to shareholders may be made when on the closing date of the last financial year the net assets as set out in the company 's annual accounts are, or following such a distribution would become, lower than the amount of the subscribed capital plus those reserves which may not be distributed under the law or the statutes.

(b) Where the uncalled part of the subscribed capital is not included in the assets shown in the balance sheet, this amount shall be deducted from the amount of subscribed capital referred to in paragraph (a).

(c) The amount of a distribution to shareholders may not exceed the amount of the profits at the end of the last financial year plus any profits brought forward and sums drawn from reserves available for this purpose, less any losses brought forward and sums placed to reserve in accordance with the law or the statutes.
(d) The expression ''distribution'' used in sub-paragraphs (a) and (c) includes in particular the payment of dividends and of interest relating to shares.
2. When the laws of a Member State allow the payment of interim dividends, the following conditions at least shall apply:
(a) interim accounts shall be drawn up showing that the funds available for distribution are sufficient,

(b) the amount to be distributed may not exceed the total profits made since the end of the last financial year for which the annual accounts have been drawn up, plus any profits brought forward and sums drawn from reserves available for this purpose, less losses brought forward and sums to be placed to reserve pursuant to the requirements of the law or the statutes.
3. Paragraphs (1) and (2) shall not affect the provisions of the Member States as regards increases in subscribed capital by capitalisation of reserves.
4. The laws of a Member State may provide for derogations from paragraph (1) (a ) in the case of investment companies with fixed capital.
The expression 'investment company with fixed capital,' within the meaning of this paragraph means only those companies:

the exclusive object of which is to invest their funds in various stocks and shares, land or other assets with the sole aim of spreading investment risks and giving their shareholders the benefit of the results of the management of their assets, and
which offer their own shares for subscription by the public.
In so far as the laws of Member States make use of this option they shall:
(a) require such companies to include the expression 'investment company' in all documents indicated in Article 4 of Directive 68/151;

(b) not permit any such company whose net assets fall below the amount specified in paragraph (1) (a) to make a distribution to shareholders when on the closing date of the last financial year company's total assets as set out in the annual accounts are, or following such distribution would become, less than one-and-a-half times the amount of the company's total liabilities to creditors as set out in the annual accounts;
(c) require any such company which makes a distribution when its net assets fall below the amount specified in paragraph (1) (a) to include in its annual accounts a note to that effect.

Article 17 (Serious Loss of Capital) 1. In the case of a serious loss of the subscribed capital, a general meeting of shareholders must be called within the period laid down by the laws of the Member States, to consider whether the company should be wound up or any other measures taken.
2. The amount of a loss deemed to be serious within the meaning of paragraph 1 may not be set by laws of Member States at a figure higher than half the subscribed capital.
General Note Article 17, which follows German company law, requires again major change in British company law. This provision affords protection to shareholders and creditors and should be welcomed.

Article 25 (Authorisation of New Share Issues) 1. Any increase in capital must be decided upon by the general meeting. Both this decision and the increase in the subscribed capital shall be published in the manner laid down by the laws of each Member State, in accordance with Article 3 of Directive 68/151.

2. Nevertheless, the statutes or instrument of incorporation or the general meeting, the decision of which must be published in accordance with the rules referred to in paragraph (1), may authorise an increase in the subscribed capital up to a maximum amount which they shall fix with due regard for any maximum amount provided by law. Where appropriate, the increase in the subscribed capital shall be decided on within the limits of the amount fixed, by the company body empowered to do so. The power of such body in this respect shall be for a maximum period of five years and may be renewed one or more times by the general meeting, each time for a period not exceeding five years.

3. Where there are several classes of shares, the decision by the general meeting concerning the increase in capital referred to in paragraph (1) or the authorisation to increase the capital referred to in paragraph (2), shall be subject to a seperate vote at least for each class of shareholder whose rights are affected by the transaction.

4. This article shall apply to the issue of all securities which are convertible into shares or which carry the right to subscribe for shares, but not to the conversion of such securities, nor to the exercise of the right to subscribe.
General Note British, Irish and Netherlands law know the concept of the authorised capital but that concept in unknown in French and German law.

It would appear from Article 2 (c) that the system of the authorised capital will be allowed to be continued in the countries which at present adopt it but that an issue out of the authorised capital will require a resolution of the general meeting (Article 25 (1)) unless the increase falls under Article 25 (2). The five years limit in Article 25 (2) is taken from French and German law. The authority given by the general meeting to the directors to issue shares to the stated maximum amount can be renewed.

Article 27 (Non-cash Consideration) 1. Where shares are issued for a consideration other than cash in the course of an increase in the subscribed capital the consideration must be transferred in full within a period of five years from the decision to increase the subscribed capital.

2. The consideration referred to in paragraph (1) shall be the subject of a report drawn up before the increase in capital is made by one or more experts who are independent of the company and appointed or approved by an administrative or judicial authority. Such experts may be natural persons as will as legal persons and companies and firms under the laws of each Member State.

Article 10 (2) and (3) shall apply 3. Member States may decide not to apply paragraph (2) in the event of an increase in subscribed capital made in order to give effect to a merger or a public offer for the purchase or exchange of shares and to pay the shareholders of the company which is being absorbed or which is the object of the public offer for the the purchase or exchange of shares.

4. Member States may decide not to apply paragraph (2) if all the shares issued in the course of an increase in subscribed capital are issued for a consideration other than in cash to one or more companies, on condition that all the shareholders in the company which receive the consideration have agreed not to have an experts' report drawn up and that the requirements of Article 10 (4) (b) to (f) are met.

Article 29 (Pre-emptive Rights to New Share Issues) 1. Whenever the capital is increased by consideration in cash, the shares must be offered on a pre-emptive basis to shareholders in proportion to the capital represented by their shares.
2. The laws of a Member State:

(a) need not apply paragraph (1) above to shares which carry a limited right to participate in distributions within the meaning of Article 15 and/or in the company's assets in the event of liquidation; or

(b) may permit, where the subscribed capital of a company having several classes of shares carrying different rights with regard to voting, or participation in distributions within the meaning of Article 15 or in assets in the event of liquidation, is increased by issuing new shares in only one of these classes, the right of pre-emption of shareholders of the other classes to be exercised only after the exercise of this right by the shareholders of the class in which the new shares are being issued.

3. Any offer of subscription on a pre-emptive basis and the period within which this right must be exercised shall be published in the national gazette appointed in accordance with Directive 68/151. However, the laws of a Member State need not provide for such publication where all a company's shares are registered. In such case, all the company's shareholders must be informed in writing. The right of pre-emption must be exercised within a period which shall not be less than 14 days from the date of publication of the offer or from the date of dispatch of the letters to the shareholders.

4. The right of pre-emption may not be restricted or withdrawn by the statutes or instrument of incorporation. This may, however, be done by decision of the general meeting. The administrative or management body shall be required to present to such a meeting a written report indicating the reason for restriction or withdrawal of the right of pre-emption, and justifying the proposed issue price. The general meeting shall act in accordance with the rules for a quorum and a majority laid down in Article 40. Its decision shall be published in the manner laid down by the laws of each Member State, in accordance with Article 3 of Directive 68/151.

5. The laws of a Member State may provide that the statutes, the instrument of incorporation or the general meeting, acting in accordance with the rules for a quorum, a majority and publication set out in paragraph (4) may give the power to restrict or withdraw the right of pre-emption to the company body which is empowered to decide on an increase in subscribed capital within the limits of the authorised capital. This power may not be granted for a longer period than the power for which provision is made in Article 25 (2).

6. Paragraphs (1) to (5) shall apply to the issue of all securities which are convertible into shares or which carry the right to subscribe for shares, but not to the conversion of such securities, nor to the exercise of the right to subscribe.

7. The right of pre-emption is not excluded for the purposes of paragraphs (4) and (5) where, in accordance with the decision to increase the subscribed capital, shares are issued to banks or other financial institutions with a view to their being offered to shareholders of the company in accordance with paragraphs (1) and (3).

General Note Article 29 provides that, where on increase of capital there is a new issue of shares for cash, the existing shareholders shall, on principle, be given a pre-emptive right to acquire the new shares in proportion to their holdings. The directive attributes great importance to this pre-emptive right which, in the circumstances laid down in the article, will enable the shareholder to maintain his proportionate holding in the company if he so desires. Article 29 (2) (b) allows, in the circumstances stated therein, a first pre-emptive right to be given to shareholders of the class affected.

The right of pre-emption is derived from German company law which, however, does not restrict that right to issues for cash consideration. The rules of the London Stock Exchange require a right of pre-emption to be granted in the case of issues of shares of listed companies for cash consideration but allow dispensation with that right by a prior resolution of the general meeting.

Article 35 (Maintenance of Capital) Where the laws of a Member State authorise total or partial redemption of the subscribed capital without reduction of the latter, they shall at least require that the following conditions are observed:

(a) where the statutes or instrument of incorporation provide for redemption, the latter shall be decided on by the general meeting voting at least under the usual conditions of quorum and majority. Where the statutes or instrument of incorporation do not provide for redemption, the latter shall be decided upon by the general meeting acting at least under the conditions of quorum and majority laid down in Article 40. The decision must be published in the manner prescribed by the laws of each Member State, in accordance with Article 3 of Directive 68/ 151;
(b) only sums which are available for distribution within the meaning of Article 15 (1) may be used for redemption purposes;

(c) shareholders whose shares are redeemed shall retain their rights in the company, with the exception of their rights to the repayment of their investment and participation in the distribution of an initial dividend on unredeemed shares.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Have the member countries of the OECD been asked to make a decision concerning the proposed program for testing new chemicals according to the guidelines developed by the OECD; if so, has the Australian Government given consideration to its attitude to this program and the OECD guidelines and when will it make a decision on this matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In May of this year the OECD Council considered and adopted resolutions relating to three aspects of a harmonised international approach to management of hazardous chemicals. The resolutions concerned standard guidelines for testing of chemicals, principles of good laboratory practice for chemicals testing, and the mutual acceptance between OECD member countries of test data on chemicals. Australia abstained from voting in the Council on the resolution.

A fourth resolution has been framed, concerning the obtaining of a minimum pre- marketing set of data (MPD) adequate to allow an initial environmental assessment of a new chemical. This resolution has yet to come before OECD Council for consideration, pending agreement amongst member countries upon a common interpretation of the draft text.

The Commonwealth Government is giving consideration to its attitude to the specific resolutions which have followed from the work of the OECD Chemicals Program. Australia actively supports the objectives and work of this Program. However, it is the practice of the Commonwealth to consult State Governments in the process of establishing its position on international agreements which may impinge upon States' interests. This consultation has been initiated in respect of the OECD resolutions on hazardous chemicals. In due course the Government will advise the OECD Council of Australia's position on all four resolutions. Meanwhile, the Australian Environment Council's Interim Notification Scheme for new industrial chemicals, which commenced on 1 October, has been framed in a manner consistent with the OECD testing guidelines, principles of good laboratory practice and minimum pre-marketing set of data.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it estimated that there will be an inflow of foreign capital into Australia of between $7,000m and $8,000m in 1981-82; if so, will a high proportion of this sum be speculative capital over which the Government will have little control and no measure of its cumulative effect once it is within Australia.

(2) Has the Government deliberately abandoned the regular compilation of all statistics in this field, including the periodic surveys that played an important role in monitoring the levels of foreign ownership and control in Australia.
(3) Is any consistent collection of data being undertaken relating to foreign ownership and control within the many sectors of the Australian economy.

(4) Has the Government ceased the collection of statistical information relating to the level of (a) foreign investment in enterprises in Australia ( preliminary), (b) foreign ownership and control of (i) general insurance business, (ii) life insurance business, (iii) finance companies, (iv) mining industry, (v) accredited advertising agencies, (vi) tourist accommodation establishments and (vii) manufacturing industry and (c) foreign control in or of (i)manufacturing industry, study of large enterprise groups, (ii) mineral exploration, (iii) finance companies, (iv) life insurance business, (v) general insurance business, (vi) registered financial corporations, (vii) the mining industry and (d) research and experimental development-private enterprises.
(5) Has his attention been drawn to the concern of the Minister for Primary Industry over the high level of foreign ownership of rural holdings in Australia .

(6) Is he able to say whether there is a very high level of foreign ownership of capital city property development throughout Australia; if so, is he able to say what degree of foreign ownership is the result of a high level of speculative capital over the last 3 years.

(7) Will he take steps to have the compilation of these types of statistics re- introduced together with such periodic surveys as will provide an adequate basis to assess the impact of foreign ownership and control within Australia.

(8) In particular, will he take steps to reintroduce the collection of statistics of (a) the financial performance (profitability, etc.) of foreign- owned enterprises vis-a-vis Australian enterprises, (b) the extent of inter- corporate sales and purchases to determine the scope for transfer pricing, (c) the extent of workforce training programs undertaken by foreign enterprises, employment of apprentices, etc., (d) advertising by foreign enterprises, (e) local research and development expenditure by foreign enterprises, (f) royalty and licence fees paid by foreign enterprises, (g) property ownership by foreign interests, (h) productivity of foreign enterprises, (j) average wages paid by foreign enterprises and (k) reliance on foreign technology licences.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A net inflow of capital (whether public or private) to Australia of the order of $7,000-$8,000m in 1981-82 would be broadly consistent with the outlook for the balance of payments which was set out in the papers accompanying my 1981 -82 Budget Speech. It is not expected that a high, or even a significant, proportion of such a sum would be so-called 'speculative' capital, however the honourable member may define that term.

(2) No. Periodic surveys on foreign ownership and control by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) were discontinued in 1978, following an assessment of the relative priorities within the Bureau given available resources.

(3) and (4) The ABS collects and publishes a substantial amount of information on inflows and levels of foreign investment in enterprises in Australia. These data cover, in broad terms, the country of origin and the industry in which the investment is undertaken, as well as the magnitudes and forms of such investment . The ABS also regularly publishes balance of payments statistics which incorporate data on capital inflow. In addition to this information, the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) also compiles statistics on foreign investment proposals. These statistics are released on a quarterly and an annual basis and relate to the proposed activities and expenditure of foreign investors.

(5) I refer the honourable member to my response to his earlier question concerning the meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council on 3 August 1981. (House of Representatives, Daily Hansard, 13 October 1981, p. 1933)

(6) The Government is of the view that foreign interests should not engage in real estate investment that is of a speculative nature or that is intended purely for capital gain or investment income without accompanying benefits to Australia. Accordingly, proposed acquisitions of real estate of this nature are not approved. Information on foreign acquisitions of Australian urban real estate is contained in my press release of 16 November 1981 (No. 203). This press release, which places in some perspective the relative importance of the foreign investment that has occurred in Australian urban real estate in recent years, does not support the views which appear to be implicit in this part of the honourable member's question.

(7) and (8) There can clearly be value in having more statistical information on many subjects, including that of foreign investment in Australia. However, as the honourable member will be aware, in the interests of sound economic and financial management the Government has had to review very carefully all demands upon public expenditure, including the costs involved in the collection and dissemination of statistics.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Definition of Employment and Part Time Employment

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government considered any change to the definition of employment or part time employment or the method of classification of employees which would affect the interpretation of employment figures by changing the significance or proportion of part time employment in official figures.

(2) When public statements on employment changes are made by Ministers, will he ensure that changes in full time job equivalents are also given, or that supplementary figures for part time employment are also given, if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The Australian Statistician publishes the official statistics on employment . These statistics do not include any reference to 'full time job equivalents'.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Parliamentary Liaison Officers: Minister for Health

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McMahon Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: How many Parliamentary Liaison Officer positions have existed in the Minister's Department and each Statutory Authority under the Minister's jurisdiction in each State, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory for each year from 1970 to 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The number of Parliamentary Liaison Officers in the Department's Central Office has varied over the last ten years but for a considerable time has consisted of three positions the occupants of which perform Parliamentary Liaison duties on a part time basis.
Of the Statutory Authorities within the Health portfolio, the Capital Territory Health Commission has two officers engaged part time on Parliamentary Liaison matters.
Neither the Health Insurance Commission nor the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Commission has full time or part time staff appointed as Parliamentary Liaison Officers.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Parliamentary Liasion Officers: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McMahon Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice , on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: How many Parliamentary Liaison Officer positions have existed in the Minister's Department and each Statutory Authority under the Minister's jurisdiction in each State, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory for each year from 1970 to 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: There is no position in my Department formally designated as Parliamentary Liaison Officer. However, since 1978, one position at Clerk Class 5 level in the Parliamentary Services Section of the Department has been nominated to undertake the duties of Parliamentary Liaison Officer.
A position of Clerk Class 8 in the same Section also provides some assistance with these activities.

Similarly, although none of the Statutory Authorities for which I am responsible have positions designated to carry out such duties, at least one senior officer in each Authority acts as a contact point with the Parliamentary Services Section of the Department.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: In each of the Australian States and Territories, what are the prevailing tariffs charged per kilowatt hour for electricity of (a) domestic consumers, (b) light industrial consumers, (c) heavy industrial consumers, (d) Government Departments and instrumentalities, (e) schools and (f) hospitals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The determination of electricity tariffs is the responsibility of State governments and the relevant authorities responsible for generation and/or distribution of electricity within each State.

Each State distribution authority publishes comprehensive tariff schedules defining charges for supply to each consumer class, and explaining conditions of supply including criteria for the application of tariffs in particular circumstances and tariff options available to consumers. This information is readily available from the various State and Territory authorities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the projected date for the opening of the National Art Gallery.

(2) Has the Gallery requested and obtained original art works from Australian embassies, Government departments, the Prime Minister's and the Governor-General 's residences, the Commonwealth Parliament building, Members of the House of Representatives and Senators' offices or any other public place.
(3) If so, has the Gallery encountered any resistance whatsoever from any of those persons to whom the request for art works has been made and, what is the reason for the resistance.
(4) How many art works are presently on loan to (a) Ministers' offices, (b) the offices of Parliamentary officers, (c) offices of Members of the House of Representatives and (d) Senators' offices.
(5) Do any of these art works include an original painting by Aboriginal artist Albert Namatjira.
(6) What security steps have been taken to protect these paintings.

(7) Is it the policy of the National Gallery that the Australian public should have the full benefit of the extensive cost of acquisition of the art works by having these works exhibited publicly in the new Gallery.
(8) Does his Department prefer that these works should be spread around private offices and overseas embassies rather than on public exhibition in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I am informed by the Australian National Gallery that:
(1) No day has yet been specified, but it is planned that the Australian National Gallery will open in October 1982.

(3) No resistance has been encountered. However, some reluctance has been experienced in arranging for the return of certain nominated works of art from overseas. These works of art have been in posts for a long period of time and have become an integral part of the decor of these posts.
Action is in train however and every assistance has been received from the Department of Foreign Affairs for their return at the earliest possible opportunity.
(b), 24; (Offices of the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives).
(c), 9; (Offices of the Rt Hon. Sir William McMahon and the Hon. the Leader of the Opposition).
(d), Nil; (Works of art on loan to Ministers are included under (a)).

(6) Works of art are lent by the Australian National Gallery only to locations where adequate security arrangements exist (e.g. Parliament House) and where environmental conditions (e.g. light, temperature and humidity) are regarded as satisfactory.

(8) The Gallery's collections comprise works of Australian art; the arts of Asia and South East Asia; primitive art; European art before 1850; art of the modern period-from 1850; prints, drawings and illustrated books from 1800; sculpture; decorative arts; and photography and film. From these collections only works of Australian art have ever been available for loan, and all items of importance have been or are being recalled for installation in the new Gallery.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sainsbury Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 23 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What arrangements have been made between the Capital Territory Health Commission and the Australian National University for the use of the Commission' s premises and facilities for the procurement, storage and use of whole, or parts of, human foetuses for pancreatic or other research.
(2) Is the Commission going to provide, or has it already provided, human foetuses or parts thereof, for the Australian National University, Dr Lafferty or any other organisation or individual.

(3) If the Commission is not involved, or will not be involved, in the provision of human foetuses or parts thereof for research, what steps does it take, or intend to take, to ensure that the foetal material to be used in its premises has been obtained legally, and in accordance with the highest ethical standards.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the regulations governing the disposal of garbage from ports and airports servicing international carriers.
(2) Is he satisfied that current regulations and their enforcement are sufficient to prevent the introduction of any exotic diseases into Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Disposal of quarantinable garbage at ports and airports servicing international carriers is regulated under the provisions of the Quarantine Act 1908 and Regulations.
Sections 29 and 44A of the Act provide that except as prescribed, the master of a vessel shall not permit the removal of goods including refuse, from his vessel .

The Quarantine (General) Regulations require, inter alia, the secure storage and appropriate treatment of refuse on board a vessel (regulations 33; 33B); prohibit the discharge of refuse into the waters of a port or onto a wharf ( regulation 33A); prohibit the removal of refuse from a vessel except by a person authorised by a Chief Quarantine Officer (regulations 33; 34) and require its disposal in a manner approved by the Chief Quarantine Officer (regulation 34).

For ports declared under the provisions of regulation 33C the master or owner of a vessel to which the regulation applies is required to make available for collection all animal waste, organic refuse, galley scraps or wastes from that vessel within a period of 24 hours of entering the port and at such other times as prescribed thereafter.

(2) No amount of regulation can guarantee that an outbreak of exotic disease will not occur. However, Australia's quarantine requirements are amongst the most stringent in the world and the Government requires that they be rigorously enforced and that all practical measures be taken to exclude exotic diseases from Australia.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Federal Police: Security at Parliament House, Canberra

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many members of the Australian Federal Police have been assigned to duty in or in respect of security at Parliament House, Canberra, in each sitting period during 1980 and 1981.
(2) What was the average overtime worked in each sitting week.
(3) Were additional police recruited for this duty; if not, in what other areas have duties been reduced to provide sufficient police for Parliament House duty.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In 1980, there were 55 Australian Federal Police (AFP) assigned each sitting week to duty at Parliament House for its protection. In 1981, this number was reduced to 47 (as from 10 March), when the internal security points at Parliament House were reassigned to members of the Parliament House Attendants staff. During September 1981, baggage search duties were transferred to Parliament House attendants, thus reducing the AFP commitment to 36.

These arrangements allowed a more efficient deployment of AFP members, including providing for a quick reaction by police patrolling Parliament House to any need from the internal security points or baggage checking areas.

(2) The average overtime worked in each sitting week during 1980 was 454 hours and during 1981 was 363 hours. With the reduction in staffing, rostered overtime per week now amounts to 120 hours during sitting periods and 40 hours during non -sitting periods.
(3) No. No other area has been reduced to provide staff for Parliament House.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which Australian cities have intensive care or coronary ambulances.
(2) Is it generally acccepted that these ambulances can and do save many lives in the immediate post-infarction period.
(3) How many of these ambulances are there in (a) Sydney, (b) Melbourne, (c) Hobart, (d) Newcastle, (e) Wollongong, (f) Adelaide, (g) Perth and (h) Canberra.
(4) If there are none in Canberra, what is the reason.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (3) Sydney, 9; Melbourne, 6; Hobart, Nil; Newcastle, 2; Wollongong, 1; Adelaide, Nil; Perth, Nil; Canberra, Nil.
In Adelaide, Hobart, Perth and Launceston, senior ambulance officers are trained to provide intensive and coronary care, and ambulances are fitted with defibrillators and cardiac monitors.

(2) Survival rates from cardiac infarctions are influenced by many factors, an important one being the length of delay before assistance is sought after the onset of symptoms. This factor is generally outside the direct control of health authorities. To date, the impact of coronary care ambulances has not been clearly isolated and quantified.

(4) The ACT ambulance service has one of the fastest response times of any service of this nature and has the advantage of a road system which enables ambulances directed to such calls to be very quickly at the point of need. Likewise it enables patients to rapidly be transferred to one of the major hospitals in a very short time. The ambulances are all well equipped and the staff have a developing and comprehensive program of continuing in-service training to maintain skills at a high level for all forms of trauma including that associated with heart attacks. Whilst the provision of a separate coronorary care ambulance has been considered from time to time it has been noted that it would involve a high capital and maintenance cost for this type of facility as well as the need for separate and additional crews of officers. As it would be stationed at only one location its response time to calls would in many cases be longer than the present method of directing the closest ambulance to the call and it is estimated that the longest trip to a hospital in the ACT is only likely to be nine minutes after resuscitation.

However, perhaps one of the most important factors which has had to be considered is that a population of around 225,000 is not sufficiently large to provide the level of workload necessary to maintain optimum skills in this specialised area. Finally, there is no evidence that a special intensive care ambulance would alter the outcome of coronary patients given the present excellent service available in the ACT, the level of its officer skill, the short travel time to major hospitals, and the likely level of demand for the specialised service.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962 provides that the Commonwealth is liable to pay pension in respect of an incapacity or death of a member of the forces whose incapacity or death has resulted from an occurrence that happened during his special service (including the contracting of a disease ) and also extends liability for any pre special service incapacity contributed to, or aggravated, by service.
(2) The Repatriation Act 1920 contains various liability provisions in respect of different periods of service and different kinds of qualifying service. These are summarised in the following table:

Persons who were enlisted or appointed for, or employed on active service outside Australia or employed on a ship of war or who were members of the Army Medical Corps Nursing Service who were accepted or appointed by the Director General of Medical Services for service outside Australia.
Incapacity or death which results or has resulted from any occurrence that happened during war service.
Persons who were enlisted or appointed for service in connection with naval or military preparations or operations.
Incapacity or death which results or has resulted from employment in connection with naval or military preparations or operations.
Persons who, after enlistment, served in camp in Australia for at least six months or embarked for active service overseas.

Incapacity or death which has been contributed to in any material degree, or has been aggravated by, the conditions of war service, notwithstanding that the origin of the cause of the death or incapacity existed prior to enlistment.
Members of the Forces who were employed on active service.
Incapacity or death which has resulted from any occurrence that happened during the period of enlistment.
All members of the Forces as defined in section 100 of the Act.
Incapacity or death which has arisen out of or is attributable to war service.
All members of the Forces as defined in section 100 of the Act.

Incapacity or death, deemed to have arisen out of service by being the result of an accident that happened to the member while travelling to or from place of employment on service or by being due to an accident that would not have occurred or a disease or infection that would not have been contracted but for being on war service or but for changes in environment consequent upon being on war service.
Members who, after enlistment, served in camp in Australia for at least six months or were employed on active service.

Incapacity or death which has been contributed to in any material degree or has been aggravated by the conditions of war service, notwithstanding that the origin of the cause of the death or incapacity existed prior to enlistment.
All members who were allotted for duty in an operational area as defined, or who were attached to a unit so allotted.
Incapacity or death which resulted from any occurrence that happened during war service.
A member of the Naval, Military or Air Forces of the Commonwealth.
Incapacitated or killed in any area outside Australia as the result of an action by an enemy or in combating an enemy.
All members who were allotted for duty in an operational area as defined or who were attached to a unit so allotted.

Incapacity which was contributed to in any material degree or has been aggravated by conditions of war service notwithstanding that the origin or cause of the incapacity or death existed prior to enlistment.
DEFENCE AND PEACEKEEPING SERVICERepatriation Act 1920, Section 107M (1).

(Excepting cases of earlier death or invalidity) Full time continuous service for at least three years as a member of the Defence Force, that period ending 1972; or, being a National Serviceman, immediately before 7 December 1972, completing, on or after that date, the period of service for which engaged or service with a Peacekeeping Force outside Australia as an Australian member, or a member of the Australian contingent of that Force.
Incapacity or death which has arisen out of or is attributable to Defence Service or Peacekeeping Service.

(Excepting cases of earlier death or invalidity) Full time continuous service for at least three years as a member of the Defence Force, that period ending 1972; or, being a National Serviceman, immediately before 7 December 1972, completing, on or after that date, the period of service for which engaged or service with a Peacekeeping Force outside Australia as an Australian member, or a member of the Australian contingent of that Force.

Incapacity or death deemed to have arisen out of Defence Service or Peacekeeping Service by being the result of an accident that happened to the member during travel to or from his place of employment on Defence Service or Peacekeeping Service or an accident, disease or infection that would not have occurred or been contracted but for being on Defence Service or Peacekeeping Service or but for changes of environment consequent on being on Defence Service or Peacekeeping Service.

Members of the Forces or Members of Peacekeeping Forces as described above who have served at least six months effective full time service as members of the Defence Force or members of a Peacekeeping Force.

Incapacity or death which resulted from a pre Defence or Peacekeeping Service incapacity, if contributed to in any material degree, or aggravated by the conditions of Defence, or Peacekeeping Service.
There is no present intention to amend the liability provisions relating to veterans covered by the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the sum of foreign money recently used to buy up Australian resources, industries, businesses and shareholdings.
(2) What is the estimated revenue which could be obtained annually if all such purchases had a 2 1/2 per cent sales tax applied to them.

(3) Will he give consideration to levying all foreign money inflow or outflow at a 2 1/2 per cent rate in lieu of the new 2 1/2 per cent sales tax on Australian consumers and will he consider making this levy retrospective.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: A tax on inflows and outflows of foreign capital along the lines proposed would reduce these flows and thus have an adverse effect on the rate at which Australian resources and industries were developed. This, in turn, would imply a lower growth rate of the economy and living standards would be lower. A substantial proportion of foreign capital flows represents the overseas borrowings and debt redemptions of Australian-owned enterprises; the tax would significantly increase the cost of these borrowings to the detriment of Australian enterprises. As the imposition of a tax on foreign capital would adversely affect foreign and Australian investors' perceptions of the potential for investment in Australia and seriously disrupt foreign capital inflows and outflows, a reliable estimate of the amount of revenue that might be collected from if could not be made.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Consumption and Sale of Beef in Australia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 21 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What functions is the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation carrying out under section 7 of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation Act to encourage and promote the consumption and sale of beef in Australia.
(2) What plans have been formulated by the Corporation under paragraph 7 (d) (i ) of the Act concerning quality standards and grading of beef.
(3) Is the Corporation exercising any powers under section 8 of the Act to improve the quality of Australian beef and the marketing of Australian beef in Australia.
(4) What directions has the Corporation given regarding the grades of beef that may be exported under section 11 of the Act.
(5) Does the Corporation have a different policy in respect of grades of beef for export and domestic consumption.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) has undertaken a number of steps to encourage and promote consumption and sales of beef in Australia as specified under the AMLC Act. It has regularly and frequently run advertising campaigns through the mass media in Australia to reach consumers and potential consumers of meat. The major media for these campaigns have been television and women's magazines. In addition, promotion through shows, exhibits , school programmes and other avenues which permit the distribution of printed matter, exhibition of film and video materials and other means of communication, have been organised. Publicity materials have also been supplied regularly, for use by print and audio/visual media in Australia, which deal with methods of buying and consuming meats.

(2) The Corporation from time to time recommends amendments to the Exports ( Meat) Regulations regarding quality, standards and grading of meat for export. For example, two recent recommendations have related to: (a) the creation of an Australian approved lamb brand to be applied to lamb carcases at slaughter in order to guarantee that product described as lamb is lamb and, (b) the creation of a special product description, 'Grainfed Beef', to meet Japanese market requirements for high quality beef and permit Australian producers and exporters to compete with USA high quality beef.

The Corporation is involved in commercial field testing of carcase classification proposals and if a satisfactory commercially acceptable system is developed, the Corporation would make recommendations on amendments to the Exports (Meat) Regulations.

The Corporation, in consultation with meat processors and exporter representatives, is currently reviewing the Exports (Meat) Regulations with a view to recommending to the Minister amendments considered to be commercially desirable.

(3) The Corporation has owned two cattle properties in Queensland for many years. These are utilised by the CSIRO and Queensland Department of Primary Industries for research into cattle breeding and nutrition.
The Corporation has also accepted managerial responsibility for the national Beef Recording Scheme (NBRS) which aims at production improvement by performance recording.

In addition, through involvement in the administration and joint membership of the Australian Meat Research Committee, the Corporation can influence the initiation and funding of research in various organisations. Much of this research is aimed at improving the quality and productive capacity of Australian livestock.

The Corporation is also encouraging the implementation of technology to improve the eating quality of beef, e.g., tenderstretch, electrical stimulation and ageing, through technical extension to meat producers and co-operation with other organisations.
(4) the Corporation has current directions in regard to qualities of beef that can be exported to:
A. European Economic Community-as high quality beef (Direction to Exporter DM 37)
B. Japan-as high quality beef (Direction to Exporter DM 42)

The Corporation is not involved in grading of beef for domestic use. This is a State function although at present no State grades beef for the domestic consumer. One State (Queensland) has had a consumer identification system for beef for several years.

(5) Gradings of beef for export are included in the Exports (Meat) Regulations administered by the Department of Primary Industry through the Bureau of Animal Health. Bone-in meat is required to be exported in accordance with these Regulations. Boneless meat does not have to be packaged in accordance with the grade of the carcase from which it was derived as boning techniques may alter the original grading determinant (e.g. fat cover).

The Corporation's policy regarding exports is that the buyer should receive product which complies with an agreed contract specification and it has issued a Direction (DM 13) to exporters covering this matter. The application of descriptive grades, First, Second, etc., can lead to marketing problems. What is first quality in some markets is totally unacceptable in others.

The Corporation favours the use of descriptions for domestic comsumer protection such as lamb branding and hogget branding. It is expected that this will extend into domestic beef which may be described as yearling, lotfed and electrically stimulated. The Corporation has recently agreed to jointly investigating and promoting such a system with the Queensland Meat Industry Organisation and Marketing Authority as a pilot study in 1982.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Meat Storage in Middle Eastern Countries

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 22 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do meat consumers in Middle Eastern countries have an ordering of preference giving first preference to freshly killed meat.
(2) On what basis has information been collected by him on an ordering of preference as to types of meat preparation.
(3) Is it a fact that most meat in Middle Eastern countries is consumed after first having been cooked for several hours with spices and vegetables.
(4) Is meat which is freshly killed and not used within 24 hours (a) thrown away or (b) stored in any way; if it is stored, what are the methods of storage or preservation.
(5) Is there evidence of increasing sophistication in the storage of meat in Middle Eastern countries.
(6) Which countries in the Middle East have refrigeration facilities in their cities at a level similar to cities in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) From a variety of sources including-
(a) Australian officials and Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation representatives either stationed in the region or visiting the region.
(b) official reports of Governments of the region.
(c) meat/livestock trade studies of the region.
(d) retail prices for different meats in Middle East markets.
(3) Some meats are prepared in this way. In other popular dishes a young animal may be baked whole or diced meat grilled as in a shish kebab.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say how many Australian subsidiaries of overseas corporations employed the technique known as above the line repatriation to remit profits to overseas parent companies in 1980-81.
(2) Is it a fact that the technique known as above the line repatriation of profits minimises the liability to Australian tax on profit remittances to non- resident parent companies.
(3) What rate of tax is payable by companies using above the line repatriation techniques.
(4) What was the tax revenue foregone in 1980-81 when above the line repatriation was used, rather than the alternative technique of remitting tax after income tax has been deducted in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) As the profits available for distribution as dividends could be reduced by the above-the-line payments, such payments might, in particular cases, tend to reduce dividend withholding tax received by Australia in respect of dividends paid to an overseas parent. If the Australian subsidiary is owned or controlled by a non-resident company, however, there would be little or no effect on the primary tax payable by the Australian company because any above-the-line payments are deductible in arriving at the subsidiary's taxable income only to the extent that they are on revenue account and do not exceed arm's length prices, or are otherwise allowable deductions under the income tax law. Moreover , to the extent that above-the-line payments constitute royalties, as defined for taxation purposes, they are taxable in the hands of the parent company at the rate of 46 per cent after deducting allowable expenses incurred in deriving the royalties.

(3) The normal company tax rate, 46 per cent of taxable income, is payable by Australian subsidiaries of overseas parents. Dividends remitted by an Australian company to overseas shareholders are, in the absence of an Agreement between Australia and the country of residence of the foreign shareholder, subject to withholding tax at the rate of 30 per cent of the gross dividends. However, dividend withholding tax is, as a general rule, limited to 15 per cent of gross dividends where the dividends are remitted to a resident of a country with which Australia has entered into a double taxation agreement. Interest remitted to a foreign lender attracts Australian withholding tax at the rate of 10 per cent of the gross amount.
(4) Statistics are not available of the tax value of such above-the-line payments as are allowable as deductions in determining the taxable incomes of subsidiaries of overseas companies.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 28 October 1981:

(2) If so, why was his Department's Rescue and Fire Fighting Service (RFFS) permitted to provide coverage for the Nigerian Prime Minister.

(3) If the RAAF Fire Service is incapable of providing adequate protection for all VIP flights, what representation has been made by the Regional Director to him in regard to recommending a 24-hour RFFS coverage at Canberra.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Responsibility for fire service coverage for RAAF VIP flights is a matter for the Department of Defence. By arrangement with the Department of Defence, my Department's Rescue and Fire Fighting Service provides coverage for military aircraft operations at Canberra during the times when it is on duty for civil aircraft operations, or shifts can be extended to do so. Outside these hours, the responsibility reverts to the Department of Defence for military aircraft movements.

(2) The flight carrying the Nigerian Prime Minister was made in a Nigerian Airways Boeing 707 and as such it was the responsibility of my Department's Rescue and Fire Fighting Service to provide coverage.

(3) A 24-hour coverage for Canberra Airport by my Department's Rescue and Fire Fighting Service has been considered, but there is no operational justification at this time to increase the hours of coverage.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Residual Links between the United Kingdom and Australian States

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the present state of negotiations between the Commonwealth and the respective State governments in regard to what the Attorney-General describes as the residual links between the United Kingdom and the Australian States.
(2) What States do not support the use of section 51 (xxxviii) of the Constitution for the purpose of terminating those residual links.

(3) Does the Attorney-General see the problems encountered by the Trudeau Government with the Kershaw Committee of the British House of Commons, serving as a lesson against Australian governments resolving problems of this kind by resorting to legislation enacted by the British Parliament.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answers to the honourable member's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Standing Committee of Attorneys-General has completed a report on residual constitutional links between Australia and the United Kingdom (other than the Crown). It was prepared in accordance with a request made in 1979 to the Standing Committee by the Premiers' Conference. The report will be considered by the Premiers' Conference at the first opportunity.
(2) This will be a matter for State Governments to declare when the report is considered by the Premiers' Conference.

(3) It is not proposed to comment on Canadian affairs. Also, there are important differences between the Canadian and Australian situations, and the same considerations do not necessarily apply in relation to the conditions under which Australian governments might be prepared to contemplate some role for United Kingdom legislation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 2707 (Hansard, 9 September 1981, page 1141) when will the Government introduce amending legislation to the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act.
(2) What will the new liability limits be and what are the general levels applying internationally at the present time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —the answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government expects to be in a position to introduce amending legislation in the near future. Consideration of the appropriate amendments to the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act 1959 are being treated as a matter of priority.

(2) As the various domestic liability levels that are embodied in the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act are currently under review by Government it is inappropriate to comment on proposed levels at this time.

International air carriers' liability limits for death or injury to passengers and for loss or damage to cargo and passenger baggage were established by the Warsaw Convention of 1929 and amended by the 1955 Hague Protocol to that Convention. Australia is a party to both treaties and the liability limits applying for carriage between Australia and a country which is a party to the Warsaw Convention are 125,000 Poincare gold francs per passenger, 250 Poincare gold francs per kilogram in the case of registered baggage and cargo, and 5,000 Poincare gold francs per passenger for cabin baggage. For carriage between Australia and a country which is a party to the Hague Protocol, the liability limit per passenger is 250,000 Poincare gold francs and the other limits are unchanged. However, since the abandonment of an official gold price, free market fluctuations in the price of gold have introduced a degree of uncertainty as to the present currency equivalents of these liability limits.
Accordingly, specified liability limits have been introduced on a voluntary basis by some airlines and on certain routes national governments have directed airlines to set a fixed limit.

Qantas has voluntarily accepted on all routes a limit of US$75,000 per passenger, inclusive of legal fees and costs, except that in case of a claim brought in a State where provision is made for separate award of legal fees and costs, the limit shall be the sum of US$58,000 exclusive of legal fees and costs .

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the high cost of pharmaceutical items related to the day-to-day control of diabetes and the enormous financial burden of the disease on those who suffer from it.

(2) In particular, is it a fact that diabetics must to a large extent be their own physicians, involving expensive Diabetic Association subscriptions to keep abreast of new developments in diabetic control, the purchase of expensive books , additional food and dietary expenses, extremely expensive blood and urine monitoring equipment for daily use, insulin and syringes for daily life support, constant doctors' visits and fees and expensive health insurance premiums, which do not cover most of these expenses.
(3) Is it also a fact that insulin is supplied under the National Health Scheme , but syringes, which are the only means of administering insulin, are not.

(4) Is it further a fact that insulin is classified as a specified drug and as such its distribution is strictly controlled and yet syringes, which are potentially extremely harmful and much sought after by drug abusers, are an over -the-counter item.
(5) In view of the difficulties facing diabetics will he ensure that syringes are made available in packages of 100 for the current cost of $2.75 under pharmaceutical benefits.
(6) Will diabetics be able to obtain syringes under the National Health Scheme; if so, when.
(7) Will he take action to have all blood testing reagent strips, which are used by diabetics up to 4 times per day, listed under pharmaceutical benefits.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The severity of diabetes, however, varies from case to case and some patients with diabetes do not have an enormous financial burden because of the disease.

(2) Most patients with diabetes would be under the continuing surveillance of their medical practitioners or would be receiving advice from an appropriate diabetic clinic, dietician and/or other medical or paramedical personnel. It is unlikely that the majority of diabetics are 'their own physicians'.

In regard to the honourable member's comment about expensive blood and urine monitoring equipment, there is some quite expensive equipment marketed to assist in the control of diabetes. I understand that there is also some Australian-made equipment, which is much cheaper, available on the market.
(3) Insulin is available on prescription under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme but syringes are not.

(4) Although insulin is available on prescription under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, insulin can be sold by pharmacists in all States and the Northern Territory 'over the counter' without a doctor's prescription. In the Australian Capital Territory insulin is available on prescription only. Syringes and needles are available 'over the counter'.

(5) and (6) Consideration has been given to ways and means by which Government assistance can be given in meeting the cost of syringes required by diabetics. The Government is sympathetic to the needs of diabetics and is mindful of the costs to the patient in the management of diabetes. However, the current economic situation has necessitated policies of restraint in public expenditure. In view of this, it is not possible for the Government to commit itself at the present time to additional programs, such as assistance with the cost of insulin syringes. Nevertheless this matter will be kept under review.

(7) Items are made available as pharmaceutical benefits only after a recommendation to that effect by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC). In accordance with a recommendation of the PBAC the two blood testing reagent strips most commonly used by diabetics in Australia are both currently listed as pharmaceutical benefits. The PBAC, which bases its advice on medical considerations, has not recommended that other blood-glucose reagent strips be made available as benefits.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that New Zealand deer farmers are launching a big campaign to market venison meat in Australia, beginning in November 1981.
(2) If so, has the Government explored the implications of this for Australian deer farmers.
(3) Will the Government act to protect Australian deer farmers by imposing tariffs of quotas on New Zealand venison.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I have no substantive information that New Zealand producers are to launch a major campaign to market venison meat in Australia.

(3) Venison is included in Schedule A of the New Zealand Australia Trade Agreement (NAFTA), according it duty free entry to both markets from either source. Any moves by either Government to introduce new import duties or restrictions on goods which are currently included on Schedule A of NAFTA would be inconsistent with the objective of a gradual and progressive liberalisation of trade across the Tasman. However, the principle of equality of trading opportunity is an essential element in the Government's present consideration of a possible new economic relationship with New Zealand. In this context, the impact of incentive schemes on trans-Tasman trade will be an important element in the Government's consideration of the final package of measures for a closer economic relationship.

Should assistance be provided to New Zealand exporters through Government incentives and subsidies, it would be consistent with NAFTA, and with the current proposals for closer economic relations, for the Australian deer industry to seek countervailing or anti-dumping action against imports of subsidised or dumped venison from New Zealand.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Transport: Public Relations Expenses

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
