ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The increase of expenditure from $150,420 to $200,000 for Public Relations expenses for 1981-82 relates to Public Information activity on behalf of the Department in a number of areas, including Coastal Surveillance, Safety at Sea and Small Boat Safety, Search and Rescue, National Highways and Airport Planning .

The estimate is based on the known requirement for public relations material to support departmental programs and projects. Public Information Campaigns have become more of a feature of departmental activity in recent years, including those related to general information, safety and to enviromental information programs such as those associated with airport developments. The substantial part of costs are related to the cost of supporting films, publications and displays.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that during the recent industrial dispute between Trans Australia Airlines and licensed aircraft maintenance engineers that occurred in the period 3 August 1981 to 11 August 1981 (a) aircraft continued to be operated by flight crew despite notification having been received by the airline from licensed aircraft maintenance engineers of other companies that the aircraft were unserviceable; (b) untrained persons and apprentices were utilised in an unsupervised manner in the maintenance of aircraft operators; (c) duties that would normally be the function of licensed aircraft maintenance engineers were carried out by staff members of the airline including assistant airport managers and persons who had no previous training in the movement of aircraft; and (d) loose pieces of paper were used to note defects of aircraft for crew change information rather than entering the details on the AMD 18 form as is the standard practice in normal situations.

(2) Is it also a fact that during the industrial dispute Trans Australia Airlines was permitted to declare bases that would normally be maintenance bases as non-maintenance bases including Mascot Airport which is the highest frequency airport in Australia for Trans Australia Airlines operations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Officers of my Department were not able to determine if this was so, however it is improbable that an engineer from another company could determine unserviceabilities on a Trans Australia Airlines aircraft. Department of Transport Airworthiness staff monitored Trans Australia Airlines performance at capital city airports including inspection of Maintenance Reports, AMD18's, and there was no evidence of carriage of unauthorised defects or of incorrect use of the Schedule of Permissible Unserviceabilities.

(b) Maintenance was performed by a number of experienced but unlicensed aircraft maintenance engineers as well as third and fourth year apprentices. This work was supervised and/or checked by a foreman who then certified to the maintenance as he is qualified to do.

(c) This matter relates to ground handling. There was an instance at Cairns where tarmac space was required and the flight crew taxied a DC9 under direction from the traffic department and the Assistant Airport Manager. In Sydney aircraft ground handling was carried out by foremen on tow vehicles with the Maintenance Supervisor in the cockpit as is permissible. In Brisbane an Assistant Airport Manager was used as a communicator to man the telephone in the foremen's office while the foremen were engaged on ground handling duties.

(d) Officers of my Department were unable to determine if this was so, however it was determined that defects were recorded by the aircrew in the normal manner in the Maintenance Report, AMD18. The only recorded defects that were cleared were those covered by the Schedule of Permissible Unserviceabilities and which did not require any physical labour to acquit.

(2) This is correct. The result of this was to make the flight crew responsible for pre-flight requirements as they are at non-maintenance bases. In view of the provisions of the approved system of maintenance for the aircraft, the action of Trans Australian Airlines in withdrawing ports from the listed locations for maintenance was of no safety significance in view of the limited maintenance capability at such ports. Officers of my Department are satisfied that when aircraft developed defects or required scheduled maintenance beyond the capacity of the particular base, they were removed from service.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, on notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With regard to the missing aircraft in Victoria chartered by German tourists, is he able to confirm that the Emergency Location Beacon on the missing aircraft was activated on, or after, impact.
(2) For what period of time would the ELB continue to emit a signal after being activated.

(3) Did the various search aircraft from his Department fitted with search meters fail to locate the missing aircraft through tracking the ELB signal because of the unavailability through maintenance checks.
(4) How many Department of Transport aircraft are fitted with search meters to enable aircraft ELBs to be located.
(5) What are the registered numbers and model type of the aircraft so fitted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is not possible to confirm that the emergency locator carried by the missing aircraft chartered by the German tourists, was in fact activated.
(2) Beacons are designed to operate for a minimum period of 48 hours.
(3) In the first instance all aircraft on the busy Melbourne-Canberra-Sydney routes and others in contact with the Melbourne centre were alerted to listen for a signal on the ELBA frequency.

No signals were heard by any aircraft other than the weak signal for a period of five minutes by the aircraft at low level enroute from Moorabbin to Tyabb. An Ansett Electra aircraft was diverted from its route near Eildon to carry our an aural search of the general area. This aircraft reported several fires, which were checked, but no ELBA signal was heard.

Homing procedures cannot commence until a signal is received. Consequently there was no requirement to supplement the already extensive listening coverage with a search meter equipped aircraft until a further signal could be identified .
(4) All departmental aircraft with the exception of one PA28 Cherokee aircraft based at Townsville are fitted with equipment which can be used in the search for ELBAs.

(5) F28-VH-ATE/D/G spectrum analysers which can be used in the search for ELBAs ; Merlin 3-VH-CAL/M search meters; Merlin 2B-VH-CAH/I/J/K search meters; Aero Commander-VH-CAX/Y search meters; Beech 35-VH-CAB/E/D/G search meters; Beech 36- VH-CAQ search meters.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Transport: Rental from Department Residences

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

I therefore would not expect changes in the level of receipts from rentals to relate directly to movements in the consumer price index.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there widespread opposition from amateur and professional small vessel mariners to the Government's program for the progressive demanning of lighthouses.
(2) If so, will he establish a Marine Advisory Committee to investigate the proposed automation and demanning of Australian lighthouses similar to the inquiry conducted in New Zealand recently.

(3) If he establishes a committee, will he ensure that (a) membership of the committee will include representatives of amateur and professional small vessel mariners as well as appropriate technical personnel; and (b) the committee conducts public hearings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware that some opposition has been voiced by some amateur and professional small boat mariners to the unmanning of some of the twelve lightstations in respect of which consideration is being given to unmanning.

(2) and (3) Detailed information is presently being obtained and examined concerning the implications of unmanning a number of lightstations. Until this exercise has progressed further, it would be premature to comment on the need for establishing such a committee.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Transfer of Division of Department of Transport to Canberra: Staff Morale

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How did he arrive at his conclusion stated in House of Representatives Estimates Committee D on 17 September 1981 that there are no morale problems within his Department.
(2) Has he spoken to Marine Standards Division officers and other officers of his Department in Melbourne or referred to letters written to him by those officers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I arrived at this conclusion firstly from discussions with senior officers of my Department, and secondly from appeals to the Grievance and Appeals Bureau of the Public Service Board from departmental officers during 1980-81. An analysis of those appeals shows that most are unrelated to morale as such, but go to matters relating to the functions of the Department.

(2) I have spoken to a number of officers whose Divisions are based in Melbourne and I appreciate that there are some officers who for a variety of reasons do not wish to transfer to Canberra. It is a matter of opinion, however, whether this could be called a morale problem.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Transfer of Division of Department of Transport to Canberra

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Marine Standards Division of his Department involved in major changes to legislation stemming from international conventions including amendments to the Navigation Act and Regulations, the introduction of Marine Orders and a new structure for certificates of competency.
(2) Are some of the changes referred to in part (1) to come into force on 1 January 1982 and others shortly thereafter.
(3) Have several technical staff already resigned because of the Melbourne- Canberra transfer and are others expected to refuse to move to Canberra.

(4) Is the implementation of Government policy regarding the changes referred to in part (1) made more difficult by (a) his Department's inability to fill all vacant positions and (b) the upheaval created by the transfer program.

(5) Will he, in the interests of the maritime industry, defer the transfer of Marine Standards Division officers who are still located in Melbourne until the changes referred to in part (1) are completed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The new provisions relating to seafarers' qualifications will come into force on 1 January 1982. Other provisions relating to international conventions will come into force progressively as subordinate legislation and administrative arrangements necessary to give effect to those Conventions are completed.

(3) A number of technical officers have left the Marine Standards Division over recent months. The reasons for persons taking other positions are not always clear, and I do not rule out the possibility that some departures have been due to the impending transfer of the Division to Canberra. As in all previous moves to Canberra, there will be some officers who will decline to transfer.

(4) I expect the changes to exacerbate some of the staffing and work load difficulties my Department has experienced in this area over a period of time, but not to an extent that will cause serious problems.

(5) I am convinced that the Marine Standards Division can provide an equally satisfactory service to industry from Canberra as it does from Melbourne, and that no good purpose would be served in deferring the transfer. I should point out that industry deals primarily through Regional Offices of the Department.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Transfer of Division of Department of Transport to Canberra

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to references in the Report of the Air Safety Investigation Branch Inquiry into the crash of the Advance Airlines aircraft VH- AAV that (a) the fuel nozzles of the failed left engine had been replaced on the morning of the crash and (b) post crash tests showed that only 3 of the 14 fuel nozzles met manufacturer's limitations.
(2) Is it a fact that the fuel nozzles were supplied by Ansett General Aviation of Bankstown.

(3) Is it also a fact that a member of the Board of Inquiry appointed to investigate the causes of the crash, Captain Peter Gibbes, M.V.O., D.F.C., A.F.C ., is a former long-term employee and Director of Operations of Ansett Airlines.
(4) Is he concerned that the tasks and conduct of the Board of Inquiry may be misconstrued by some members of the public if the answer to part (2) is in the affirmative; if not, why not.
(5) Does he propose to reconsider the appropriateness of Captain Gibbes' appointment to the Board of Inquiry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of the section of the report by the Air Safety Investigation Branch to which the honourable member refers. I am also aware that the soot contamination of some of the nozzles was concluded to have occurred subsequent to the impact.

(2) The nozzles were not supplied by Ansett General Aviation of Bankstown. They were, however, serviced by that organisation of behalf of Advance Airlines. I am advised that the records show that the nozzles were all in a fully serviceable condition at the time they were released back to Advance Airlines.

(3) Captain Gibbes retired from his position as Director of Operations of Ansett Airlines in 1975. Since 1977 he has served as a non-presidential member of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, an appointment which has recently been renewed for a further period of three years. He has a reputation and record as a man of the highest integrity.
(4) In all the circumstances, I do not consider that the tasks and conduct of the Board of Inquiry may be misconstrued by some members of the public.
(5) No. Captain Gibbes' appointment under Regulation 288 (3) of the Air Navigation Regulations is entirely appropriate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that there is a tax deduction for householders who insulate their homes on or after 1 October 1980; if so, does this deduction apply only to new homes.
(2) If this deduction applies to new homes only will he consider extending it to cover all homes insulated after that date as an incentive to energy conservation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) An income tax deduction is allowed for amounts paid by a resident taxpayer for thermal insulation materials, and for the cost of their installation in a dwelling, if the dwelling is the sole or principal residence of the taxpayer in Australia. A further condition is that the taxpayer or, in the case of married couples, the taxpayer or his or her spouse, has not previously owned another dwelling in Australia that he or she used as a home. For these purposes, a married couple includes persons living as husband and wife or on a bona fide domestic basis although not legally married.

It is not a condition of the deduction that the thermal insulation materials be installed in a new dwelling. Subject to the specified requirements, the deduction is allowable for the cost of insulating a dwelling purchased by the taxpayer on or after 1 October 1980 or, if a dwelling is constructed by the taxpayer, where the construction started on or after that date. Amounts paid for the insulation of extensions to dwellings qualify for the deduction under the specified conditions.

(2) The question of extending the concession to the cost of insulating all homes after 1 October 1981 has been considered. However, having regard to the other demands on the Budget it was decided not to depart in this respect from the announcement made by the Prime Minister before the 1980 election.

(2) Is he able to state whether the disparity between the UK and Australian funding levels is attributable to the failure of the Australian Research Grants Committee to index research grants for a sophistication factor, namely the factor which would enable the acquisition of microprocessor-controlled instrumentation to enable high quality data collection and analysis.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. It is not possible to make valid comparisons concerning support of chemical research based on Australian Research Grants funding alone. For example , the Project Score figures for 1976-77 show total expenditure of $6.845m on chemical research at Australian Universities of which approximately $1.5m was provided through Australian Research Grants.

(2) Where microprocessor-controlled instrumentation is necessary and justified for high quality research programs, then the Australian Research Grants Committee recommends that such equipment be awarded.

(2) What use is presently made of the unchartered areas.
(3) Is mapping of shipping routes to be undertaken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Survey Office has a program of work on the Great Barrier Reef for the Australian Institution of Marine Science and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Container Terminal at Mort Bay, New South Wales

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 27 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Government decided that the Department of Defence should acquire part or all of the property presently occupied by the Australian National Line container terminal at Mort Bay, New South Wales; if so, is he able to say for what purposes that Department will use the site.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Defence has a requirement for property in Sydney suitable for the establishment of a military port and a shore support depot for Cockatoo Island Dockyard.

The Government decided that the Australian National Line container terminal at Mort Bay would be technically suitable to meet these requirements on the one site and the Minister for Defence announced on 25 March 1980 that the Government planned to purchase that property.

The proposal raised considerable local concern about the use of the Australian National Line property and as a result the Government is now looking at alternative means of meeting its essential requirements whilst minimizing the impact on the local community. To this end negotiations are continuing with the New South Wales Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is zeranol, marketed under the trade name Ralgro, used in treating any human condition.
(2) Has zeranol any known adverse health effects in humans.
(3) Have animals been tested in Australia for residues of zeranol.
(4) Do any antibiotics presently used to stimulate growth in animals produce any adverse health effects in humans.
(5) Are animal carcasses and products analysed for the presence of growth stimulants such as antibiotics and hormones.
(6) If so, are residues less than those found in animals bred and tested in the United States of America.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Zeranol, marketed under the tradename Ralgro, is not marketed in Australia for the treatment of any human condition. The product, in the form of a subcutaneous implant, is used for growth promotion in steer cattle in Australia.

(2) There have been no reports of suspected adverse reactions in humans to either the Australian or the World Health Organization Registries of Adverse Reactions, nor in the recognized texts on the side effects of drugs. Extensive data on zeranol have been examined by expert committees of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) and Council has made recommendations for maximum residue limits of zeranol in the meat of cattle and sheep.
(3) Yes. The Department of Primary Industry's National Residue Survey includes monitoring for zeranol residues in samples of beef liver from animals killed in registered export abattoirs.

(4) At its 83rd Session in April 1977 NHMRC recommended that certain antibiotics including penicillins and sulphonamides be prohibited as growth promotants in animal husbandry in Australia. Council was of the opinion that the continued use of therapeutic antibiotics as growth promotants in animal feedstuffs could lead to an impairment of their efficacy in the treatment of human disease. These recommendations have been substantially adopted by the States in Australia. Hypersensitivity reactions resulting from prior contact with antibiotic feed supplements have been reported in the literature. At the present level of usage reactions in hypersensitive individuals from residues in food are not considered to be a problem of consequence. The Antibiotics Committee of NHMRC has under consideration the use of antibiotics in animal husbandry and this matter is being kept under review by both the Poisons Schedule (Standing) Committee and the Pesticides and Agricultural Chemicals ( Standing) Committee of Council.

(5) The National Residue Survey of the Department of Primary Industry includes a monitoring for antibiotic residues in cattle meat and it is intended to extend such monitoring, from 1982, to sheep and pig meat. Aside from zeranol, which has hormone-like properties, true hormones are not approved for growth promotant purposes in Australia and are not the subject of routine residue monitoring.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a study undertaken by Professor L. J. Opit and others, of the Department of Social and Preventive Medicine, Monash Medical School, Prahran, Victoria in January 1981 of the relationship between age and the number of general practitioner consultations of members of the Mutual Health Association in Adelaide referred to on page 16 of New Doctor, April 1981.
(2) If so, does this study suggest a peak of consultations in the 40-50 age group and the second lowest rate for those over 70.
(3) Are there any figures available from Pensioner Medical Service usage or from other studies which either support or oppose the findings of this study.
(4) Are the figures obtained in this study, if applied to the general population, surprising and can they be explained on a rational basis.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Professor Opit's study needs to be seen in context. It analysed data relating to a random sample of members of Mutual Health Association (MHA), i.e. it relates only to insured persons. No account is taken of the use of medical and hospital services by persons eligible to receive treatment under pensioner and disadvantaged arrangements, and uninsured persons. Clearly, then, Professor Opit's study does not include a large number of services used by people in older age groups where eligibility for Pensioner Health Benefits (PHB) services is most concentrated, or those by people who chose not to insure because they considered themselves relatively healthy-this group is likely to include many relatively younger people.

The data drawn from the Australian Health Survey and presented by Dr Powles in the article 'Over-Indulgence in Private Medicine' (New Doctor, April 1981, p. 16 )-Figure 1-show quite clearly the distortion that results in the upper age groups by the exclusion of uninsured persons.

Moreover, while consultations rendered in hospitals and nursing homes were deleted from the pool of consultations counted by Professor Opit, these members in respect of whom consultations were rendered were not deleted from the pools of people in each age group. This procedure would have had the effect of selectively depressing the general practitioner consultation rates for the higher age groups in Professor Opit's study, since these people are more likely to have consultations in hospitals or nursing homes.
(2) The results of Professor Opit's study for general practitioner contact rates for persons insured with MHA in Metropolitan Adelaide, classified by age, are:
However, when the services to other persons are added to these, it is considered most unlikely that the peak of consultations would be for the 40-49 age group.

For example, in 1979-80 there were 14,281,100 direct-billed general practitioner consultations by eligible pensioners (Director-General's Annual Report, 1979-80, Table 107). At 30 June 1980 there were 1,551,888 persons eligible for PHB services, of whom 67 per cent were age pensioners (Annual Report, Department of Social Security, 1979-80, Table 41). This means that PHB services by general practitioners are an estimated 9.2 per eligible pensioner annually. To this would have to be added general practitioner pensioner services processed through the private health insurance funds and general practitioner services to disadvantaged persons and uninsured persons, and certain primary- contact services at outpatient departments of hospitals.

(3) In respect of that part of the question relating to other studies, in the Australian Health Survey, 1977-78, conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the reported consultation rates by age group in the two weeks before interview were as follows:

These estimates include consultations with general practitioners, specialists and hospital doctors. They serve to show that the peak in total consultations is not in the 40-50 age group, but in fact in the 65 and over age group, as would be expected.

An analysis of Medibank data for the year ended in June 1976 for all medical benefit services paid in that year (see table below) shows that the average number of services per head of population at that time increased with rising age groups. The conduct of such an exercise on medical benefits data has not been possible since the introduction of amended health insurance arrangements effective from 1 October 1976.
AVERAGE NUMBER OF MEDICAL SERVICES PER HEAD OF POPULATION BY AGE AND STATE (a), YEAR ENDING 30 JUNE 1976
Australia NSW Vic. Qld SA WA Tas. ACT
(a) Classified into State according to practice address of doctor.

(4) No. The figures obtained in this study are not surprising when they are seen for what they really are-a study of insured persons. For reasons outlined above, they cannot be applied to the general population. They can indeed be explained on a rational basis in that they illustrate the effect of community rated medical insurance.
Morbidity tends to increase with age, so the younger, healthy insured tend to subsidise the older, less healthy, insured.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice , on 8 September 1981:

(3) What is the estimated value of any pieces of art unaccounted for.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The instrumentalities within my portfolio responsibilities which acquire works of art are the Australian National Gallery, Art Bank, Australian War Memorial, Museum of Australia, National Library of Australia, Australian Archives, Historic Memorials Committee and Australia Council.
I am advised that works are known to be missing from the holdings of three of these bodies:
(2) I am advised that in the cases of those authorities which have lost works:
National Library of Australia-The inventory is continuous but staff resources have permitted only one-third of the collection, comprising 33,868 works, to be inventoried during the last five years.

I am further advised that all art acquiring authorities within my portfolio responsibilities have procedures for regular inventory of art works. Australian War Memorial-None of the missing works has a market value in excess of $500 and the majority would be valued at less than $250.

Australian War Memorial-The stocktake of the total art collection will be undertaken after completion of stores rationalisation, expected to be June 1982.
National Library of Australia-The inventory is continuous.
Australian National Gallery-Present inventory procedures are annual but consideration is being given to a system of continuous stocktake.
Australian Archives-The inventory forms part of the annual stocktake.
Museum of Australia-The next inventory will be undertaken as soon as staff resources permit.
Historic Memorials Committee-The next stocktake of its holdings is planned for early 1982.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Government's decision to restore Commonwealth funding for the Institute of Criminology, reject one of the recommendations of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions (Hansard, 30 April 1981, page 1841).

(2) How many of the itemised recommendations (a) have been effected and completed, (b) have been put in motion (c) have been deferred, (d) have been amended, (e) have been reversed or (f) are awaiting further departmental or other reports.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Prime Minister, I provide the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. On 30 April 1981 the Prime Minister announced, as part of the Government's decisions arising out of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, that the Government would be asking all States to share the operating costs of the Australian Institute of Criminology. All of the States declined to contribute to the Institute's running costs but indicated they were most anxious that the Institute should continue its work. The Government has decided to continue funding the Institute but will be assessing its current and future projects. The Government's decisions on the future of the Institute were announced by the Attorney-General on 10 September 1981.

(2) As at end October 1981, approximately 270 of the Government's decisions relating to the Review had been implemented or were close to final implementation, of a total of some 350 decisions. Implementation of the remainder is being pursued by responsible Ministers and is oversighted by a Cabinet Committee chaired by the Minister for Industry and Commerce. To answer the question in the precise detail sought by the honourable member would entail a major commitment of staffing resources which I am not prepared to authorize.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Biological and Chemical Warfare Tests on Prisoners of War

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fry Mr K.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 14 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the fact that during the Second World War the Japanese military carried out extensive biological and chemical warfare tests on prisoners of war, particularly those held in camps in Manchuria .

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I have seen a press article claiming that the Japanese carried out chemical and biological tests on prisoners of war during World War Two.
(2) and (3) My Department hold no records containing information on this subject.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 14 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the supplementary information provided by his Department relating to a question raised at the Estimates Committee D hearings on 15 September 1981 (Hansard, House of Representatives Estimates Committees C, D, E and F, page 252) in which I asked (a) do rural industries or rural associated industries, for example, the processors of rural products, qualify for export development grants, (b) what is the total amount that has been paid to rural associated industries under the Export Development Grants Scheme and (c) what implications do the payments have for calculating Government assistance to rural industries, particularly rural exports, was his answer, as recorded in Hansard, correct, that in the broad, about 40 per cent of the grants are for rural associated industries and that he would get the details.
(2) Did Attachment D of the supplementary information state that no figures are available on the amount that has been paid to rural industries; if so, how does he reconcile these two statements.
(3) What does the 40 per cent figure quoted by him relate to.

(4) Does the supplementary information also state, presumably as a response to the third part of my question, that the level of assistance is small in terms of the total value of rural production and exports; if so, is this the basis on which Australia's trading partners who are signatories of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade subsidies agreement are likely to view the grants.
(5) What will be the implications for Australia's rural exports of the payment of export grants to processors of rural products.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Based on the 1980-81 growth of export trade by broad industry classification, about 40 per cent of Export Expansion Grants (EEG) for that year could be expected to accrue to rural and associated industries. Similar estimations are not able to be made for the Export Market Development Grants ( EMDG) scheme as those grants are not dependent on the levels of exports achieved but on individual claimants' expenditure on eligible promotion.

(2) The Export Development Grants Board has not maintained statistics of grant distribution by industry. The proportion referred to in (1) above is an estimation only and was made by the Department of Trade and Resources. There is no inconsistency between the answer I gave to the question on 15 September 1981 and the supplementary information provided by my Department in Attachment D.
(4) No contracting party to the GATT has requested consultations or taken action against the EEG or EMDG schemes under the provisions of Article XVI ( Subsidies) of the GATT.
However, the United States has considered applying countervailing measures against two products (wool tops and lamb) allegedly benefiting from the EEG and EMDG schemes.

In the case of wool tops the investigation concluded that the level of subsidisation was insignificant and therefore not countervailable. The investigation of lamb exports was terminated when the complaint of alleged subsidisation was withdrawn.

(5) The difficulties of precisely determining the effects of incentives on the level of exports are obvious. Nonetheless the Government has accepted the worth of operating export incentives, a policy endorsed by a wide spectrum of Australian industry.

The whole question of export incentives is presently before the Industries Assistance Commission. In looking at the forms of incentives to be made available after June 1983, the Government will consider, inter alia, the likely impact of particular schemes on particular industries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Insofar as the Commonwealth's responsibilities are concerned, three projects providing pregnancy support services received Commonwealth funding during 1980-81 under the Community Health Program to the extent shown:
Victoria: Caroline Chisholm Pregnancy Support Service-$60,850
New South Wales: Preparation for Parenthood-$5,400; Pregnancy Help-$28,600

These Commonwealth Funds were paid to the projects by the relevant State health authorities from the Commonwealth's block grant for community health services. In each case, the State authorities determined the level of the grant to individual projects.

Community Health Program funding was absorbed into general revenue funding with effect from 1 July 1981. For the current year the States are receiving, within general revenue grants, a component equal to the total Community Health Program block grant in 1980-81, plus 10 per cent. It is now entirely a matter for the States to determine how those funds are applied.
(3) and (4) Apart from the projects referred to in (1) and (2), I am advised that my Department holds no information on these purely State activities.

(5) My Department did not receive any requests from States during 1980-81 to fund new pregnancy support services. New South Wales requested specific additional funds for a minor expansion of the Pregnancy Help project under the Community Health Program. Under the conditions applying to the Community Health Program in 1980-81, no additional funds were available for new or expanded projects, but it was open to the State authorities to provide funds for the expansion from within the approved block grant.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Cost of Deleterious Effect of Alcohol Consumption

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an estimate by the Australian Foundation on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence in 1978 that deleterious effects of alcohol consumption cost the community over $1,000m per year.
(2) Has he been given more up to date estimates of this cost for each of the last 5 years.

(3) Can he state what the estimated government income was for each of the last 5 years at constant prices from (a) excise on beer, (b) excise on spirits, and ( c) State government liquor taxes and licences.
(4) What has been the level of Commonwealth Governmint funding for each of the last 5 years at constant prices for preventive and rehabilitative services for alcohol problems.
(5) What is the estimated change in (a) need, (b) effectiveness and (c) demand for the services referred to in part (3) above in the last 5 years.

(6) Can he state what has been the national level of untied grants to the States in lieu of preventive educational and rehabilitative health grants and the level of borrowing approvals for the State available for similar purposes in each of the last 5 years at constant prices.

(7) Can he also state whether non-wage incomes of some 30 per cent of higher incomes on average have risen while wages and the other 70 per cent or so of incomes have fallen in real terms after tax and standard health insurance cover during the last 5 years so that those less able to pay have less access to public clinics, counselling and rehabilitative services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. It appears that the figure of over $1,000m refers back to the year 1972-73 when an estimate of alcohol costs of $1,177m was made.

(2) Figures have not been calculated for each of the last 5 years. However, using the same approach as was adopted in the estimate of $1,177m for 1972-73 an estimate of $2,051m has been derived for 1977-78, and an estimate of $2,238m has been derived for 1979-80, the last year for which sufficient figures are available upon which to make a reasonable estimate.
(3) The estimated Government income for each of the last five years, at constant prices, (1976-77 representing the baseline) was as follows:
State Government and local authority liquor taxes, 1976-77-$123m, 1977-78-$128m , 1978-79-$131m, 1979-80-$134m, 1980-81-Not available.

(4) The Commonwealth Government has, over the last five years, contributed significant funds, under the Community Health Program, to projects which specifically and primarily relate to alcohol and other drug problems, mostly with a preventive or rehabilitative emphasis. It is estimated that the amounts, (at constant prices, 1976-77 representing the baseline) the Commonwealth Government spent on such projects over the last five years were as follows:

In addition further Commonwealth Government expenditure was directed at alcohol problems through the general health services. It has been calculated that at least 10 per cent of all general hospital costs can be attributed to alcohol related problems, and that a significant proportion of private health care is also directed towards persons with alcohol problems. However in many cases the involvement of alcohol in causation is apparently unrecognised. It is thus impossible to ascertain how much if this care could be said to be preventive or rehabilitative or to assess the amount of Commonwealth Government funding which could be allocated to such provisions.

(5) (a) An estimate of need can be based on average alcohol consumption and alcohol-related deaths. Average alcohol consumption rose only marginally between 1974-75 and 1979-80. There is no indication of significant change since June 1980. Estimated death rates per 100,000 population for alcoholic cirrhosis of the liver increased from 3.9 in 1974 to 4.6 in 1979; estimated death rates for alcoholism decreased from 3.3 in 1974 to 2.8 in 1978 (the last year for which comparable statistics are available); and estimated death rates for alcohol- related traffic accidents decreased from 13.6 in 1974 to 13.1 in 1979. Overall death rates from alcohol-related causes remained almost constant between 1974 and 1979.

(b) No reliable assessment of change in effectiveness of services has been made . No simple procedures are available by which to make such assessment. Nevertheless, compared with trends in the period 1969 to 1974, the trends in 1974 to 1979 are most encouraging.

(c) No formal assessment has been made of change in demand for services. However, there is evidence to suggest that greater demands are being made on services, in part due to earlier recognition of need. The Occupational Drug and Alcohol Program, operated through the Australian Foundation on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence could have played a part in this change.
(6) No. The information is not available.
(7) I have no information available that would either confirm or deny these statements.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Defence Service Homes Corporation: Sale of Land

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 20 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to his reply to my Question No. 2403 (Hansard, 9 September 1981, pages 1134-5) why was property previously owned by the Defence Service Homes Corporation in Queensland sold by a means other than the standard procedure adopted by his Department for the disposal of Commonwealth land.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government decided in 1978 that persons eligible for a Defence Service Homes loan should be offered the opportunity of purchasing a developed lot. Land not disposed of in this way, together with partly developed and undeveloped land , was then to be offered for sale on the open market for private home building.
As the land in question was acquired not for Commonwealth use but for resale for private home building, it was only appropriate that it be disposed of for that purpose.
This procedure in no way overturns the Government's long-standing policy of offering States and local government authorities the first opportunity to purchase surplus Commonwealth lands.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 20 October, 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are the delays of up to 4 months in the installation of new telephone services in the Brisbane suburbs of Highgate Hill and Woolloongabba due wholly to the lack of sufficient cable.
(2) Why is telephone cable in short supply.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Telecom Australia has advised that connection of nine applicants for new services in Kangaroo Point, a suburb adjacent to Woolloongabba, has been delayed because of insufficient cable capacity in their area. The installation of additional cable has been programmed, and the cable has been ordered. The work is expected to be completed in February 1982. These nine are the only applicants from the suburbs in question whose connections have been delayed by shortage of cable capacity. Other applicants, however, are waiting for the provision of additional telephone exchange equipment before their services can be connected.

Another 35 applications for new services in the Woolloongabba area have been delayed because of insufficient capacity in the telephone exchange equipment. The installation of additional equipment is being carried out, and completion is expected in February 1982.

In addition, there are 160 applicants for new services in the South Brisbane exchange area that require the installation of extra exchange equipment before they can be connected. (The South Brisbane exchange services Highgate Hill). The installation of additional equipment is being undertaken. The original program for this installation expected completion in December 1981, but, owing to circumstances beyond the control of Telecom Australia, a contractor has been delayed in completion of his part of the work. As a consequence, the completion of the installation is expected in February 1982.

(2) Telecom Australia has advised that there are no problems in cable supply affecting the areas in question. Cable is ordered some months ahead of the requirement and is delivered progressively, in accordance with these orders, to meet the installation program.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the decision of Mr Justice Gobbo of the Victorian Supreme Court in Niemann v Heartsview Insurance: re Palmdale Insurance (In Liquidation).

(2) If so, was it held that where a broker receives a premium, he does so as agent for the insured, not the insurer, and that, as a consequence, the (a) broker is not liable for the premium to the insurer even if he has received it from the insured and (b) insured remains liable for the premium to the insurer, even after it has been paid to the broker.

(3) Is it a fact that, since brokers profit from investments of premium funds, their actions in investing those moneys and in profiting from them, constitute a breach of trust, on Mr Justice Gobbo's holding.
(4) Is it also a fact that these actions might incur criminal penalties under various Acts forbidding the taking of secret commissions.

(5) Will he act, in accordance with the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission, to declare that brokers receive premiums on behalf of insurers; if not, what justification does he have for leaving large numbers of reputable brokers in a situation in which their proper business arrangements with insurers may unfairly subject them to the danger of civil and criminal penalties.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The relevant part of the judgment reads as follows:

'Question 1: Where contracts of insurance were effected with Palmdale Insurance Limited (''the Company'') through insurance brokers or agents of the Company, are such brokers or agents liable to pay to the Company any amount of unpaid premium in respect of policies issued by the Company to the policy holder?
As to marine insurance policies, yes.
As to non-marine insurance policies where effected through brokers, no.
As to non-marine insurance policies where the unpaid premium was received by the Company's own agent, then it is liable to account to its principal for such premium.

(3), (4) and (5) It would be inappropriate for me to speculate on how the findings of the specific case cited might apply in other, hypothetical, situations. In my statement of 10 June 1981 concerning the regulation of insurance brokers I specifically mentioned the traditional practice in the general insurance industry whereby brokers (and to some extent other insurance intermediaries) hold and invest or otherwise use on their own account premiums and other moneys from which they receive income over and above whatever commission is received by them. I also indicated that this practice of extended credit terms would be considered by the Government with a view to amending the Insurance Act 1973 to circumscribe dependence by brokers on this form of remuneration. Means of seeking to effect this are currently under consideration.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 28 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the current situation regarding patents on the immunisation procedure.
(2) Is Glaxo providing money to the Division of Animal Production; if so, what sum and what does Glaxo stand to gain by providing this money.

(3) In light of the data published by Martin et al (1979), why were tenders called for in February 1980, since this data indicated a need for immunological work to be done in order that the chances of eventual success might be optimal.
(4) Was the decision to call for tenders made at the level of Chief of Division or within the CSIRO Executive.

(5) If Glaxo has now acquired patent rights on this potential product how can the role played by CSIRO be justified to Australian farmers since their contributions by way of levies on wool and meat have supported research done by the Division of Animal Production for the past 20 to 25 years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Patents in respect of the immunisation procedure to increase fecundity in livestock were applied for provisionally in Australia by CSIRO in February 1980. Final specifications were filed in January 1981, in Australia and other countries including United States of America, United Kingdom, New Zealand, France, South Africa, and Argentina. Prosecution of these CSIRO patent applications is currently proceeding.

Following the agreement between CSIRO and Glaxo (Aust.) to develop immunisation procedures for increasing livestock productivity, there have been two additional filings of provisional patent specifications in the joint names of CSIRO and Glaxo to protect inventions regarded by the two parties as their joint property.

These filings follow the normal procedures used by CSIRO to secure ownership of its technological discoveries and to provide the licensees of its processes with the protection needed to bring innovative products to the marketplace.

(2) As a result of a collaborative agreement entered into after public tender, Glaxo Australia Pty Ltd is providing $145,000 in the financial period 1981-82, $ 120,000 in 1982-83, and $120,000 in 1983-84. These funds are to assist CSIRO in a collaborative research and development program with the specific aim of transferring a laboratory process into field application. Glaxo Australia Pty Ltd has been granted an exclusive licence with respect to the commercialisation of the CSIRO patents.

(3) The research referred to in the question was a preliminary experiment, carried out during 1977. Major changes in technique occurred during 1978-79 and these modifications produced much improved results. As a consequence, a decision was made to call tenders on 23 and 25 February 1980.
(4) The decision to call for tenders was made at the level of Chief of Division after consultation with CSIRO's Commercial Group, in accordance with CSIRO Executive policy.

(5) For Australian farmers to benefit from research, promising innovations such as the immunisation process have to undergo commercial development and evaluation. The high cost of developmental research, the necessary toxicological studies for registration of biological materials, and necessary marketing expertise, is outside the scope of CSIRO's resources. CSIRO's policy is to encourage industry to commercialise the Organization's research findings-the ultimate benefit is that Australian farmers will be provided with a major new technology for increasing the reproductive efficiency of their livestock.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Air Force and Navy Officers of Temporary Rank

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 28 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his reply to Question No. 3139 (Hansard, 27 October 1981, page 2645), why are the numbers of officers holding temporary rank in the Air Force and Navy disproportionately higher than those in the Army.
(2) What are the reasons for 9 Naval officers and 3 Air Force officers holding temporary rank beyond 12 months and what are the ranks held in these areas

The number of naval officers who have held acting rank longer than 12 months is now seven. Six of these officers are in the RAN Emergency Reserve undergoing a period of full time service. He will hold his acting higher rank only for the duration of this posting. He could, however, be promoted substantively in the meantime.
The acting ranks are as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the Prime Minister's answer to Question No. 3186 in which he indicated that 494 persons have received the British Empire Medal during the period of his Prime Ministership, was this award originally given for special acts of personal heroism or self sacrifice.
(2) If so, is there any means by which those to whom the B.E.M. was awarded for these actions can be identified as distinct from awards made in recognition of community services, etc.
(3) If this is not possible, will he examine means by which those awarded the B .E.M. for special achievement can be accorded proper recognition of the special circumstances of their award.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) The Most Excellent Order of the British Empire, with five classes and a Medal, the B.E.M., was founded in 1917 chiefly to recognise service by civilians in the First World War. There are two divisions, military and civil. It became the Order most widely conferred on civilians and service personnel for meritorious service. Until July 1974, when the Queen's Gallantry Medal was instituted, the Order including the B.E.M. could also be used to recognise acts of gallantry. On the occasions when the B.E.M. was awarded for gallantry, the wearing of a silver emblem of crossed oak leaves on the ribbon distinguished the wearer. In addition, the citations accompanying awards indicate clearly those made in recognition of bravery. Since the Government re-instituted the practice of making recommendations for Imperial honours in 1976, awards of the British Empire Medal have not been recommended for gallantry. The Government instead has recognised acts of bravery by the award of Australian Bravery Decorations which are part of the Australian Honours System.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the financial year of Qantas Airways Ltd end at 31 March each year, if so, when will the Qantas financial statements for the year ended 31 March 1981 be tabled in the Parliament.
(2) What are the reasons for the seven months delay in the tabling of these statements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The end of the financial year of Qantas Airways Ltd is 31 March. The financial statements for the year ended 31 March 1981 were tabled on 29 October 1981.
(2) The time between the end of the financial year and the tabling of the financial statements is required to enable all tasks associated with the preparation of the statements to be completed.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Relocation of Civil Airport, Darwin: Progress

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What progress has been made in the relocation of the civil airport at Darwin to the north side of the airport.
(2) Is it a fact that this relocation was to be started in 1982 and that no provision has been made in the 1981-82 Budget estimates for this project to proceed; if so, when are funds to be provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Detailed planning by my Department for the relocation of civil aviation activities at Darwin to the north side of the airport is being co- ordinated closely with the Department of Defence, Department of Housing and Construction, the Northern Territory Government and the Corporation of the City of Darwin, and is well advanced.

The overall project timing calls for initial capital works expenditures to be made in financial year 1982-83 and the Government will be considering this project, along with all the other proposals, when formulating the next Budget.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the rationale for the treatment of interest charges of $3m for off- budget borrowings by the Australian National Railways Commission in relation to the Adelaide-Crystal Brook Rail Standardisation Project as an expense item in his Department's estimates of expenditure and receipts for 1981-82 explanatory notes rather than as a capital item to be charged against the total cost of the project.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Loan Council approval for the Adelaide-Crystal Brook project funding covered only the funds necessary for the actual construction of the project which will not generate revenues until services commence late in 1982.

It was considered inappropriate to fund these charges from the commission's normal capital scources, which are fully committed to maintain the 'other' capital works program. It was therefore decided that the net interest charges should be funded by way of an addition to the loss subsidy for 1981-82.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to the Government's directive to the Australian National Railways Commission to aim at eliminating operating losses by 1988-89 what services (a) have been, (b) are being or (c) are planned to be cut to eliminate operating losses and for other reasons and over what periods.
(2) If the directive requires certain services to be cut or discontinued, what criteria are to be used to determine where cuts are to be made or services discontinued.

(3) Do these criteria include (a) full social cost-benefit analyses of the services and of the alternatives, including full resource, environmental and social costs and benefits or (b) only commercial cost-benefit valuations.

(4) If full social cost-benefit analyses are not to be undertaken into the alternatives available, such as with rail, road or no service at all, is it a fact that in the existing situation of differential mode cost recovery (a) rates , subsidies, taxes and environmental and social costs, cause financial cost to differ from full social costs and (b) an efficient, cost effective national transport system is inhibited rather than fostered.
(5) If full social cost-benefit analyses are not to be undertaken, is it a fact that Government policy on ANR, based on this, leads to national transport resource misallocation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The Australian National Railways Commission has indicated that since it became fully responsible for the Tasmanian and non-metropolitan South Australian Railways the following service changes have been implemented:

(i) passenger service reductions on the following lines to match effective demand: Adelaide-Port Pirie, Adelaide-Peterborough, Adelaide-Victor Harbour, Adelaide-Tailem Bend, Riverton-Jamestown and Peterborough-Broken Hill.
(ii) cessation of passenger services on the Naracoorte-Kingston line.
(iii) rail passenger service replaced by private bus service on Tailem Bend- Pinnaroo route.
(iv) reduction in scheduled local intrastate freight services on all lines to match effective demand.
(v) cessation of scheduled freight services on the following lines (lines now operate on as required basis): Karoonda-Waikerie, Strathalbyn-Victor Harbour, Clare-Andrews and Nuriootpa-Truro.
(vi) replacement of scheduled rail freight services by road freight services on the Peterborough-Quorn route.
(vii) withdrawal of freight services on following lines: Wallaroo-Moonta and Andrews-Spalding.
(viii) replacement of rail freight services by road freight services on Berri- Barmera route.
(ix) alteration to station status: 69 closed to less than carload (but left open to wagonload) traffic, 93 closed to all traffic and 11 made unattended.
(i) closure of North Australia Railway and Marree-Alice Springs line.
(iii) passenger service reductions on Port Augusta-Marree line because of the Marree-Alice Springs line closure.
(iv) variations to freight services to match demand.
(v) alteration to station status: 12 opened, 43 closed and 1 made unattended.
(i) cessation of Hobart-Launceston-Wynyard (Tasman Limited) and Parratah-Hobart passenger services.
(ii) variations to all freight services to match demand.
(iii) alteration to station status: 7 opened (includes 6 sidings), 16 closed to all traffic, 71 closed to less than carload (but left open to wagonload) traffic , and 22 made unattended.
(b) At present, the following rationalisation measures are under consideration: .

Adelaide-Gladstone-Quorn co-ordinated rail/bus service to be replaced by through bus service, Balaklava-Paskeville and Lochiel branch line closures, and regional freight centre at Loxton with associated rationalisation of rail services on Riverlands branch lines.
(c) Regarding future rationalisation measures, the Commission keeps such matters under continuous review. Further proposals will be considered as necessary.

(2) to (5) I have been advised that the Commission takes into account a range of factors when considering service rationalisations. These factors include the ability of the service to cover avoidable costs currently and within ten years, the provision of transport services by all modes in the particular area concerned, social implications of the contemplated action and the terms of the Transfer Agreements. As appropriate, consultation also takes place between the Commission and the relevant State Authorities. Furthermore, under the terms of the Transfer Agreements there are provisions for the States under certain circumstances to seek arbitration on service reductions.
Application of the above procedures should ensure that well considered decisions are taken in relation to service reductions.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Marine Standards Division Staff: Transfers to Canberra

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In House of Representatives Estimates Committee D on 17 September 1981, did he state that the Marine Standards Division staff to be compulsorily transferred to Canberra are Central Office planning and policy, and that operations staff responsible for carrying out day-to-day operational functions will not be transferred.

(2) Does the Australian Government Directory of 1981, at pages 346 and 347, correctly list the Marine Standards Division as an operational division and not a policy division; if so, will he explain the apparent discrepancy in his advice to the committee on this matter.

(3) Are officers of the Division primarily involved in operational matters requiring a day-to-day contact with the maritime industry in relation to (a) the approval of plans and submissions, (b) determining the manning of ships, (c) setting and enforcing industry standards under the Navigation Act and (d) such other matters which are not the responsibility of the regional offices.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In the House of Representatives Estimates Committee D on 17 September, I said:

'The people who will not be transferred are those who are operational staff responsible for carrying out the day- to-day operational functions of the Department of Transport. Those people who are being transferred from the Marine Division happen to be central office planning and policy staff. They are not the day-to-day operational officers. So the Industry will still have opportunities to meet with the operational people face to face in the marine areas and other areas at the regional offices'.

(2) Marine Standards Division is responsible for formulating, promulgating and supervising implementation of technical and safety standards to facilitate safe shipping operations in Australian waters. This is quite commonly referred to as a policy function and this usage is reflected in the duty statements of senior officers of the Division requiring participation in policy formulation on marine operational and survey matters. It was in this sense that I used the expression 'planning and policy', to make clear the distinction between the Central Office responsibility for planning, formulation and promulgation of standards and the day-to-day Regional responsibility for the implementation and practical operation of those standards. The distinction made in the Australian Government directory is a strictly formal one. It distinguishes between those Divisions responsible for policy in the purest sense and those responsible for operational policies.
(3) The honourable member has referred to four aspects under this question:
(a) The approval of plans and submissions: This is done through the Regions except where some Central Office guidance is required. The industry contact, however, should be at the Regional level.

(b) Manning of Ships: This involves setting the level of manning required for Australian ships. Day-to-day contact with industry to ensure that prescribed manning standards are met is a Regional responsibility.

(c) Setting and enforcing industry standards under the Navigation Act: Setting standards is essentially policy work, in the sense described in part 2 to the question. This is done in Central Office. Enforcing standards is regarded as an operational task and is undertaken by Regional Officers.
(d) The matters referred to here would be of a non-operational nature, or involve guidance to Regional Officers as to how they should perform operational functions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that his Department has had difficulties in recruiting suitably qualified and experienced staff for the Marine Standards Division in its Central Office, Melbourne.

(2) If the Australian maritime industry is to be safe and efficient, and if it is to be revitalised in accordance with his stated policy, is it essential that staff of the Marine Standards Division are fully conversant with the Australian Industry; if not, why not.

(3) In view of the high salaries paid to serving ships' officers, how does the Department propose to recruit suitable staff to a future Central Office in Canberra, particularly as such staff will not be eligible for the conditions provided for compulsory transferees.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) Staff recruited to Marine Standards work are generally those who prefer the advantages of a land-based position to the disadvantages of serving on ships. Indeed, practically all Marine Surveyors currently employed by the Department have at some time been serving ships' officers.
I would therefore not expect transfers to Canberra to materially affect the recruitment situation one way or the other.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that tenders for CSIRO's oceanographic research vessel are to be re-opened.
(2) If so, what are the reasons for the delay.
(3) What effect will the delay have on the current plans for research.

(4) Is it a fact that Senator Messner, while representing him in a Senate Estimates Committee hearings, said that he could not divulge the reasons for the delay; if so, what were the reasons for this statement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
