ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Exchange of Documentary Broadcasts with the Soviet Union

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the Cyprus Bulletin for the week ending 15 August 1981, that Cyprus has an agreement for exchange of documentary broadcasts with the Soviet Union.
(2) Will he facilitate talks between the ABC and the Soviet State Radio and Television Committee to try to achieve a similar agreement in conformity with UNESCO principles; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) I understand that an agreement was signed by Sir Talbot Duckmanton, General Manager ABC with the State Committee for Radio and Television of the USSR in Moscow on July 1978. The agreement ran for two years and was automatically renewable every second year, unless either party makes a written statement of its wish to abrogate the document. The document covers an exchange of television material on general life, documentaries, feature, popular science, musical and children's programs and in radio, material on literature, popular science, sports as well as classical, folk and present-day music.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have investigations into the safe use of Debendox, a drug prescribed for morning sickness in pregnant women, been completed; if so, what were the findings and were they published.

(2) Is it compulsory for the medical profession to report to the Drug Evaluation Committee all abnormalities, defects and miscarriages, together with the case history, where the administration of drugs during early pregnancy has occurred.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Data on both safety, and the validity of inclusion of dicyclomine in the formulation are still under evaluation.
(2) No. The procedure for reporting suspected adverse reactions to any drug is entirely voluntary.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the drug Marzine intensively investigated before being released on the market.
(2) Was it banned at a later date; if so, for what reasons.

(3) Was there any investigation carried out of the number of children born with defects such as deafness, blindness and short weak muscles, particularly of the neck, during the years that Marzine was being prescribed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The marketing of Marzine predated by many years current evaluation procedures.
(2) No. However the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee recommended in 1966, after consideration of available evidence, that the product information carry a warning on teratogenicity in animals.

(3) Concern about the potential of the piperazine group of antihistamine drugs, including Marzine, to cause birth defects in humans arose from findings that these drugs may cause birth defects in rodents, notably cleft palate. Several studies, including one at the Women's Hospital in Sydney, failed to confirm the role of Marzine in causing human birth defects. My Department is not aware of any study demonstrating Marzine to cause the birth defects described by the honourable member. Only one Australian report describing a suspected association between the use of Marzine and a birth defect (cleft lip and cleft palate) has been received by the Australian Adverse Drug Reactions Registry since 1964.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Government Publishing Service: Lease of Bookshops

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many (a) written and (b) telephone complaints have been received protesting at the proposal to transfer the functions of the Australian Government Publishing Service to the private sector.
(2) Has his attention been drawn to the enormous public support for retention of the existing Australian Government Publishing Service functions; if so, what action will he take.

(3) In the light of extensive public support for the retention of the existing Australian Government Publishing Service functions, will he take steps to reverse the decision to hand over these functions to the private sector; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) It is presumed that Mrs Kelly's question referred to the Government's decision to lease the Australian Government Publishing Service bookshops to the private sector. In this regard, five hundred and fifty written representations have been received, of which five hundred and eight comprised identical roneoed letters.
(b) Representations have been received by telephone from various sections of the community but no records have been kept of these calls.

(2) The representations which have been received indicate the public's high regard for the Australian Government Publishing Service bookshops. Under the proposed leasing arrangements, it is intended that public access to the full range of government publications will be maintained.

(3) No. It is the Government's view that commercial activities of this kind are best performed in the private sector, where they are open to greater influence from consumers and to the disciplines of competition.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Science and Technology: Staffing Arrangements

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the Public Service Board has written to staff of his Department warning them that about 200 persons will lose their positions in 1982 .
(2) If so, will he provide a copy of that letter to the Shadow Minister for Science and Technology.
(3) Is it a fact most of the staff to be displaced were formerly staff members of the Department of Productivity who were absorbed into his Department.
(4) How many former Department of Productivity personnel are now working within his Department and how many will be affected by the Public Service Board's decisions.

(5) Is it a fact that the areas to be wound down or cut back completely are the divisions of (a) working environment, (b) physical work environment and human relations, (c) Productivity Promotions Council, (d) productivity development, (e ) National Materials Council, (f) pilot programs for inventors and inventions, ( g) the 'Buy Australian' campaign and (h) special research programs for primary and secondary producers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Several months ago my Department completed an assessment of the effects upon it of the Government's decisions in regard firstly to the Review of Commonwealth Functions and secondly the provisional staff ceilings for 1981-82. It was concluded that it might be necessary for some 200 staff to be relocated away from their present work areas. In accordance with normal practice this conclusion and related background information was advised to the Public Service Board which in turn notified Peak Councils and each staff association and union with members employed in the Department. All staff of the Department were given similar advice by way of an internal administrative circular.
(2) I will arrange for a copy of the Department's administrative circular to be made available to the Shadow Minister.

(4) Of the nearly 1100 staff who were transferred to my Department from the former Department of Productivity less than 400 are presently working in areas nominated for change by RCF decisions. The number who will need to be redeployed away from their present positions is not able to be determined at this stage because several of the major functions involved are the subject of reviews which have yet to be completed.

(5) In regard to parts (a) to (f) inclusive of the Question the Government's decisions were conveyed to the Parliament by the Prime Minister in his statement of 30 April 1981. They are recorded at pages 1847 and 1848 of the Hansard. In respect of the areas of the Department covered by the RCF decisions the information set out in the administrative circular referred to above remains substantially correct. There has been one significant development. The funtions of the National Materials Handling Bureau in Sydney are being reviewed at my direction and further action in relation to the relevant RCF decision will be determined when the review is completed. I should mention also that the functions indicated at parts (g) and (h) of the question are not within my portfolio.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of his Government's position on relations with South Africa, is consideration now being given to allowing reciprocal agreements between Air Zimbabwe and Qantas for regular flights to the African continent.
(2) If no consideration is being given, will he now order it to commence; if not, why not.
(3) If an agreement has been reached, or is about to be finalised, when will he announce the details of the Government's policy.

(4) In view of the Minister for Transport's answer to a question on the House from the honourable member for Parramatta (Hansard, 28 October 1981, page 2574) will he now give a firm undertaking that the Government's foreign policy will not be ignored by Qantas when it is making its commercial decision on flights to Mauritius or ports on the African continent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government would welcome the introduction of commercial air services by Qantas between Australia and points in southern Africa, other than South Africa, but has left it to Qantas to use its economic judgment as to the viability of such services. I understand that discussions are taking place between representatives of Qantas and a number of African airlines, including Air Zimbabwe, regarding such services.

(3) Discussions are continuing at the airline level. Once Qantas has assessed the commercial risks and potential benefits of any proposed service it will report to the Government. At that time the Government will give consideration to any public announcement that may be necessary. The Government's policy towards airlinks with the African continent is already on the public record.

(4) There is nothing in the course of action being followed by Qantas that conflicts with the Government's foreign policy. Indeed it is my understanding that Qantas has been consulting with Government Departments on a regular basis to ensure that its actions are fully consistent with the Government's broader objectives.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he say when opening the meeting of the World Heritage Committee in Sydney on Monday, 26 October 1981, 'We established the Fox Inquiry on uranium and have acted on the report'.

(2) If so, is it a fact that the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry, otherwise known as the Fox Inquiry, was established in July 1975 under the provisions of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, by the then Prime Minister and Minister for Environment, the Hon. E. G. Whitlam.
(3) Is it also a fact that during almost 6 years of office his Government has not established one environmental inquiry under the Environment Protection ( Impact of Proposals) Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) As I pointed out in my address at the opening of the World Heritage Committee in Sydney last October, the Commonwealth Government has shown in a number of practical ways its awareness of the need for initiative and action on matters of conservation and the environment. Shortly after its election in 1975, the Government decided that the Fox Inquiry on uranium (the Ranger Inquiry) should proceed with expedition. The honourable member will be aware that the Government accepted and acted upon the principal recommendations of the Ranger Inquiry to safeguard and protect the environment.

Since 1975, the Government has directed a total of 59 Environmental Impact Statements (EIS's) on a wide range of proposals for which Commonwealth decisions were required. In particular, major assessments, including the preparation and public review of EIS's have been made of proposed uranium mining projects at Nabarlek, Koongarra and Jabiluka in the Alligator Rivers Region of the Northern Territory.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Disallowance of Claim for Compensation under Commonwealth Employees' Compensation Act

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister direct that an investigation be held into the claim made by Terence Ronald Scott, former Private, Australian Military Forces, Service No. 38649, against the Commonwealth Commissioner for Employees' Compensation, the examination of that claim by the then Commissioner and the evidence which was presented in support of the claim, and the reasons why that claim, which related to alleged illness following military service in Vietnam, was rejected; if not, why not.

(2) In particular, will the Minister direct that the investigation sought in part (1) ascertains (a) whether the decision of No. 1 War Pensions Entitlement Appeal Tribunal, dated 19 July 1971 (Registered No. 60652) and (b) what other medical and other evidence, was placed before the then Commissioner for Employees' Compensation by any party to that claim, or any representative of any party; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) & (2) No. I am informed by the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation that a claim made in November 1970 by Private T. R. Scott for compensation under the Commonwealth Employees' Compensation Act 1930 was disallowed on 6 October 1972, following comprehensive investigations, on the basis of specialist medical opinion.

Private Scott died in October 1971, and his legal personal representative was given a notice of rights of appeal with a copy of the determination disallowing the claim. No appeal against the determination was lodged.
The Commissioner was at all times prepared to reconsider the case on request by either the legal personal representative or the widow of Private Scott.

However, the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation was advised on 25 November 1981 of the decision of the War Pensions Entitlement Appeal Tribunal of 16 July 1971, and the subsequent acceptance by a Repatriation Board, of Private Scott's death as related to his service in South Vietnam, with consequent payment of a war widow's pension to Mrs Scott.

Had these Repatriation Act entitlements been revealed at the time the compensation claim was determined, Section 98 of the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act would necessarily have been invoked, precluding payment of compensation irrespective of the nature of medical evidence.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian War Memorial: Eligibity for Roll of Honour

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are the names of Australians who were killed during World War II and who were not members of the Australian armed forces, but who were serving with the Merchant Navy, the RAF and other similar forces, included in the Hall of Honour at the Australian War Memorial; if not, why not.
(2) Is it proposed to include these persons' names on the Hall of Honour at the Australian War Memorial; if so, will he ensure that relevant next-of-kin are notified of this decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australians who died during World War II as a result of service with the Merchant Navy, the RAF and similar forces are not named on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Menorial. The reason for this is that at the time the Roll of Honour at the Memorial was compiled and erected the Australian War Memorial Act provided only for commemoration of Australians who died on or as a result of active service with the armed forces of Australia.

(2) The Act has been amended to provide for commemoration of Australians who have died as a result of any war or warlike operations in which Australians have been engaged on active service. A bronze plaque commemorating Australians who died serving with armed forces of allied countries, merchant marines, philanthropic organisations, and as war correspondents, photographers and artists has been erected adjacent to the Roll of Honour at the Memorial. Work has been proceeding on the compilation of a list of names of Australians in those categories to be incorporated in a Commemorative Book which will be exhibited at the Memorial. It will include, inter alia, the names of over 500 former members of the Merchant Navy. Many of the names to be included in the book have been supplied by next-of-kin and other relatives as a result of publicity in the national and international press. Insofar as it is practicable, next-of-kin will be advised of the inclusion of names in the book.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that rates for health insurance are for only 2 categories, single and family.
(2) If so, does the family with only one adult subsidise the family with 2 adults.
(3) Will he undertake to negotiate with the various funds for a rate to cover one parent families.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The present and past health insurance arrangements are based on the community rating principle which provides that contributors pay the same rate of contributions regardless of such factors as state of health, age, family size etc. It is accepted within this principle that single persons (without dependants) pay half the family rate.

(2) It could be argued that one parent families may subsidise two parent families but, equally, it could also be claimed that couples without dependent children, young single persons, families with some alternative health cover, e.g . Repatriation or Defence, etc., also subsidise other persons. This is the nature of the community rating principle which the Government adopts as a measure to keep contribution rates within reasonable reach of all persons.

(3) Because of the attractiveness and simplicity of the community rating principle I do not see merit in negotiations that could give rise to a conglomeration of contribution rate arrangements. I could see a series of differing arrangements being sought to relate to particular circumstances which would endanger the present satisfactory and long standing acceptable practices.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Costs of Connecting Services to Manufactured Homes

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the current estimated costs of connection of services to individual manufactured homes (a) on separate locations and (b) within mobile home parks.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The cost of connection of services to individual manufactured homes would be the same as the cost of connection for any other detached home provided that the same number of connections to services and the same allotment size are used in each case. Costs would depend on the particular site characteristics such as topography, soil and location of the services. It is normal practice in manufactured housing to use only one connection for each hydraulic service where this is allowed by regulation, while for conventional housing two or more connections are normal. Again, costs savings would vary with the particular site conditions.

I am not aware of mobile home parks in Australia for permanent dwellings and therefore no figures are available on the costs of connection of services. The service connection costs would again depend on the characteristics of the particular site including the size of allotments and the length of runs from the mains.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2843) Mr Giles asked me a question , without notice, in my capacity as Minister for Primary Industry. His question concerned a new high yielding variety of wheat called Roseworthy College 311 and the difficulties this variety was encountering in being registered in Queensland and Western Australia. Mr Giles asked that the matter be listed for consideration by the Australian Agricultural Council.

ANSWER.PARA: I am now able to supply you with the following additional information:

The registration of a crossbred variety such as RAC.311 requires endorsement by the Wheat Advisory Committee in the State concerned, followed by agreement by all co-operators in the wheat registration scheme (i.e., all wheatbreeding organisations in Australia). The crossbred wheat RAC.311 is unique in that it is a mixture of two components, one hard grained and the other soft grained.

Because of this dual characteristic the Western Australian Department of Agriculture objected to the principle of releasing what was in effect two varieties each of which could be unsuitable when grown on its own.

The Queensland Department of Primary Industry had similar objections as well as objecting to the overall quality of the mixture, maintaining it was inferior in certain regards to the varieties it was planned to replace. The Department contended that crude selection within the variety could change the composition of the mixture in an unpredictable manner reducing quality even further. In particular it could reduce the quality of ASW in South Australia, leading to a decline in returns to all growers in Australia including those in Queensland.

The Australian Wheat Board has indicated that RAC.311 was intended in South Australia to replace Halberd because it had superior quality characteristics as regards hardness, dough properties and baking quality.

Although being marginally superior to Halberd in quality it is of lesser quality to other recommended varieties in South Australia and if RAC.311 replaced Oxley, Condor or Aroona, the AWB considers the quality of South Australian ASW would decline.

Regarding other States, the Board considers that where quality standards are generally higher (for example, Queensland and New South Wales) RAC.311 would be unlikely ever to be released. The low test weight of RAC.311 further increases the likelihood of it failing to meet the ASW standard of 74 kg/hl minimum.

The Board has concluded that the South Australian Advisory Committee did not fully appreciate the implications of releasing a mixed variety at the time. The Board believes that Roseworthy College should now seek registration of only the hard component of RAC.311 and the South Australian Committee should limit the extent of its recommendation of this hard component to higher protein areas of that State.

After considering the information supplied by the Australian Wheat Board I consider there is no basis to take the matter to the Australian Agricultural Council for further consideration. I consider that adequate arrangements already exist in each State for comprehensively examining the registration of crossbred varieties based on criteria and standards applicable to that State.

at the expiration, surrender, or sooner determination of the lease, the lessee has the right to remove any improvements he has made during the lease term;

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Third Party Insurance Claims in the Australian Capital Territory

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Commonwealth Government contribute to the funds administered by the Nominal Defendant to pay claims for damages in respect of death and bodily injury arising from the use of uninsured or unidentifiable vehicles on the basis of the percentage of Commonwealth vehicles in the Australian Capital Territory; if so, why.
(2) Does the Commonwealth make similar contributions in the States; if not, what particular circumstances exist in the Australian Capital Territory to justify these contributions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Because section 50 of the Motor Traffic Ordinance 1936 subjects the Commonwealth, as its own insurer, to the same rules that apply to insurance companies in relation to third party insurance in the Australian Capital Territory; and section 86 of the Ordinance requires the Commonwealth and the authorised insurers to contribute proportionately to the costs of administration and the cost of claims against the Nominal Defendant for the Australian Capital Territory.
(2) My Department does not have details of arrangements, if any, between the Commonwealth and the States in respect of this matter.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Revenue from Motor Vehicle Registrations: Australian Capital Territory

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the fact that whereas the numbers of vehicles registered in the Australian Capital Territory increased by 1.1 per cent during 1979-80, yet revenue from motor vehicle registration decreased from $7.86m in 1978-79 to $7.79m in 1979-80 , indicate that a greater proportion of small cars was registered than in the previous years or did other factors contribute to this fall in receipts; if so what other factors.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The figures do not indicate that a greater proportion of small cars was registered in 1979-80 than in previous years-all motor vehicles up to two tonnes pay the same registration renewal fee.
Observe factors which would have contributed to a fall in revenue include the following:
There was an increase of 330 motor cycles and 857 trailers registered in 1979- 80. These attract registration fees of $15 and $10 respectively compared with $ 56 for a standard vehicle.

First registrations attract a surcharge of $25 for cars and trucks and $15 for motor cycles and trailers. In 1978-79 23,035 vehicles were registered for the first time, but in 1979-80 the number of first registrations fell by 2,687 to 20 ,348.
There was a decline of 74 in the number of heavy vehicles presented for registration over the two years. These attract fees of around $100 more than a car.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Income Tax Payable on Interest Yielded from Savings Accounts

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that income tax is paid on interest yielded from savings accounts in banks, building societies and finance companies.
(2) Is it also a fact that when interest rates rise the interest yielded from those savings accounts increases; if so, does the tax paid on that interest increase when the interest increases.

(3) What is the estimate of increased income tax revenue derived by the Government from a 1 per cent increase in interest rates for savings accounts in banks, building societies and finance companies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Income tax is payable on interest yielded from savings accounts in banks and building societies and from savings invested with finance companies where the interest is received by a taxpayer whose income, including the interest, exceeds $4195 and who is not otherwise non-taxable by entitlement to rebate. An increase in rates of interest, causing interest received to increase, also results in increased income tax becoming payable.

(3) As interest received from savings through banks, building societies and finance companies is not distinguished from other interest in the income tax statistics, it is not possible to provide an accurate estimate of the increased income tax revenue that would result from an increase in interest rates on these types of account. Statistics are, however available of the total amount of interest included in individuals income tax returns for the 1979-80 income year. If half of this amount had related to such savings, and if the relevant interest rates had been 1 per cent higher for that year, the resulting increase in tax would have been an amount of the order of $50m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fry Mr K.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 26 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How long has the Canberra Development Board been in operation.
(2) What have the previous annual budgets of the Board been.
(3) What sum has the Board spent on travelling costs.
(4) How many firms have been established in the Australian Capital Territory as a direct result of the activities of the Board.
(5) How many jobs have been created by the Board, apart from the Board's own membership.
(6) If the Board has not achieved any substantial results by June 1982, will the Government consider not giving further grants to it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Board was established in August 1979.

(a) The Board was not operating for the full year. The salary of one officer ( Level 1, Second Division) was met by the Department of the Capital Territory. The Executive Director was on staff for only seven months.

(4) From the outset it has been widely recognised that the Board would probably not achieve anything significant during its first three years because of the time it takes to organise resources, establish the name, and sell the product, and for industry to assess the situation, finalise the decision, plan the operation and begin work in the new location.
In circumstances, as can be seen from the following information, the Board has achieved a remarkable response to its efforts and it can be expected that it will go from strength to strength.

During 1980-81, the Board has been instrumental in bringing the discussions with Natsemi to the stage where that company sent three of its senior technical personnel to Australia to collate information on which to conduct a feasibility study.
Duntech International opened here, from United States of America, in 1981 as a consequence of the Board's efforts.
Techway, an Australian high technology company, has announced publicly that it is negotiating through the Board to establish in Canberra.

The Australian office of the European Economic Community was established in Canberra in 1981, largely through the efforts of the Board-in fact, if it had not been for the Board, those offices would not yet be in Australia.
A furniture assembly plant will soon begin operations in Canberra following considerable assistance from the Board.

The Board has devoted a lot of resources to the development of projects to attract visitors to Canberra. Apart from the proposed international hotel/ convention centre, the Board is developing some very exciting proposals which will become public knowledge in the near future, and when constructed will provide both entertainment for the Canberra population and a significant boost to the visitor industry.
National Associations are now establishing in Canberra at the rate of one per month and the Board has provided assistance to many of these.

Following the European mission, representatives of three large Italian groups, one major French group of companies and a German company have already visited Canberra, and the discussions indicate that there is a very high chance that facilities will be established here.
Discussions are continuing for potential joint ventures between six Australian companies and three overseas companies to form three new companies in Canberra.
(5) Statistics showing the number of jobs created by the Board are not available. The Board does not have the resources to collect and update such information.

(6) The Board was established following the clear recommendation of the Committee of 22 (now CARD) representing a large segment of the Canberra community and the decision was widely welcomed throughout Canberra.

The fact that the Board has clearly attracted serious interest in Canberra from so many major companies, and in particular, has brought the Natsemi proposal so far so quickly, justifies its establishment.

The Board has achieved more than any other group of its size and resources, and it's already significant achievements will continue despite the activities of its critics and opponents both inside and outside Canberra.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McMahon Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have any cases of tenosynovitis been reported to date, in the Department or Statutory Authorities under the Minister's jurisdiction.

(2) If so, will the Minister state (a) how many cases have been reported, (b) in what types of work the affected persons were engaged, (c) of the cases reported how many were in respect (i) female and (ii) male employees, and (d) what age brackets appear to be most affected, in the Department and each Statutory Authority.
(3) Will the Minister provide similar information in respect of carpal tunnel.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answers to the honourable member's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2)(a) Since 1 July 1979 there have been four cases of tenosynovitis reported, two cases of tendonitis and two cases of carpal tunnel syndrome.

(2)(b) The four cases of tenosynovitis were all persons engaged on typing, shorthand duties. Of the cases of tendonitis there was one case involving a typist and one case involving a Clerk. The two cases of carpal tunnel syndrome involved a Clerical Assistant and a Tea Lady.
(2)(c) The cases of tenosynovitis were all females. The cases of tendonitis involved one male and one female and the two cases of carpal tunnel syndrome were both female.

(2)(d) The age bracket of the tenosynovitis cases ranged from 28 years to 51 years. The ages of the two persons with tendonitis were 35 years and 40 years respectively, and the age of the two persons with carpal tunnel syndrome were 48 years and 64 years respectively.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the level of congestion throughout the Brisbane telephone network causing an abnormally high failure rate.
(2) Is the acceptable failure rate for connecting calls usually 1 per cent.
(3) Does the failure rate stand as high as 17 per cent in some exchanges, for example Beenleigh and Thornlands, Queensland.
(4) Has Telecom Australia announced the introduction of a fully automatic mobile telephone service from 14 September 1981.

(5) Will he make provision for the extra switching apparatus and extra links required to provide a satisfactory service to Queensland subscribers before committing funds for a purpose such as automatic car phones.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) STD calls to some destinations are currently experiencing abnormally high failure rates due to congestion especially during the evening STD concessional periods. Failures on local calls in the Brisbane telephone network, due to both congestion and plant defects, are within Telecom Australia's objective of no more than 2.5 per cent of call attempts.

(2) On local calls the acceptable failure rate due to congestion only is 1 per cent. On STD calls Telecom Australia's objective is that no more than 2 per cent of call attempts during the STD full tariff period be unsuccessful due to congestion. The objectives during the STD concessional tariff periods are that no more than 7 per cent and 10 per cent of call attempts be unsuccessful due to congestion in the measurement periods of 6 p.m.-9 p.m. and 9 p.m.-10 p.m. respectively. These latter objectives recognise the need for economic provisioning of trunk circuits and exchange switching equipment, in ensuring that the system is not dimensioned solely for a relatively short evening traffic peak which incurs cheaper rates.

(3) In September 1980, service quality at the Thornlands exchange as measured by artificially generated STD calls recorded 16.9 per cent congestion. This high figure reflected a fault condition rather than the standard of performance of the Thornlands exchange.

Existing call failures in the telephone network are mainly due to circuit underprovisioning on some STD traffic routes. Shortfalls have arisen in some parts of the network due to the traffic stimulus that has been generated by the cheaper call charges after 6 p.m. and 9 p.m. creating differing traffic dispersions from those which prevailed during the day time busy periods.

(4) Yes-A modern mobile radio service was established in Melbourne in September 1981; to be followed by Sydney in December 1981. Provision of these mobile services is a long term project extending over several years. Planning is now in hand for the provision of similar types of services for the other capital cities .

(5) Telecom Australia is giving high priority to the provision of relief on the congested traffic routes in the network, and this action is not prejudiced by the progressive implementation of new facilities like the mobile radio service.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Bureau of Mineral Resources: Mineral and Petroleum Discoveries

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which mineral and petroleum discoveries, and extensions to known deposits, have been made since 1960 (a) by the Bureau of Mineral Resources, (b) after the BMR found strong evidence of mineralisation, or of the locality being highly prospective, (c) using results of geophysical or other surveys conducted by the BMR or (d) with other assistance from the BMR.
(2) What is the size and value of each of these discoveries and what stage of development has been reached in each case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The petroleum and mineral exploration industries have acknowledged the importance of the Bureau of Mineral Resources' (BMR) role in providing the basic scientific framework in which private exploration efforts are undertaken. However, it is not generally possible to attribute specific mineral discoveries to basic geological work published by the Bureau.

The link between BMR's geophysical surveys and discoveries of particular mineral deposits is sometimes more specific. BMR's magnetic, radiometric, and gravity surveys, and subsequent publication of maps, have resulted in some of the indicated anomalies being drilled and deposits outlined by private enterprise. Examples include the Savage River (Tasmania) iron ore deposits, the Galilee Basin (Queensland) coal deposits, Olympic Dam (Roxby Downs, South Australia) copper-uranium-gold deposit, the Nabarlek and Ranger (Northern Territory) uranium deposits, the Yeelirrie (Western Australia) uranium deposits, and the Agnew-Mount Keith (Western Australia) nickel deposits. In 1968, BMR identified, by a marine seismic survey, most of the petroleum structural trends on the North West Shelf and the Exmouth Plateau, subsequently tested by private companies and, in the case of the North West Shelf, now in the process of development. A large number of Australia's petroleum discoveries were also assisted through subsidies paid under the Petroleum Search Subsidy Act which operated from 1957 to 1974. The BMR was responsible for examining and recommending applications for subsidy under the Act and for oversight of subsidised operations.

Major mineral and petroleum discoveries are shown in the table below together with estimates of reserves prior to commencement of production. No 'category (D) -BMR provided other assistance' has been shown on the table because the use of basic information provided by BMR would be a factor, directly or indirectly, in most Australian discoveries of minerals and petroleum. The value of the petroleum and mineral deposits, in the discovery of which BMR has had some involvement, is difficult to quantify, and depends on factors such as location, grade, size of orebody or reservoir, production and initial treatment costs, world metal and fuel prices, and the world political and economic situation. However, with the 1980 production of minerals and petroleum alone valued at 7.5 billion dollars, the overall value of such discoveries can conservatively be placed at several billion dollars.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Safeguards Procedures for Uranium Enrichment Plants

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to statements published by the International Atomic Energy Agency in the International Atomic Energy Agency Bulletin of August 1980 pages 32-4, that the Agency has no actual experience safeguarding uranium enrichment plants, that the Agency has not defined in detail a safeguards strategy applicable to all types of enrichment plants and that INFCIRC/66/Rev.2 does not as yet contain special safeguards procedures for enrichment plants.
(2) If so, what action is the IAEA taking to develop appropriate safeguards procedures for enrichment plants.
(3) Is the Australian Government taking action to have these procedures developed before Australian uranium undergoes enrichment overseas.
(4) In view of the absence of IAEA safeguards procedures, what assurance exists to guarantee that uranium undergoing enrichment is not diverted to non-peaceful purposes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (i) The reference is to a reprinting of a document first published by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) in February 1979 (INFCE/SEC/11) for the International Nuclear Fuel Cycle Evaluation which stated that as of the date of the document's preparation the IAEA had had no actual experience in safeguarding uranium enrichment plants because such facilities had only just begun to come under IAEA safeguards.

(ii) The article further stated that the IAEA had defined in detail a safeguards strategy applicable to all types of enrichment plants. Most of the study effort to that time had centred on centrifuge facilities of the type the IAEA was immediately faced with safeguarding.

(iii) Since the entry into force in 1970 of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT) and the progressively wider acceptance of that Treaty, international efforts to develop IAEA safeguards have largely been focused on IAEA document INFCIRC/153 (Corrected), which elaborates the system of IAEA safeguards to be applied in non-nuclear-weapon states which are party to the NPT . Safeguards agreements of the INFCIRC/66/Rev.2 type apply only to States which are not parties to the NPT. It has not been found necessary to include special safeguards procedures for enrichment plants in INFCIRC/66/Rev.2 because there is no enrichment plant at present subject to safeguards under an agreement of the INFCIRC/66/Rev.2 type.

(2) The IAEA conducts inspections of the enrichment plants subject to its safeguards. The IAEA has for some time been giving detailed consideration to the question of further developing procedures for safeguarding uranium enrichment plants and has held a number of meetings on this subject. The IAEA is also currently participating in a six-party study of the safeguarding of enrichment plants of the centrifuge type. As noted in the article referred to, IAEA safeguards are not static, but are continuously evolving.

(3) The Australian Government is participating actively in the ongoing consideration of developing procedures for safeguarding uranium enrichment plants by the IAEA and is participating in the six-party study of the safe- guarding of enrichment plants of the centrifuge type referred to in (2). Australia also has a program to assist the nuclear safeguards capability of the IAEA which lays emphasis on the development of safeguards techniques and instrumentation for uranium enrichment plants.

(4) In accordance with the Government's nuclear safeguards policy, Australian uranium exported under new contracts must be subject to a nuclear safeguards agreement between Australia and the importing country. Each of Australia's nuclear safeguards agreements incorporates a treaty commitment by the government of the recipient country not to use nuclear material subject to the agreement for nuclear weapons, nuclear explosive devices or other military purposes. Each agreement also provides for nuclear material subject to the agreement to be covered by IAEA safeguards in accordance with the recipient country's safeguards agreement with the IAEA. Verification that Australian origin nuclear material may not be diverted to non-peaceful or explosive purposes is carried out under the arrangements set out in these agreements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

ANSWER.PARA: Corporate income tax payable by overseas-owned companies is not distinguished from that payable by Australian companies in the income tax statistics, except that separate statistics of non-resident companies are tabulated. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I assume that the honourable member's question refers to that element of the Commonwealth's expenditure on road safety under appropriation code 970/01, ' Grants to the States for the Promotion of Road Safety Practices'. These grants to the States comprised $150,000 for each financial year from 1970-71 until 1979 -80. In 1980-81 this grant was increased to $153,000 to include an amount payable to the Northern Territory. The grants to be payable in the present financial year will also be $153,000.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the claim made earlier this year by the Chase Econometrics Group that (a) the cost of power in Australia to the smelting industry is about 30 per cent lower than in the United States of America, and (b) the Department of Industry and Commerce, Australia/Japan Joint Study Group Report (AGPS 1980) indicated that Alcan production at Goodwood (Wide Bay Burnett Electricity Board Area) Queensland, will mean a loss of State revenue on coal alone of $207 per tonne of aluminium.
(2) Is there any substance to this claim; if so, can the Minister justify this subsidising of power, without public assessment of how many smelters will be needed

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of a document entitled 'Economic Aspects of Bauxite/Aluminium Industry'. This is the text of a speech presented by Mr Thomas G. Langton, Director, Light Metals Service of Chase Econometrics to the International Symposium on the Bauxite/Aluminium Industry in the Americas on 25 June 1980.

I am also aware of a report published in 1980 under the auspices of the Australia/Japan Joint Study Group on Raw Materials Processing entitled ' Australian and Japanese Aluminium Smelting Industries: Future Development and Relationship' which contains reference to a possible new Alcan aluminium smelter at Gladstone in Queensland.

The comparison of electricity costs in Australia and the United States included in the document referred to in (1) (a) above is in relation only to electricity from new generating facilities, and not to current costs in the two countries. With regard to part (1) (b) of the honourable member's question, I am not aware of the basis on which he has drawn his conclusion from the report. (2) Yes-both officers travelled in 1979 on similar duties, primarily related to purchase of rapid intervention vehicles. (a) Departed Australia 26 June 1979, returned Australia 22 July 1979 (Gascoigne), 29 July 1979 (Davis). (b) As for 1( d) except travel related to rapid intervention vehicles. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 27 October 1981:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The transfer of Cairns aerodrome to local ownership took place on 14 December 1981 and proposed development works are to be carried out by the Cairns Port Authority. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 28 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the waste oil re-refining industry considered important (a) overseas and (b) in Australia.
(2) Does nearly all the heavy crude suitable for lube oil production come from overseas.
(3) Should re-refining be encouraged instead of burning.
(4) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to allegations of pressure being exerted by oil companies on waste oil collectors not to sell to re-refiners but to burners.
(5) Can the Government do anything about this situation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Some overseas countries have taken steps to promote re-refining, notably New Zealand, South Africa, West Germany and Italy. I understand the United States of America is also seeking to encourage re-refining. In some other countries steps have been taken to encourage greater collection of waste oil as an environmental measure but, with the exceptions mentioned above, I am not aware of any special emphasis on re-refining.

(b) There is only one small scale waste oil re-refinery operating in Australia at the present time. Development of a larger industry on a commercial basis would reduce Australia's dependence on imported oil.

(3) Yes, provided sufficient volumes of suitable feedstock can be collected to make re-refining economically viable. It should be noted, however, that blending of waste oil with fuel oil for burning as an industrial fuel also reduces our dependence on imported oil.

(4) and (5) I am advised that some oil companies are offering a higher price for waste oil delivered to their refineries than the re-refiner operating in Sydney is prepared to pay. One of the consequences of this is that a larger volume of waste oil from a wider geographic area is now being collected, and waste oil that might otherwise become an environmental hazard is being recovered . It would not be appropriate for the Government to attempt to direct sales to one buyer rather than another.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Domestic Flights: Closure of Aircraft Doors

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the fact that TAA and Ansett are closing the doors of aircraft up to 10 minutes before the scheduled departure time and that airline staff are refusing to open the aircraft doors for late arriving passengers even though such passengers may already have a seat allocation.

(2) Will he instruct the airlines to keep open the doors of aircraft on scheduled flights so that passengers that are delayed may travel on the flight for which they are ticketed and have been allocated seats.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) I am neither aware of nor have I received any complaints on the matter to which the honourable member refers.

However, I have raised the matter with the airlines and am advised that although TAA and Ansett employ different practices concerning seat allocation and door closure, neither close aircraft doors 10 minutes before scheduled departure.

TAA passengers are asked to register for seat allocation 20 minutes before scheduled departure but seat allocation continues until the doors are closed. Unreserved seats and unclaimed reserved seats are released to standby passengers from eight minutes before scheduled departure and the aircraft doors are closed not earlier than three minutes before schedule departure, and even then closure is permitted only if all waiting passengers have been cleared.

Ansett's aircraft doors are closed within the last two minutes of departure while seat allocation is closed 10 minutes before scheduled departure in order to finalise pre-flight procedures. Within this time period full-fare wait listed passengers and standby passengers are allocated seats while operational procedures relating to the aircraft's trim sheet and verification of actual numbers on board are carried out.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Transport: Air Navigation Charges

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do the Budget Revenue Estimates for 1981-82 show that a sum of $3.37m was outstanding in air navigation charges from prior years as at 30 June 1981.
(2) Is he able to say who are the debtors and the individual sums comprising the $3.37m that is outstanding and for what period each of the sums has been outstanding.
(3) Why was there a delay in collecting this sum in air navigation charges.
(4) Are interest charges payable on outstanding air navigation charges; if so, what are the rates of interest charged and the associated conditions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2), (3) and (4) The amount of $3.37m in air navigation charges outstanding at 30 June 1981 mentioned in the Explanatory Notes to the Estimates of the Department of Transport was in respect of charges payable by two Australian airlines for operations they undertook towards the close of the year ended 30 June 1981. The amounts outstanding were paid early in 1981-82 and before the airlines were liable to pay interest.

Under Schedule 1 of the Air Navigation (Charges) Act 1952 by which charges for airline operations are raised, a charge under that Schedule becomes due and payable at the expiration of 28 days after the end of the month in which the flight, landing or takeoff to which the charge relates was completed.

Clause 5 (2) of the Act provides that where the liability of a person to pay a charge under this Act is not discharged within 45 days after the day on which that charge became due and payable, that person is liable to pay to the Commonwealth, by way of penalty, in addition to the amount of that charge, an amount calculated upon the amount of that charge remaining unpaid at the rate of one per cent for each month or part of a month for which that amount is unpaid, to be computed from the day on which that charge became due and payable.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Transport Estimates: Radio Communications Licence Fees

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that Martin's Refineries Pty Ltd in Sydney is the only re- refinery of waste lubricants existing in Australia.
(2) Is the entire output of this refinery readily marketed.
(3) Are the only alternative means of disposing waste oil burning or dumping.

(4) Does the re-refining of waste oil have a number of advantages, such as the conservation of energy used in the production of lubricating oils, and the lessening of dependence on imported heavy crude.
(5) Can the Minister say what measures are taken in countries such as the United States of America, New Zealand, South Africa, Canada and Western Europe to promote re-refining of waste oils.

(6) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the fact that the high level of vertical integration in the oil industry means that large oil companies effectively control the supply of waste oil, necessary for re-refining.
(7) Is there evidence that these companies have a vested interest in preventing the sale of re-refined oil in competition with their own oils.
(8) What is the current price paid for waste oil by major oil companies in Sydney and what is the price paid in other capital cities, where no competition from re-refined oil exists.
(9) Will the Minister investigate claims that major oil companies in Sydney are inflating the price of waste oil to destroy the re-refining industry; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) Used lubricating oil, as well as being blended with fuel oil and burnt, in which case the full energy value of the oil is recovered, is also used for other purposes such as a wood preservative, as a weed-killer, and for laying dust on country roads.
(4) Yes. It should be noted, however, that blending of waste oil with fuel oil for burning as an industrial fuel also reduces our dependence on imported oil.
(5) By way of example, measures taken in the following countries are:

(i) United States of America-The United States Department of Energy is seeking to encourage re-refining to conserve energy and lubricating oil, and to reduce degradation of the environment. Heavy emphasis is placed on re-refining but not to the exclusion of processing for use as a fuel or other acceptable uses such as in asphalt.

(ii) Japan-Present annual consumption of lubricating oil is 2000 megalitres of which 500 megalitres is recovered. Of this 95 per cent is blended with fuel oil for burning while the balance is re-refined by the acid clay process. The Environmental Control Service Corporation assists industries in the disposal of all wastes by low interest loans covering up to 30 per cent of the cost of construction of waste disposal and treatment facilities.

(iii) New Zealand-It is Government policy to encourage the re-refining of waste lubricating oil. A subsidy, believed to be 2.5 cents per litre, is paid on used oil collected and delivered to re-refiners. Re-refined oil is exempt from the 20 per cent sales tax that is levied on virgin lubricating oils.

(iv) EEC-The EEC Council adopted a directive on 16 June 1975 relating to disposal of waste oil by a compulsory collection system. The emphasis is on collection as an environmental measure but, with the exception of Italy, I am not aware of any special emphasis on re-refining. In Italy a Bill has been introduced requiring that waste oil be re-refined. Taxes on re-refined oil are one third of those on virgin oil but it is intended that the differential tax system will eventually be eliminated.

(v) South Africa-I understand that in South Africa regulations prohibit the use and disposal of waste oil other than by delivery to a re-refiner. The regulations cover metropolitan and urban areas only. All lubricant sellers are obliged to receive waste oil from the public. Waste oil collection is handled entirely by private operators within the framework of the regulations.

(6) The premise on which this part of the question is based is incorrect. Large oil companies do not own waste oil unless they buy it from waste oil collectors. New oil is sold to consumers as a normal part of the oil industry's operations but the industry has no control over what happens to it once they have sold it.
(8) Prices paid by major oil companies to collectors for waste oil are determined by commercial negotiation between the oil company and the waste oil collector. I am not privy to these negotiations.

(9) I am aware that major oil companies in Sydney have recently increased the price they are prepared to pay to collectors for waste oil. I am advised that this is to encourage the collectors to sell the waste oil to the oil companies in preference to other purchasers, including enterprises which use it as a direct substitute for fuel oil. The oil companies at present blend the waste oil with fuel oil controlled quantities to prevent environmental problems. A viable re-refining industry requires substantial volumes of feedstock. Thus a potential re-refiner must be prepared to pay the market price of the waste oil's alternative use, i.e. burning as a fuel. I know of no justification for the suggested investigation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are staff of the Marine Standards Division and other Melbourne-based Central Office staff required to advise the Secretary to the Department by 3 December 1981 whether they will accept a transfer by 3 June 1982 to Queanbeyan, New South Wales.

(2) Did he on 17 September 1981, cast doubt on that location when he stated that the Government would be making a decision in the not too distant future regarding the location of staff being transferred to Canberra-Queanbeyan.
(3) Will he state whether that decision has now been made.

(4) If no firm decision has been made regarding a permanent site, will he defer the transfer of the staff concerned in view of the uncertainty and the consequential difficulties for staff not only in making the far-reaching decision as to whether to accept transfer but also as to where to purchase property so as to be close to the location of their workplace.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) When notices of transfer were issued to staff in May 1981 it was the intention then that some staff would be located in Canberra and some in Queanbeyan. Since then arrangements have been made to accommodate in Canberra all of the staff who were required to advise the Secretary to the Department by 3 December 1981 of their intention concerning the transfer.

(2) I said on 17 September 1981, that there had been some objections expressed about Queanbeyan as a transfer location and that discussions were continuing concerning adequate accommodation facilities.
(3) A decision on whether or not elements of my Department will be housed in Queanbeyan has not been made. The Government is still considering a Canberra- Queanbeyan accommodation strategy.
(4) No. It should be noted that it is proposed to consolidate the Central Office of my Department in the Canberra City East area by the completion of the 1984 Canberra Transfer Program.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that little support is being offered to the ethnic aged; if so , is this currently posing enormous problems to migrant families and agencies.
(2) Will this situation become worse since the aging population is increasing.
(3) What action can he take to alleviate this problem.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The ethnic aged are entitled to the full range of pensions and benefits provided through the Department of Social Security, subject to the same conditions as apply to the rest of the community. To qualify for age pension, a person must, among other things, generally have resided in Australia for a continuous period of not less than 10 years.
A person who is ineligible for age pension through lack of residence may be paid special benefit if he is unable to earn a sufficient livelihood.

Where a person was admitted to Australia on condition that another person would guarantee his maintenance, it is the responsibility of the guarantor to fulfil the terms of the undertaking. However, special benefit may be paid in such cases to the person concerned if the undertaking is not met. Under the Migration Regulations, the full amount of any such benefit paid becomes a debt due and payable to the Commonwealth by the guarantor.
Organisations representing the ethnic aged are also eligible to receive Commonwealth assistance for the construction of accommodation for and the provision of services to aged people.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What was the contribution to money supply growth from (a) private sector balance of payments surplus and (b) private capital inflow for each of the years 1970-71 to 1980-81 and what is the expected contribution in 1981-82.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The annual percentage point contribution to money supply (M3) growth of the external transactions of the private sector (PSFET) over the years 1970-71 to 1980-81 is tabulated below. The table also provides the total percentage point money supply growth.

(b) While private capital inflow (net) contributes to the growth of the domestic money supply, it does so only as one component of the private sector's foreign exchange transactions (PSFET); moreover, private capital inflow is not independent of other components of PSFET and hence could not be considered an independent source of changes in the domestic money supply any more than could, say, export receipts from the sale of wheat or (on the debit side) import payments for the purchase of motor vehicles.

The Budget documents indicated an expectation that the contribution of the external transactions of the private sector to money supply growth during 1981- 82 might be of a similar order of magnitude to the $2802m recorded in 1980-81. On that basis, the percentage point contribution to M3 growth would be 5.0 per cent. The Budget documents also indicated that the balance of payments outlook for 1981-82 is, as always, subject to many uncertainties. Accordingly, no particular importance was, or should be, attached to this figure.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that all but 29 of the 287 trawling licences for the Gulf of Carpentaria have been given to trans-national companies with up to 80 per cent foreign ownership since 1977.

(2) Have many of these companies re-invested their profits to improve the technical standards of trawlers free of tax on these profits, with a 27 1/2 per cent Commonwealth subsidy to new vessels over 21 metres, and a 20 per cent investment allowance sufficient in some cases to offset the cost of the licence.

(3) Has his attention been drawn to claims of Queensland officials who have likened the prawning in the Gulf to mining, anticipating that it cannot continue on the present scale without devastating the resources.

(4) Is he able to say whether 1980 season banana prawns have been (a) sold at half the previous year's prices in Japan to interests connected with the trawling interests, thus reducing liability to Australian taxes, (b) processed in low tax regions and (c) largely re-exported to the United States of America and elsewhere.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. There are currently 292 vessels eligible to operate in the Declared Management Zone (DMZ) of the northern prawn fishery which includes the Gulf of Carpentaria. Full details of the share holdings of all companies operating in this fishery are not available, however, information available to my department indicates that three companies, which are entitled to operate a total of 63 vessels in the fishery, have significant foreign ownership. In addition, approximately 100 vessels are operated by individual persons or private companies.

(2) Since 1977, 10 vessels have been built under the Ship-building Bounty Scheme for operation in the DMZ by the three companies having significant foreign ownership. Of these, eight are replacement vessels (three being replacements for vessels lost in Cyclone Tracy) and two were constructed to complete obligations under a joint venture arrangement entered into prior to 1977. Original operators in the fishery paid no premium on licences and market prices for licences have varied widely in recent years. The extent to which Government assistance, such as the ship-building bounty and investment allowance , offsets the costs of licences and other expenses incurred in operating in the Gulf of Carpentaria cannot be readily determined.

(3) To my knowledge Queensland officials have not made such a statement and I believe it is not appropriate to compare prawning in the DMZ with mining. Although banana prawns in the Gulf of Carpentaria have been fully exploited since the early 1970's research has shown that environmental conditions during recruitment to the fishery are the major determinant of their abundance. Catches of other species in the DMZ have increased steadily since 1970-71, however, research to assess the status of these resources is not yet complete.

(4) Details of individual sales of prawns to Japanese commercial interests are not available and I am therefore unable to comment on the statements concerning disposal of the 1980 banana prawn catch. Should firm information concerning practices of this nature become available I shall ensure that it is investigated by the appropriate authorities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that on Tuesday, 27 October 1981, when an exceptionally heavy storm swept over much of southern and central Victoria, including Melbourne and Geelong, the State Emergency Services at Geelong were unable to obtain vital information about predictions of wind and weather conditions from the Bureau of Meteorology.

(2) If so, was the reason given for the inability to provide this information that economic restraints imposed as a result of cuts made following the Review of Commonwealth Functions meant that there were no personnel to provide these services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Regional Officer of the State Emergency Services (SES) Geelong has advised the Bureau of Meteorology that he has no specific complaint regarding the provision of meteorological information on 27 October 1981. However recently the SES indicated that it has a need for additional information on warnings of floods and severe storms. Arrangements for transmission of additional information to the SES were made at a meeting between the two organisations on 6 November 1981. These arrangements are understood to be satisfactory to the SES.
(2) Decisions based on the Review of Commonwealth Functions have not affected the service provided by the Bureau to the SES.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice , on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Who are the current members of the Australian Ballet Board and what has been the length of service of each.

(2) How many members are in the corps de ballet of the Australian Ballet and what is the (a) classification for each level of dancers; (b) salary award for each level; and (c) number of performances/hours of rehearsal required for personnel at each of the levels.
(3) What claims regarding salary and conditions are being made with respect to each of these levels.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) The Australian Ballet Foundation is not a Commonwealth Government organisation and as such it would not be appropriate for me to provide the details sought by the honourable member. In the circumstances, it is suggested that the honourable member approach the Australian Ballet Foundation direct for the information he seeks.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether the co-operative housing societies of New South Wales are one of the main avenues of funds for housing for those in greatest need and whether their lending is strictly regulated on the basis of means tests .
(2) Do the societies depend in part on funds raised from private sources, especially savings banks.

(3) Is it a fact that funds from the private savings banks have decreased from $9,240,000 in 1976-77 to $2,550,000 in 1980-81 whilst the Commonwealth Bank and Rural Bank contributions increased from $3,100,000 to $5,570,000 in the same period.
(4) Will he and his colleague, the Treasurer, exert some moral pressure on the private banks to at least maintain their contributions at the real value of 1976 -77 levels.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In 1980-81 the co-operative housing societies of New South Wales approved housing loans totalling $103,753,000, compared to loans totalling $2,820,831,000 approved to individuals in New South Wales by all significant lenders. While banks and permanent building societies are the major sources of housing finance, providing $2,224,187,000 in 1980-81, the co-operative housing societies in New South Wales have traditionally directed lending to home seekers in the lower income brackets.

Since 1956, co-operative housing societies of New South Wales have been the principal agents of the home purchase assistance program. To date some $692m in Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement funds have been channelled through co- operative housing societies for on-lending to low income earners. Societies received $59.6m from this source in 1980-81 and were able to approve 1753 loans, approximately 2 per cent of all housing loans approved in New South Wales.

Home purchase assistance program loans made by co-operative housing societies of New South Wales are regulated on the basis of means tests with the objective of providing assistance to those most in need. For applicants to be eligible, they should not be able to obtain finance in the open market or from other sources. Available funds are allocated on the basis of the Loan Request List which was introduced in June 1978. This list includes all applicants and ensures that assistance to those with an immediate need is first priority. Classification of applicants takes account of each family's circumstances including income, dependants and net assets. The specific need test adopted is a matter for the State Governments.
(2) Traditionally, co-operative housing societies in New South Wales have relied on a mixture of government and private funds. The main sources of funds in 1980-81 were:
Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement 59,610,000 Guaranteed private funds
Banks 8,120,000 Insurance companies 100,000 Other lenders 6,000,000 Non- guaranteed funds 37,018,000
Private savings banks provided $2,500,000 of the total of $110,848,000 available in 1980-81.
(3) In recent years contributions by the traditional institutional lenders such as private savings banks have decreased.
(4) It is a matter for the private banks to determine their own investment decisions within the prevailing economic circumstances.
