ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: HIFAR Reactor: Lucas Heights, New South Wales

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the question of earthquake damage enter into the original design of the HIFAR Reactor at Lucas Heights, New South Wales; if so, what specific measures against this damage were incorporated in the construction of the reactor; if not , what level on the Richter Scale is the reactor and buildings capable of withstanding.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Because HIFAR was not to be located in or close to a major fault zone, resistance to earthquake damage was not a specific requirement in its original design. However, the conservative design of the reactor and containment building provides inherent protection against earthquakes.

It is not possible to give a specific level on the Richter Scale which the reactor and buildings are capable of withstanding as this is dependent on the location of the earthquake, the propagation path between it and the reactor and the geological conditions at the site of the reactor.
The seismic safety of the reactor was reviewed in 1972, and calculations showed that the containment building could withstand predicted seismic activity in the region of the Sydney Basin.

As the data, knowledge and techniques used in such reviews are continually evolving, they are normally updated at intervals. Accordingly, in May 1980 the Commission requested the Department of Housing and Construction to independently review the seismic risk at Lucas Heights. This study is still in progress.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the Workers' Compensation Board of Western Australia was instructed by the Commonwealth Commissioner of Taxation that, in future, interest earned on monies invested on behalf of widows whose husbands died as a result of work caused injuries would be taxable.
(2) If so, what was the reason for the Commissioner's decision to tax this previously untaxed income.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Workers' compensation payments are held in trust for dependants of deceased workers. Income derived from the investment of those funds is required to be declared for income tax purposes.

(2) This form of income has always been liable to tax. However, the Commissioner of Taxation has advised that the amounts of income derived from these sources in past years have, in many cases, been below the limits on which tax becomes payable.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Perth Airport: Compensation for Local Residents

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his Department sought information from local government authorities around the Perth Airport as to their views on appropriate means for compensating local residents affected by aircraft noise and air pollution arising from usage of the airport.

(2) If so, was this request a result of the suggestion by the Joint Governmental Committee on Perth Airport Developments that a trade-off should be made between a decision not to proceed with a parallel north/south runway and compensation to residents and institutions affected as a result.

(3) Is this request an indication that the Government intends to introduce legislation to permit payment of compensation for residents injuriously affected by usage of Commonwealth installations such as airports; if so, when will the legislation be brought before Parliament and, in particular, will it precede future developmental work at Perth Airport.

(4) Given the cost involved for the local government authorities undertaking, at the Government's request, the research on the environmental impact of the airport on local residents, will he consider reimbursing the councils the cost of their efforts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. My Department sought, from local councils, information on appropriate methods of costing environmental impacts-particularly aircraft noise-associated with alternative development strategies for Perth Airport. One method suggested to my Department was to use the cost of sound insulation of affected residences as a guide.

(2) No. This information was sought as input to the master plan for Perth Airport which my Department is producing. The Commonwealth-State Advisory Committee to Study Western Australia's Airport Requirements recommended that the master plan should be based on a detailed analysis of airport development options and their impact on the environment and land use.
(4) No, particularly as the local government authorities themselves elected to undertake such detailed considerations of this matter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister able to say whether Vietnam veterans are arranging, at their own expense, to have (a) general examination of sperm and (b) peripheral blood chromosomal studies carried out by reputable doctors.
(2) If so, has the Department of Veterans' Affairs made any attempt to monitor the results of the two types of studies referred to in part (1) and if it has, what are the details.

(3) Has the Department ordered these tests for any Vietnam veterans seeking repatriation benefits; if so, in how many cases and during what period, giving the figures for each fiscal year, if appropriate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Veterans' Affairs has no information on procedures arranged by veterans at their own expense, other than that publicly available.
(2) Apart from monitoring reports in the medical literature, the Department is not in a position to monitor activities carried out outside its organisation.
(3) In 1980-81 a total of six blood chromosome tests were ordered for Vietnam veterans and four seminal fluid tests. No abnormalities were discovered in these tests.
Chromosome tests have only recently been requested in a further seven cases and the results are not yet available.

Additionally, a total of 11 persons, including veterans and/or their wives, have been referred to the infertility clinic or genetic counselling service of major hospitals for a variety of problems. The results of these referrals showed no abnormality.

(3) Is any existing United States of America or joint Australian-US facility in Australia capable of making ELF transmissions.
(4) Will he give an assurance that there are no proposals to establish an ELF facility in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has Telecom Australia received complaints from private and business subscribers concerning unsolicited phone calls from business establishments or fund raising authorities seeking sales or donations.
(2) If so, has the incidence of the unsolicited calls increased over the last 12 months compared to the previous 12 month period.
(3) What action does he propose to take in respect of these calls.
(4) Will he consider recommending to Telecom that it establish in each capital city a telephone inquiry number which subscribers may call to voice their complaint about unsolicited calls.
(5) Is this proposal considered consistent with the statement issued by Telecom Australia (pr 10/81) entitled 'Telecommunications and society-Telecom's new educational package'.
(6) Did the statement express the view that belonging to an organisation like Telecom impinges on the lives of most Australians and makes it imperative to have a social conscience.

(7) Would the establishment of a complaints number for unsolicited phone calls as outlined in part (4) be indicative of Telecom's social conscience, as indicated in the statement referred to in part (6).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Telecom does not maintain records of this nature. However, the continued operation of telephone sales promotional organisations is indicative of a section of the community accepting it as being a legitimate form of selling or of fund raising.

(3) Telecom has the power under its legislation to prevent the connection to the telephone network of automatic subsequential dialling equipment which, in Telecom's view, would not be acceptable to the Australian community generally.
(4) Telecom feels that the more positive action is for offended called parties to voice their feelings at the time an unsolicited call is received.

(5) Telecom would not see the establishment of the proposed centre as being either consistent or inconsistent with its social conscience. Being aware, on the one hand, that a number of people object to receiving unsolicited sales calls and, on the other, that some sections of the community would resent a public authority attempting to regulate how a telephone may be used, Telecom considers that the most constructive and effective role it can play is to encourage initiatives for self regulation by telephone sales organisations. For instance, in its discussions with the Australian Direct Marketing Association on ethical sales practices and the like, that organisation has assured Telecom that once a subscriber registers with any of its member companies that he objects to being called, then this request is circulated to, and honoured by, all its member companies.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it the intention of the Government to impose a sales tax on non-profit newspapers and journals produced by religious organisations.
(2) If so, is it a fact that this tax will apply even to those journals and newspapers which are free, and which therefore involve no sale.
(3) Can a tax imposed on these journals be regarded correctly as a sales tax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Government has stated its intention of imposing sales tax at the rate of 2 1/2 per cent in respect of a range of goods, including newspapers and journals, as from 29 March 1982. Under these proposals, newspapers and journals produced for religious organisations by printing firms will attract sales tax at that rate.

However, some religious organisations print their own newspapers and journals. While the materials used to produce publications bear tax at the time of purchase, the publications themselves may not bear sales tax because the particular religious organisation is not in the business of publishing magazines and journals or, in the event that it is, the average annual sales do not exceed $12,000.
(3) Sales tax legislation applies not only to goods sold but also to goods imported, goods leased and to goods given away or otherwise applied to a person' s own use.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did his Department circulate promotional information (e.g. posters) to publicise World Food Day on 16 October 1981, to local government authorities throughout Australia.
(2) If so, why was this information delivered three days after World Food Day and what was the cost of printing and circulating this information.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The Department was operating to a tight timetable in planning and organising activities for this the first World Food Day. Recognising this it sought the assistance of other government agencies in the preparation of material and outside assistance in despatching the material once it was ready. Despite this effort, some local government authorities did not receive the posters until after World Food Day.
World Food Day is an annual event and the design of the posters allows local government authorities to use the posters in future years, should they so wish.
The cost of printing and circulating the World Food Day material to local government authorities was approximately $1,000.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 18 November 1981 :

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the admission of the Queensland Minister for Northern Development and Maritime Services published in the Courier Mail of 11 November 1981 to the effect that oil spill equipment presently available under the National Plan to Combat Oil Pollution was meant mainly for use in smooth water.

(2) Is it a fact that (a) the first Vikoma Seaboom sank on 1 November 1981 when used to contain oil spillage from the Anro Asia, (b) the second boom obtained from Sydney was beached on 2 November 1981 and (c) both booms failed due to unfavourable weather conditions and rough seas.

(3) Is any equipment presently held by the National Plan designed to be effective in handling oil pollution in rough seas; if not, will he take steps to have suitable equipment purchased and added to the National Plan equipment holding.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, I am aware of the statement made by the Queensland Minister for Northern Development and Maritime Services. Equipment used during the incident was the most suitable available at the time of purchase. Oil spill equipment presently available is suitable for use off-shore in moderate weather conditions .
(b) The second boom obtained from Sydney was beached on the morning of 3 November 1981.

(c) The first boom sank due to mechanical failure of the pump used to keep the boom inflated. The second boom was washed ashore as a result of adverse weather conditions, which occurred at short notice. It would have been hazardous for personnel to have attempted to retrieve the booms during the prevailing weather conditions.

(3) In rough seas, oil spillage is generally dissipated by wave and wind action . Equipment presently held by the National Plan is designed to be most effective during moderate weather conditions. Developments currently taking place overseas in equipment technology are being closely monitored. Should suitable equipment become available for use during adverse weather conditions, then its procurement will be considered.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Response to Hijacking of Aircraft

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 5 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a proposal by Lord Duncan-Sandys that nations with key airports should announce that they will return plane hijackers to their country of origin and boycott flights to and from nations which do not agree to do the same.
(2) What progress has Australia made in consideration of the proposal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) My attention has not been drawn to the proposal by Lord Duncan- Sandys that nations with key airports should announce that they will return hijackers to their country of origin and boycott flights to and from nations which do not agree to do the same.

The Government has, however, endorsed the Bonn declaration on terrorism made on 17 July 1978 by the seven heads of state and heads of government which attended the Economic Summit Meeting in Bonn. The English version of that statement reads as follows:

The Heads of State and Governments concerned about terrorism and the taking of hostages declare that their Governments will intensify their joint efforts to combat international terrorism. To this end in cases where a country refuses extradition or prosecution of those who have hijacked an aircraft and/or do not return such aircraft, the Heads of State and Governments shall take immediate action to cease all flights to that country. At the same time, their Governments will initiate action to halt all incoming flights from that country, or from any country by the airlines of the country concerned.
They urge other Governments to join them in this commitment.

The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) informed the House on 26 September 1978 that the Commonwealth Government strongly supported the constructive action taken by the 'Bonn Seven' against the threat of terrorism and that the Government agreed completely with the objectives of the declaration. He said, ' Australian support of the Bonn declaration means that we consider ourselves committed to its objectives' (Hansard, 26 September 1978, page 1360).
The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) in response to the Prime Minister's statement said that the Opposition supported the action of the Government in endorsing the Bonn statement on terrorism.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Mineral Rights Held by Australian Government

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What mineral rights are held by the Australian Government in (a) Singleton Army Reserve (b) other defence reserves (c) Aboriginal reserves and (d) other crown land.
(2) When, how and from whom were these rights acquired in each case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Information in respect of all matters referred to in the honourable member's question is not readily available. To collect and assemble it would be a major task and it has not been the practice of successive ministers to authorise the expenditure of money and effort involved in assembling such information on a general basis. The following information, however, may assist the honourable member.

When the Commonwealth acquires title to land by voluntary transfer it acquires the mineral rights if the vendor owns them and if the instrument of transfer so provides. Although there have been some exceptions, it is the normal process to acquire mineral rights when the Commonwealth acquires title to land under statutory powers of compulsory acquisition. I am informed that the Commonwealth owns the mineral rights in most of the land known as the Singleton Army Training Area.

If the honourable member should be interested to know the position as to Commonwealth interest in the mineral rights in any other particular parcel of land, I would be prepared to consider obtaining that information for him.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Information about Overseas Visits by Members of Parliament

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 22 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of the reply given to Senate question No. 996 (Senate Hansard, 15 September 1981, page 739) rejecting suggestions that his Department improperly provides information about the activities of members of parliament to anyone, does he regard State Government Ministers as proper recipients of information about overseas activities of State members of parliament; if so, what are the reasons for providing this information.

(2) Does his Department provide regular restricted reports on Australian personnel in overseas countries to State Ministers; if so, what personnel and what factors decide the restricted nature of reports.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The question is phrased in general terms but I understand that it relates to comment made by Mr Chatterton, MLC, South Australia, following a visit he made to certain North African and European countries, and in particular to Algeria. Mr Chatterton asserted that during his visit he was subject to surveillance by the Department of Foreign Affairs and that reports on his visit were sent to his political opponents.

These allegations are not true. What is true, and what appears to be a source of concern to Mr Chatterton, is that advice was passed to the South Australian authorities of a planned visit by Mr Chatterton to an agricultural development project in Algeria for which the South Australian Government has contracted to provide expertise. While it is the case, as Mr Chatterton has stated, that it is for the Algerians rather than the South Australians to say who visits the project, I do not regard it as improper that a State government should be advised of planned visits to what we in Australia would regard as a State project. There was no request by Mr Chatterton that his visit be concealed from the State authorities responsible for the project.
The answer to the second part of the honourable member's question is 'No'.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 22 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will he urgently consult with Telecom Australia to facilitate the provision of Porta Printer type telephone receivers for the deaf being made available to profoundly deaf persons on a reasonable rental basis.
(2) Has his attention been drawn to the fact that the purchase price of these receivers is so high that it precludes almost every deaf person from being able to afford one.
(3) Is he able to say whether these receivers have been made available on a very reasonable rental or lease basis to many deaf persons in the United States of America.

(4) In this International Year of Disabled Persons will the grievous and distressing handicap of deafness be recognised, the difficulties in normal communication conceded and the assistance a telephone as a life line or distress signal would provide to the deaf be understood.
(5) What positive action can profoundly deaf people expect as a result of many pronouncements of concern for the handicapped in this special year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Porta Printer, like many other devices available for use by the disabled, is but one of a wide range of products approved by Telecom for connection to the network and marketed by private enterprise. In the case of the Porta Printer, Telecom is acting as a distributor for the importer-Intercept Communications Pty Ltd-to make it easier for deaf people throughout Australia to obtain and utilise this new product.

Telecom has advised me that it has given consideration to the suggestion of making the Porta Printer available on a rental basis but regrets it is not in a position to include in its range of customer facilities special equipment of this type, for which at this stage there is a fairly limited demand.

(2) It is understood that the sale price of a Porta Printer Plus is $996 to Government Departments and Commercial Organisations, and $846 if sold to disabled persons and their respective institutions.
(3) Telecom advised that it is only aware of one area, viz California, which provides telephone typewriters to deaf people at a subsidised rate.

(4) and (5) Telecom assures me that it is mindful of the needs of the disabled and is contributing resources and expertise towards increasing the range and availability of products for the disabled generally. However, it is of the opinion that financial assistance to make facilities such as the Porta Printer more readily available to the disabled should be funded by taxpayers generally through the Government's social security programmes rather than by other users of telecommunications services.

Separate statistics have not been maintained categorising visits as routine inspections or surveys. However, over the period the ratio would be approximately 10: 1.

to develop a viable explosive cable cutter to reduce accidents in aerial agriculture resulting from wire strikes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Following the decision to purchase the FA18 aircraft and the upgrading of Darwin airbase to permit its deployment from that base, has the Government considered, upgrading facilities at Learmonth and Derby, Western Australia, to permit easier temporary deployment of the aircraft from these airfields.
(2) Does the Government intend to construct air defence radar and missile systems at any or both of these two facilities.
(3) What alterations will be required to weapons replenishment facilities to facilitate the FA18's deployment from Derby and Learmonth.
(4) Will any additional fuelling facilities be required.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Work now in progress at Learmonth would assist the deployment of FA18 aircraft from that airfield. Works proposed at Derby will enable it to support a tactical fighter squadron, together with strike, maritime and transport aircraft .
(2) Not at this time. These systems could be developed at Learmonth and Derby if the need arises.

(3) and (4) The weapons replenishment and fuelling facilities required at the bases will depend mainly on the operations to be conducted. For the types of operations currently envisaged, no significant alterations or additions to the replenishment and fuelling facilities already planned will be necessary to enable FA18 deployments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that amateur fishermen who want maximum safety on their boats have to buy 2 radios, one for the 27 megahertz marine band the use of which is not permitted for vessel to shore communication except in the case of registered clubs and rescue organisations, and the other for the normal CB range which allows communications with a wide range of shore bases.
(2) Is it also a fact that there are radio sets now available which could adequately handle both bands and save the expense of buying two sets; if so, what are these sets.
(3) Will he undertake to amend regulations to permit this dual use; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Amateur fishermen requiring maximum safety radiocommunications carry a radio transceiver capable of transmitting and receiving on at least 2182, 4125 and 6215.5 kilohertz. Such equipment enables around the clock communication over substantial distances via Coast Radio Stations of the Overseas Telecommunications Commission. Though permitted, it is considered that carriage of either or both 27 megahertz inshore boating radio service or citizens band radio service equipment, provides a more restricted measure of safety.

My Department's technical specifications pertaining to equipment used by small craft vary according to the frequency bands for which the apparatus is designed. The specification for the inshore boating radio service is not compatible with the requirements of the citizens band radio service. Consequently manufacturers do not produce equipment capable of such multi-purpose operation.

It is considered essential, in order to ensure orderly operations of the various radiocommunication services, that equipment is not authorised which would enable licensees of one radio service to participate in another service as distinct from the service in which they are authorised to operate.
(3) No, for the reasons previously explained.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Where service personnel are required to take part in continuous duty over an extended period, such as participation in exercises, are additional payments made in respect of the extra days; if so, are these payments automatic and inclusive of all days covered by normal duty patterns.

(2) Does the commanding officer have the right to determine that less than the total additional duty days will be subject to additional payment; if so, what is the criteria for applying any reduction.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Additional payments are not made in respect of the extra days where regular service personnel are required to take part in continuous duty over an extended period, such as participation in exercises. However, service allowance, payable at the rate of $2500 a year (formerly $1625 up to 4 November 1981), is paid principally as recompense for the need to be on call at all times and to work long and irregular hours. In assessing the quantum, the fact that time off in lieu is granted on some occasions was taken into account. The time off in lieu provisions in these circumstances are:

(a) Extra recreation leave of up to five working days per year may be credited to a member in recompense for arduous, special or prolonged periods of duty not otherwise compensated for (by way of leave) during the preceding year; and/or
(b) Short leave may be granted to an eligible member for compensation in respect of long or unusual duty for a period in respect of which no other leave is applicable.
Disability oriented allowances also are paid in respect of operational training and service in seagoing ships.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Tranet Tracking Station, Smithfield, South Australia: Satellites

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of his answer to question No. 713 (Hansard, 7 April 1981, page 1422 ), can he provide a complete list of all satellites ever tracked by the TRANET Station at Smithfield, South Australia.
(2) What were or are the functions of each of these satellites, eg navigation, geodesy, etc.
(3) What were or are the formal designations, orbital parameters and dates of launch of each of these satellites.
(4) What were the periods over which Smithfield was involved with each of these satellites.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) The TRANET Station has been operating for more than 20 years and comprehensive records of the individual satellites tracked by it are not available over the whole of this period. The satellite programs with which the station has been associated have all, however, been connected with navigation or geodesy.

To provide what information may be available about the satellites previously tracked by the station in the detail that has been requested by the honourable member would require the diversion of significant departmental resources and I am not prepared to authorise this.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report prepared by the United States of America State Department's Bureau of East Asian and Pacific Affairs dealing with the defence needs of Australia and South Pacific nations in relation to the United States' presence in the region.
(2) What liaison did the State Department have with the Australian Government in the preparation of this survey.
(3) Is one of the recommendations of this report that the United States' presence should be expanded in the South Pacific to minimise any threats of stability.

(4) Does the study suggest that Australia's main concern in the South Pacific lies in the fear that a future Indonesian Government could develop ambitions to move against Papua New Guinea or that political instability within Papua New Guinea itself could threaten Australian political and economic interests in that country.

(5) Is his Department in agreement with the findings of the United States State Department's report; if not, has he notified the State Department through the appropriate channels of his Department's disagreement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (5) As far as the Government is aware no report of the type referred to by the honourable member has been prepared by the United States of America State Department Bureau of East Asian and Pacific Affairs. I understand however that a State Department officer did prepare a paper which considers defence issues in our region as part of his course of study at the United States National War College. As such, the paper is an expression of personal views and carries no form of State Department endorsement. Indeed I understand that the author specifically states in his paper that the views expressed are his own and not those of the State Department.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to (a) the Journal of Occupational Medicine, 19 (1) 1977, pages 11-87, suggesting that Australian Research is necessary to establish the adequacy of controls in those countries from which we appear to be formulating our environmental health protection policy, (b) section 3.3.1. of the Supplementary Report of the same issue of the journal referred to in part (1 ) (a), which gives fluoride emission figures as 0.2 micrograms per cubic metre ( mcg/m3) (c) the Newcastle Ecology Centre NSW claim that almost half of the tonnage of uoride going into the Lochinvar Smelter yearly is unaccounted for and (d) the opinion of the Australian Chemical Industry Council in August 1980 that many of the present regulations applying to hazardous chemicals are fragmented inadequate difficult to follow and nonuniform from State to State

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Who are the members of the surveillance committee appointed recently to monitor work on recombinant DNA and related biotechnological subjects, supervising proposed research and commercial uses, giving in each case the names of the members, their academic qualifications and areas of professional expertise.
(2) Is it a fact that the Committee does not include representatives of broad community and non-economic/ technical interests, e.g. public health, moral philosophy and the law.

(3) Is it also a fact that comparable supervisory committees in other countries include representation of broader community interests; if so, what are the details and why has Australia chosen not to follow the overseas examples.

(4) Has his attention been drawn to the claim of the Chairman of the Australian Law Reform Commission, Mr Justice Kirby, that the ethical problems raised by genetic engineering are too serious to be left to scientists alone; if so, is there any substance to this claim.
(5) Does he consider that a committee of scientists, bureaucrats and businessmen is also too narrow; if so, what does he intend to do about this proposal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The names and academic qualifications of the members of the Committee and its Scientific Sub-committee together with the expertise of each member as indicated by their present positions are set out below:
Membership of Recombinant DNA Monitoring Committee
Dr N. F. Millis, M.B.E., M.Ag.Sc., Ph.D. (Chairman)-Reader, Department of Microbiology, University of Melbourne.
Dr B. D. Booth, B.Sc., Ph.D.-Scientific Director, Wellcome Australia.
Dr B. M. Comben, M.Sc., Ph.D.-Managing Director, Sigma Company Ltd.
Professor R. Johnston, B.Sc., Ph.D.-Chairman, Department of History and Philosophy of Science, University of Wollongong.
Dr L. Dobson, M.B., B.S., D.C.P., D.Phil (Oxon)-Director of National Biological Standards Laboratory, (representative of Department of Health).
R. W. Gee, B.V.Sc.-Director, Bureau of Animal Health (representative of Department of Primary Industry).
*Professor G. L. Ada, (Chairman of Scientific Sub-committee) D.Sc.-Department of Microbiology, John Curtin School of Medical Research, ANU.
*Dr W. J. Peacock, B.Sc., Ph.D.-Chief, Division of Plant Industry, CSIRO.
*Dr E. L. French, M.Sc., Ph.D.-Consultant to the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories.
Dr J. D. Bell, M.Sc., Ph.D.-Assistant Secretrary, Science and Technology Policy Branch, Department of Science and Technology (representative of Department of Science and Technology).
Dr R. Francki, M.Sc., Ph.D.-Reader, Department of Plant Pathology, Waite Agricultural Research Institute, S.A.
Dr J. Shine, B.Sc., Ph.D.-Associate Director, Centre for Recombinant DNA Research, ANU.
Professor A. J. Pittard, Dip.Pharm., D.Sc., Ph.D.-Department of Microbiology, University of Melbourne.
Professor R. G. Wake, M.Sc., Ph.D.-Department of Biochemistry, University of Sydney.
* The asterisk signifies those persons on the Committee who are also members of the Scientific Sub-committee.

The first part of the question implies a wider role for the Committee than it actually possesses. The terms of reference call upon the Committee to assess whether new biological hazards are likely to be associated with the application of recombinant DNA technology and to see that this new technology is used only under safe conditions. No other form of biomedical manipulation or biotechnological process is to be monitored by the Committee.

(2) Members were chosen because of their technical expertise relevant to the terms of reference of the Committee. Except for the nominees of the three Commonwealth departments, members were not chosen as representatives of particular groups or organisations.

The Committee includes scientists some of whom have particular knowledge of recombinant DNA technology and others who are expert in fields relevant to the safety of the technology. The businessmen on the Committee are able to advise on existing manufacturing practices and on the practicality of the industrial guidelines now being developed. The social scientist on the Committee is familiar with the issues surrounding this technology including such aspects as risk assessment.

The representative of the Department of Health will be concerned with any public health implications. He will be able to draw upon the expertise of his Department as the need arises. The representatives of the Departments of Primary Industry and of Science and Technology have similar roles and capacities in their areas of concern. Thus the Committee draws on a wide range of expertise.

(3) Similar committees overseas vary considerably in both their terms of reference and membership. Many do have representatives drawn from the 'broader community'. Such committees were set up at a time of considerably greater speculation as to future hazards.

It is appropriate to note that in the eight or so years since this technique was first developed no novel hazard has been shown to be associated with the technique. This is despite an extensive series of experiments, conducted primarily by the National Institute of Health in the United States, which tried to produce the hazards postulated.

The terms of reference of the Australian Committee relate primarily to the physical and biological safety of the technology, both in research and industrial usage, and the composition of the Committee is well balanced and capable of monitoring the safety of this technology in Australia.

(4) and (5) Yes, Mr Justice Kirby sent me a copy of a speech in which he made comments to that effect. The application of these techniques to humans may well raise significant moral and ethical questions in the future. Resolution of such questions lies outside the terms of reference of the Recombinant DNA Monitoring Committee. I believe there will have to be general discussion of such matters by the community at large before a consensus view is reached. However, I am sure the Committee members will be sensitive to such issues and bring them to my attention, contribute to that discussion, and provide advice on scientific aspects when required.
I find Justice Kirby's comments valuable and will take them into account when making future appointments to the Committee.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that scientific research relating to the Crown of Thorns Starfish plague on the Great Barrier Reef, falls broadly into the 2 categories of (a) research studies which attribute the cause of plague proportions to human intervention and to human activity and (b) studies which attribute causation to natural or cyclical patterns.
(2) What is the extent of current Commonwealth Government funding for each type of research and at which institutions and by whom is the research being undertaken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The majority of research on crown of thorns starfish has not been specifically directed towards seeking a relationship between crown of thorns populations and human activity or natural events but has been directed at monitoring the distribution and size of crown of thorns populations, examining potentional control methods, obtaining population biology data where possible and investigating the genetic relationships between different populations of crown of thorns.
Despite years of research, there is still no evidence to support the suggestion that crown of thorns populations are the consequence of human activity on or near the Great Barrier Reef.
(2) In the 1979-80 and 1980-81 periods direct Commonwealth assistance to research on crown of thorns starfish was $113,000.
(i) Genetic studies of crown of thorns starfish populations (Dr J. S. Lucas, James Cook University) AMSTAC-FAP $3631; and
(ii) An historical study on previous crown of thorns populations and their relationships, if any, to human use of the reef (being developed by GBRMPA- approximate cost $25,000).
Commonwealth support is also being provided through the Tertiary Education Commission Commonwealth Graduate Awards. For example:
Genetic diversity in crown of thorns starfish populations (Mr W. Nash, James Cook University), in this instance supplemented by a Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority Augmentative Grant of $500.
